[Source: Adapted from File: bacteriophage-virus. Retrieved 10 December 2024 from: https://smart.servier.com/smart_image/bacteriophage-virus. CC BY 4.0]State two structural features common to all viruses.[2]Identify the name of this virus.[1]Label the capsid on the image.[1]Compare and contrast the lytic and lysogenic cycles.[4]
list.markScheme:
anytwoof the following:→\ce{ -> }​small size relative to living organismsORsize is fixed[1]→\ce{ -> }​contains nucleic acids as genetic materialORcontain genetic materialORcontain DNA or RNA (both needed for mark)[1]→\ce{ -> }​surrounded by a capsidORprotein coat[1]→\ce{ -> }​do not have cytoplasmORdo not have organelles[1][2 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Two structural features common to all viruses are that they contain eitherDNA or RNA(✓\checkmark✓), surrounded by acapsid(✓\checkmark✓).→\ce{ -> }​bacteriophageORlambda bacteriophageORlambda phage (phage on its own is not accepted)[1][1 mark maximum]see the image below

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/15372430-26ce-4b28-83fc-2ffbfac1c616/images/e3b47844-9c3d-4109-a3dc-5fdf96b5d2d3/BI0852%20mark%20scheme.png)

[Source: Adapted from File: bacteriophage-virus. Retrieved 10 December 2024 from: https://smart.servier.com/smart_image/bacteriophage-virus. CC BY 4.0][© Revision Village 2023. Created with Biorender.com][1 mark maximum]anyfourof the following, but answer must include at least one similarity and one difference to earn full marks:similarities→\ce{ -> }​BOTHcycles are mechanisms for phage,ORbacteriophage, reproduction[1]→\ce{ -> }​BOTHcycles require phage proteins to bind to specific receptors on the surface of the host bacterium[1]→\ce{ -> }​BOTHrequire phage DNA,ORphage genetic informationORphage genome, to be inserted into the host bacterium[1]differences→\ce{ -> }​in lytic cycle, host bacterial cells are killedORlysed,WHILEhost cells are not destroyedORlysed in lysogenic cycle[1]→\ce{ -> }​in lytic cycle, phage genomeORDNA remains separate to bacterial DNA within the host cell,WHILEphage DNA is inserted into host cell in lysogenic cycle[1]→\ce{ -> }​in lytic cycle, phage genes,ORDNA,ORgenetic information is expressed immediately,WHILEin the lysogenic cycle, genes are not transcribed,ORexpressed,ORgenetic information lies dormant[1]→\ce{ -> }​in lytic cycle  host cells are lysed rapidly, leading to immediate harm to the host bacterium,WHILEin lysogenic cycle, there is no harm to host for extended period of time,ORcycle is not immediate[1][4 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Bothlytic and lysogenic cycles are processes ofphage reproduction(✓\checkmark✓).Bothcycles start withphage proteins bindingto bacterial host cellreceptors(✓\checkmark✓), and then thegenetic materialisinjected(✓\checkmark✓) into the host cell. In thelytic cycle, phage DNA remains separateto thebacterial DNwithin the host cell, while in thelysogenic cycle, viral DNAisinserted into the host chromosome(✓\checkmark✓).

list.title: Question 154
list.content:
The photograph below is of the sea oat (Unola paniculata). This plant is found on sand dunes.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/1af502cc-5332-4529-ac1e-57e68511c43f/images/54f3a7af-d48b-4bb1-9278-4e35299e8584/BI1424.png)

[Source: Adapted from Daniel Di Palma (2 Feb 2017)Miami Beach - Sand Dune Flora - Sea Oats in South Beach. Retrieved 31 Jan 2024 from https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?curid=59792482. Copyright CC BY-SA 4.0]Explain how the sea oat (Unola paniculata) is adapted to survive in its environment.[3]Describe the importance of the solvent properties of water for transport in plants and humans.[3]
list.markScheme: Anythreeof the following:→\ce{ -> }​wide shallow root system that helps anchor them securely in shifting sandsORto allow rapid absorption of water from sandORto stabilise sand reducing rate of erosion[1]→\ce{ -> }​salt tolerance to survive exposure to salt spray from the sea[1]→\ce{ -> }​narrow leaves that reduce water loss through transpiration[1]→\ce{ -> }​flexibleORbendy stems allow sea oats to sway with the wind without breaking[1]→\ce{ -> }​long bristle-like structures on seeds that catch the wind to aid seed dispersal[1]→\ce{ -> }​some sea oat populations have a symbiotic relationship with nitrogen-fixing bacteria in their root nodules enabling them to survive in nutrient-poor beach soils[1]→\ce{ -> }​NodesORrhizomes allow regeneration after a fireORto reproduce asexually to survive being covered by sand[1][3 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Thewide, shallow rootsystem of sea oats allows them toanchor themselvesin the shifting sand (✓\checkmark✓) of the dunes and toabsorb water rapidly(✓\checkmark✓). Theirnarrow leaves reduce water lossthroughtranspiration(✓\checkmark✓) and theirflexible stemsallow them to survive thesea winds without breaking(✓\checkmark✓).Anythreeof the following (needoneexample for plants andoneexample for humans to gain maximum marks):→\ce{ -> }​water molecules are polarORhave an uneven distribution of charge so attract other polar moleculesORions through hydrogen bondingORwater dissolves hydrophilic substances[1]→\ce{ -> }​in cellular transport water allows movement of ionsORhydrophilic moleculesORpolar molecules around the cell[1]Plants→\ce{ -> }​xylemORtranspiration stream carries mineralsORmineralsORpotassiumORcalciumORmagnesium from roots[1]→\ce{ -> }​phloem carries nutrientsORsucroseORcarbohydratesORglucoseORamino acids[1]Humans→\ce{ -> }​blood plasma dissolves and transports sodium chlorideORglucoseORamino acidsORwastesORhormonesORoxygenORcarbon dioxide[1]→\ce{ -> }​oxygen dissolution in aqueous lining of lungs allows uptake of oxygen into blood[1]→\ce{ -> }​waste products are filtered out at the kidneyORwastes are transported in glomerular filtrateORwater allows the transport of wastes through the nephron to the bladder for excretion[1][3 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Becausewater moleculesarepolar, hydrophilic substances dissolveinaqueous solutions(✓\checkmark✓). Inplants, water transportsmineralsupfromtheroots, where they have been absorbed from the soil, to where they are needed in the plant (✓\checkmark✓).  In humans, water acts as the medium forblood plasma, transportingessentialnutrientsandoxygenaround the body (✓\checkmark✓).

list.title: Question 155
list.content: Distinguish between a colony of algal cells forming a multicellular sphere, and a multicellular plant such as a water lily.[3]Draw a labelled diagram which shows the structure of an animal cell.[5]Describe the evidence for the endosymbiotic theory.[7]
list.markScheme:
Anythreeof the following:→\ce{ -> }​colony of algal cells are generally undifferentiatedWHEREASmulticellular plants like water lilies are composed of different typesORdifferentiated of cells[1]→\ce{ -> }​noORminimal organisationORminimal division of labour of cells in algal colony,WHEREASin multicellular plant cells arranged into tissues, organs and organ systems,ORwell-defined structures carry out specific roles in plants[1]→\ce{ -> }​each individual algal cell is capable of performing all necessary functions for lifeORsurvival independentlyWHEREASmost individual cells of multicellular plants cannot survive independentlyORaway from the main body of the plant[1]→\ce{ -> }​each algal cell in a colony is genetically distinct,WHEREASnearly all cells in a multicellular organism are genetically identical[1]→\ce{ -> }​development of colonies is often simpleORcells simply join existing colonyWHEREASplants undergo complex developmental processes[1]→\ce{ -> }​reproduction in an algal colony typically involves asexual methodsWHEREASin multicellular plants such as the water lily typically involves sexual reproductionORmulticellular plants use both sexual and asexual reproduction[1][3 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Unlike true multicellular organisms like water lilies, algal colonieslack cellular differentiationandspecialised tissues.Individual cellswithin the colony aregenetically distinctand largelyindependent, being able to perform allvital functions. In contrast, most cells in themulticellularplant aregenetically identical(✓\checkmark✓) and usuallydo not survivewhenseparatedfrom the plant (✓\checkmark✓). These cells becomespecialised(✓\checkmark✓) and formtissues, organs, andorgan systemswithin the plant. This intricatedivision of labour(✓\checkmark✓) allows plants to achieve greater size and complexity.Anyfourof the following labelled correctly in an appropriate drawing of an animal cell:→\ce{ -> }​nucleus (shown with double membrane)[1]→\ce{ -> }​cytoplasm[1]→\ce{ -> }​cellORplasma membrane[1]→\ce{ -> }​mitochondrion[1]→\ce{ -> }​ribosome[1]→\ce{ -> }​golgi apparatus[1]→\ce{ -> }​rough endoplasmic reticulum[1]→\ce{ -> }​smooth endoplasmic reticulum[1]→\ce{ -> }​lysosome[1]and the following:→\ce{ -> }​diagram drawn without sketchy lines and acceptable size[1][5 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/1ff31851-24a7-4efc-b3a3-080da5df9c59/images/efb7b494-b22f-41fc-8c24-c635f2f9bcac/BI1050.png)

[© Revision Village 2022]Anysevenof the following:→\ce{ -> }​larger prokaryotesORcells engulfed smaller prokaryotesORcells[1]→\ce{ -> }​ingested cell was kept alive[1]→\ce{ -> }​symbiotic relationship between both cells[1]→\ce{ -> }​ingested cell acquired a second membrane[1]→\ce{ -> }​ingested cell is ancestor of chloroplastsORmitochondria[1]→\ce{ -> }​chloroplastORmitochondrial structures provide evidence for the endosymbiotic theory[1]→\ce{ -> }​chloroplastsORmitochondria contain 70S ribosomes[1]→\ce{ -> }​chloroplastsORmitochondria contain their own DNAORlooped DNA[1]→\ce{ -> }​chloroplastsORmitochondria can conduct transcriptionORtranslation[1]→\ce{ -> }​chloroplastsORmitochondria divide in a similar manner to prokaryotic cellsORby binary fission[1]→\ce{ -> }​chloroplastsORmitochondria are similar in size to prokaryotes[1][7 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:The endosymbiotic theory explains the origin of some structures in eukaryotic cells, including chloroplasts and mitochondria. Theancestorsof chloroplasts and mitochondria were prokaryotes thatwere engulfed by larger prokaryotes(✓\checkmark✓).  The ingested cells werekept alive(✓\checkmark✓) and both cells eventually developed asymbioticrelationship (✓\checkmark✓) with the cell that engulfed them. When the larger cells engulfed the smaller cells, the smaller cells gained asecond membrane(✓\checkmark✓) as they were engulfed via endocytosis. Further evidence for the theory is that chloroplasts and mitochondria contain their own70s ribosomes(✓\checkmark✓) so canmake their own proteins, and also containtheir own DNA(✓\checkmark✓) so can carry outtranscription(✓\checkmark✓). Chloroplasts and mitochondria are also able todivide in a similar manner to prokaryotic cells(✓\checkmark✓).A quality mark is awarded if each part of the question (a, b, c) is answered to earn at least half of the points available, answers do not require re-reading to be understood, and there are almost no errors and little irrelevant information.[1]

list.title: Question 157
list.content:
The Hershey-Chase experiment in 1952 involved cultured viruses that were radioactively labelled with either sulfur (35S) or phosphorus (32P) in two separate flasks. Each batch of viruses was then added to separate cultures of bacteria. After allowing time for the viruses to infect the bacteria, the culture solutions were centrifuged to separate the viral remains from the bacterial cells, forming two layers, the pellet and the supernatant.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/2f8b667a-860a-43e9-b612-fc096b40d7a2/images/1e94d3d8-01de-4530-87fd-2ef060887957/BI0900.png)

Created with Chemix (https://chemix.org)]State reasons for using radioactive sulfur (35S) and phosphorus (32P).[2]Suggest one technological development, other than radioisotopes, that helped open up possibilities in understanding the overall structure of DNA.[1]Outline the results of the experiment that provided evidence to support the conclusion that DNA is the genetic material.[2]Describe how the 4 nitrogenous bases of DNA enables polypeptides to be coded for.[2]Explain how DNA can be packaged into compact units to form chromatin.[3]
list.markScheme: Anytwoof the following (AT LEASTONEfor phosphorus andONEfor sulfur):→\ce{ -> }​sulfur is found in protein and not in DNA[1]→\ce{ -> }​35S is used to label protein[1]→\ce{ -> }​phosphorus is found in DNA and not in protein[1]→\ce{ -> }​32P is used to label DNA[1][2 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:35S is used becausesulphur is found in protein and not in DNA(✓\checkmark✓), and32P is used becausephosphorus is found in DNA and not protein(✓\checkmark✓).Anyoneof the following:→\ce{ -> }​X-ray crystallographyORdiffraction (by Rosalind Franklin)[1]→\ce{ -> }​paper chromatography (by Erwin Chargaff)[1][1 mark maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Another technological development used wasX-ray diffraction(✓\checkmark✓) by Rosalind Franklin which provided evidence that DNA has a helical shape.→\ce{ -> }​35SORradioactively labelled protein was found in the supernatantORnot found in the pelletORno radioactivity detected in bacteria infected with viruses labelled with35S[1]→\ce{ -> }​32PORradioactively labelled DNA was found in the pelletORnot found in the supernatantORradioactivity was detected in bacteria infected with viruses labelled with32P[1][2 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:The results from the Hershey-Chase experiment showed that35S, used tolabel protein, was found in the supernatant(✓\checkmark✓), and the32P, used to label DNA, was found in the pellet (✓\checkmark✓).Anytwoof the following:→\ce{ -> }​the four nitrogenous bases are A, T, G, CORadenine, thymine, guanine, cytosine[1]→\ce{ -> }​polypeptides are coded for by genes OR a sequence of nucleotides[1]→\ce{ -> }​three nitrogenous basesORcodonORtriplet of bases, code for a specific amino acidORstartORstop[1]→\ce{ -> }​degenerative codeORseveral codons can code for one amino acid[1]→\ce{ -> }​DNA as a templateORantisense strand to form mRNA strand[1]→\ce{ -> }​complementary base pairing between DNA nucleotides and RNA nucleotidesORbetween codons on mRNA and amino acid[1]→\ce{ -> }​mRNA is used as template to form polypeptide chains[1][2 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Polypeptides are coded for bygenes(✓\checkmark✓) made up of a specific sequence of nucleotides. A nucleotide consists of a ribose sugar, a phosphate group and one of four nitrogenous bases -adenine, guanine, cytosine and thymine(✓\checkmark✓).  DNA  is used as atemplate to form the mRNA strand(✓\checkmark✓). A triplet of bases,a codon, along the mRNA strand codes for aspecific amino acid(✓\checkmark✓).Anythreeof the following:→\ce{ -> }​DNA tightly wraps around a core of eight histone proteins[1]→\ce{ -> }​held together by an additional histone proteinORH1 linker protein[1]→\ce{ -> }​H1 histone proteins binds the nucleosomes together to form a 30 nm chromatin fibre[1]→\ce{ -> }​long DNA molecules are packed into a small space[1]→\ce{ -> }​the negatively charged DNA is attracted to the positively charged histones[1]→\ce{ -> }​form structures called nucleosomes[1]→\ce{ -> }​nucleosomes are attached to other nucleosomes by linker DNA[1][3 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:DNA coils tightly around a core ofeight histone proteins(✓\checkmark✓) which are held together byH1 histone proteins(✓\checkmark✓) to form structures known asnucleosomes(✓\checkmark✓). Thenucleosomesare bundledtogetherto form the30nm fibre chromatin(✓\checkmark✓).

list.title: Question 158
list.content: The table below shows the percentage of the amino acid sequences of cytochrome c shared between a human and four other species.Species PairCytochrome c sequence shared (%)Human–chimpanzee99Human–mouse87Human–chicken75Human–zebrafish50Which conclusion is best supported by these data?A.\hspace{1em}A human and a chimpanzee shared a common ancestor more recently than a human and a mouse.B.\hspace{1em}Cytochrome c has evolved faster in the chicken lineage than in the mouse lineage.C.\hspace{1em}The human–zebrafish divergence occurred most recently.D.\hspace{1em}The molecular clock runs at different rates in mammals and fish.
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Ais correct because there is a higher percentage similarity for the cytochrome c amino acid sequence between the human and chimpanzee (99%) compared to the human and mouse (87%). This indicates less time for mutations to accumulate, meaning humans and chimpanzees shared a common ancestor more recently than humans and mice.Choice Bis incorrect because although the cytochrome c percentage similarity is lower in chickens (75%) than in mice (87%), this alone does not confirm that cytochrome c evolved faster in the chicken lineage. To determine evolutionary rates, both sequence similarity and known divergence times are needed.Choice Cis incorrect because the lowest sequence similarity (50%) between human and zebrafish suggests the longest time since divergence, not the most recent.Choice Dis incorrect because differences in sequence similarity alone cannot demonstrate variation in molecular clock rates. The molecular clock is a concept based on the idea that mutations accumulate at a relatively constant rate over time in most species. To conclude rate differences, both the time since divergence and the number of accrued changes must both be known.

list.title: Question 159
list.content: What characteristic of DNA allows it to serve as a template for both DNA replication and mRNA synthesis?A.\hspace{1em}The genetic code in DNA is universal across all organismsB.\hspace{1em}Hydrogen bonding enables the correct alignment of deoxyribonucleotides and ribonucleotides in newly synthesised strandsC.\hspace{1em}DNA’s double helix structure means one strand can be replicated at the same time as the other is being transcribedD.\hspace{1em}The strong sugar-phosphate backbone
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Bis correct. During both replication and transcription, nucleotides are aligned along the DNA template strand according to base-pairing rules. Hydrogen bonds form between the nitrogenous bases of the template DNA strand and the incoming deoxyribonucleotides (during replication) or ribonucleotides (in transcription).The genetic code being universal means that the same codons code for the same amino acids in all organisms. However, this relates to protein synthesis, not to how DNA acts as a template for replication or transcription;Choice Ais incorrect.Choice Cis incorrect because replication and transcription can’t occur on opposite strands simultaneously.Choice Dis incorrect because while the sugar-phosphate backbone is a feature of both DNA and RNA strands that provides structural stability, it does not explain how DNA can interact with both DNA and RNA nucleotides.

list.title: Question 160
list.content:
Which of the labelled structures shows the correct directionality of the DNA molecule?

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/3fd5dfef-fa67-41d4-888d-d6469c0c0ba7/images/f01a75fa-dbe1-4a7e-b42c-c434520d15a4/BI0891A.png)



![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/3fd5dfef-fa67-41d4-888d-d6469c0c0ba7/images/946a1579-f3ea-4b5e-b8bf-f0c789af6574/BI0891B.png)

[ © Revision Village 2023]
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Cis correct because the left strand is running in the 5’ - 3’ direction with the phosphate group attached to the 5th carbon at the 5’ end, and the 3rd carbon of the terminating deoxyribose sugar is free. The right strand is running antiparallel in the 3’-5’ direction.Choice Ais incorrect because both strands are labelled as running in the 5’ - 3’ direction, and the carbons of the deoxyribose sugars are incorrectly labelled.Choice Bis incorrect because the strands are incorrectly labelled with the 5’ and 3’ ends, and the carbons of the deoxyribose sugars are incorrectly labelled on both strands.Choice Dis incorrect because both strands are labelled as running in the 3’ - 5’ direction, and the carbons of the deoxyribose sugars on both strands are incorrectly labelled.

list.title: Question 161
list.content:
The image shows a ringed seal (Pusa hispida) that lives in the Arctic Sea.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/4b6b08e8-875d-4ac4-abba-a9c4c27a129b/images/d4b9a85b-c422-4e0a-b290-37d692fd87be/BI0835.png)

[Source: Adapted from: Kingfisher. (2021, May 29). Pusa hispida. Wikimedia Commons. Retrieved from July 07, 2023, from https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/Pusa_hispida. Copyright free]Distinguish between the physical properties of air and water that allow the seal to mostly live in the sea.[2]Ringed seals glide into the water head first from ice shelves, rather like humans diving into a pool head first. Explain the advantage of entering the water in this way rather than ‘belly-flopping’ into the water.[2]
list.markScheme: Anytwoof the following:→\ce{ -> }​water has a high specific heat capacityCOMPARED TOair, so its temperature remains relatively stable compared to airORso water remains relatively warmer during the winter[1]→\ce{ -> }​water has a higher densityCOMPARED TOair, and this supports the seal’s body weight as the water exerts buoyant forces on the seal[1]→\ce{ -> }​water has a higher viscosityCOMPARED TOair, providing the seal with more resistance to movementORmotion, which provides the seal with thrust and propulsion for swimming[1][2 marks maximum]Sample Answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample Answer}}Sample Answer​:The ringed seal is mostly able to live in water rather than air as water has ahigh specific heat capacitycompared to air, so itstemperature remains relatively stableso that the seal does not get too cold (✓\checkmark✓). Water has ahigher densitycompared to air, and thissupportsthe seal’sbody weightas the water exertsbuoyant forceson the seal (✓\checkmark✓).Anytwoof the following:→\ce{ -> }​water has a high surface tension due to hydrogen bondsTHEREFORE, ‘belly-flopping’ will cause pain due to the hydrogen bonds breaking forcefullyORgliding/diving causes hydrogen bonds between water molecules to be broken more gentlyORentering head first reduces the body surface area that initially comes into contact with the waterTHEREFOREreducing water resistance[1]→\ce{ -> }​gliding in is more energy-efficient for the seal as they use momentum generated from sliding on ice[1]→\ce{ -> }​gliding is more stealthy OR quiet, which allows the seal to avoid predators[1]→\ce{ -> }​gliding is more controlled, so the seal is at less risk of injury[1][2 marks maximum]Sample Answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample Answer}}Sample Answer​:Gliding in head first’ is advantageous as water has ahigh surface tensiondue to the high number of hydrogen bonds between water molecules, therefore,  ‘belly-flopping’ may causepainfrombreaking the hydrogen bondsforcefully (✓\checkmark✓). Gliding is morestealthyso the seal has more chance of catching prey orescaping predators(✓\checkmark✓).

list.title: Question 162
list.content: How are the chromosomes in a karyogram ordered?A.\hspace{1em}By analogous pairsB.\hspace{1em}By number of genesC.\hspace{1em}By sizeD.\hspace{1em}By position of the centromeres
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Cis correct because the chromosomes in a karyogram are ordered in homologous pairs from largest to smallest.Choice Ais incorrect because chromosomes are grouped in homologous pairs (one from each parent), not analogous pairs.Choice Bis incorrect because the number of genes on each chromosome is highly variable, and genes do not have a consistent length. Although the chromosomes are aligned with their centromeres in a karyogram, the question only asks about the order of the chromosomes, which is not dependent on centromere position; thus,Choice Dis also incorrect.

list.title: Question 163
list.content: Which of the following thermal properties of water isincorrectlymatched?PropertyWaterA.\hspace{1em}Melting Point0°\degree°CB.\hspace{1em}Specific Heat Capacity2.2 Jg−1\text{g}^{-1}g−1°C−1\degree \text{C}^{-1}°C−1C.\hspace{1em}Latent Heat of Vaporisation760 Jg−1\text{g}^{-1}g−1D.\hspace{1em}Boiling Point100°\degree°C
list.markScheme: BExplanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}Explanation:​Choice Bis incorrectly matched. The specific heat capacity of water is 4.2 Jg−1°C−1\text{g}^{-1} \degree \text{C}^{-1}g−1°C−1, not 2.2  Jg−1°C−1\text{g}^{-1} \degree \text{C}^{-1}g−1°C−1.Choice A,C, andDare correctly matched.

list.title: Question 164
list.content:
All organisms contain genetic material. The type, quantity and location of genetic material differ between kingdoms and species.State if the cell shown in the image is a prokaryotic or eukaryotic cell. Give a reason for your answer.[1]

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/8024806a-71b0-45c1-abd9-26abe1b9d775/images/4acbd2c2-a08b-4399-bb2b-e8c3deecb828/BI0199.png)

[Source: Adapted from Ruiz (16th January 2007).File: Prokaryote cell diagram international.svg.Wikimedia commons. Retrieved 18th May 2022 from https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File: Prokaryote_cell_diagram_international.svg. Copyright-free]Distinguish between prokaryotic and eukaryotic DNA.[2]
list.markScheme: The following:→\ce{ -> }​prokaryotic cellBECAUSEchromosome is loopedORno nucleus is present[1][1 mark maximum]Sample Answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample Answer}}Sample Answer​:This is aprokaryotic(✓\checkmark✓) cell because the chromosome isnot within a nucleus(✓\checkmark✓).Anytwoof the following:→\ce{ -> }​prokaryotic DNA is looped,BUTthe majority of eukaryotic DNA is linear[1]→\ce{ -> }​prokaryotic DNA is not contained in a nucleus,BUTthe majority of eukaryotic DNA is found within a nucleus[1]→\ce{ -> }​prokaryotic DNA is found in a chromosome and plasmidsWHEREASthe majority of eukaryotic DNA is found in chromosomes and not in plasmids[1]→\ce{ -> }​the majority of eukaryotic DNA is always associated with proteins (histones)WHILEprokaryotic DNA is not bound to proteins (with the exception ofArchaewhose DNA is associated with proteins)[1][2 mark maximum]Sample Answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample Answer}}Sample Answer​:Prokaryotic DNA is looped while the majority of eukaryoticDNA is linear(✓\checkmark✓). DNA can be found inplasmids in some prokaryotes(✓\checkmark✓), while the only plasmids found in eukaryotes are present in mitochondria and chloroplasts.

list.title: Question 165
list.content:
Which of the following pairs of limbs are homologous?A.\hspace{2cm}B.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/95ce83ee-4cfc-4990-979c-7472080d185f/images/b2b1c0e9-ab57-4231-aee5-6518a9f9bc32/BI1577A.png)



![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/95ce83ee-4cfc-4990-979c-7472080d185f/images/62b811f3-008e-4d9f-9a9b-44a6e73f64f6/BI1577B.png)

C.D.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/95ce83ee-4cfc-4990-979c-7472080d185f/images/546632a5-9c94-4e3d-9ed0-eef9040b8de0/BI1577C.png)



![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/95ce83ee-4cfc-4990-979c-7472080d185f/images/ec7a434a-80b0-4dba-9293-d513594f781c/BI1577D.png)

[© Revision Village 2024. Created with BioRender.com]
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Dis correct because the horse and sea lion limbs have the same bones in the same order. This is the result of common ancestry between the two species, making these structures homologous despite their different functions.Choices A, B,andCare incorrect because these are examples of analogous structures as a result of convergent evolution. Analogous structures share a common function but do not share a common ancestry. A further clue is that horse and sea lion are both mammals, whereas the other pairs of animals belong to different taxonomic groups (Choice A= mammal, insect;Choice B= mammal, crustacean;Choice C= mollusc, echinoderm).

list.title: Question 166
list.content:
It is thought that the Congo River divided a population of the common ancestor of bonobos (Pan paniscus) and chimpanzees (Pan troglodytes), resulting in geographic isolation.  Which correctly pairs theoretical selection pressures and consequent adaptations of the two populations?

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/95d2e015-b514-409e-bc3c-a4d60240f3d6/images/e9f0bfbf-b64e-4476-8fa3-e01eb43f2eb1/BI0859.png)
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Bis correct because a scarcity of food as well as competition with gorillas, led to increased aggression in the ancestral population to chimpanzees and plentiful food on the south side of the river, as well as an absence of gorillas led to increased cooperation in the ancestral population of bonobos.Choice Ais incorrect because there was and is no difference in solar radiation on either side of the Congo River.Choice Cis incorrect because the selection pressures and adaptations are reversed in terms of where they existed (south side vs. north side).Choice Dis incorrect because food scarcity led to more aggression, and plentiful food led to more cooperation.

list.title: Question 167
list.content: Which role of RNA supports the hypothesis that it acted as the first genetic material?A.\hspace{1em}It functions as a primer during transcriptionB.\hspace{1em}It functions as an enzyme used by ribosomesC.\hspace{1em}It serves as a template for polypeptide synthesisD.\hspace{1em}It transports amino acids during translation
list.markScheme: BSample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:RNA has the ability to self-replicate and can also act as an enzyme. These two properties contribute to the hypothesis that RNA was the first genetic material, rather than DNA.Choice Bis correct.Choice Ais incorrect, as transcription does not involve primers.Choice Cis incorrect, as RNA’s role as a template for polypeptide synthesis does not contribute to the hypothesis that it was the first genetic material.Choice Dis wrong, as RNA’s role in transporting amino acids during translation does not contribute to the hypothesis that it was the first genetic material.

list.title: Question 168
list.content: Which statements about chloroplasts and mitochondria support the endosymbiotic theory?ChloroplastsMitochondria\hspace{1em}A.\hspace{1em}Contain 70S ribosomesContain cristae\hspace{1em}B.\hspace{1em}Found in prokaryotesContain 80S ribosomes\hspace{1em}C.\hspace{1em}Have a single membraneContain circular DNA\hspace{1em}D.\hspace{1em}Contain 70S ribosomesHave a double membrane
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The endosymbiotic theory states that larger prokaryotes engulfed smaller prokaryotes, which were the ancestors of modern chloroplasts and mitochondria. The smaller prokaryotes were engulfed via endocytosis, so they have their original membrane as well as the membrane of the larger prokaryote.   Both chloroplasts and mitochondria have 70S ribosomes and a double membrane.Choice Dis correct.Choice Ais incorrect because the fact that mitochondria contain cristae is not due to the endosymbiotic theory.Choice Bis incorrect because chloroplasts are not found in prokaryotes.Choice Cis incorrect because chloroplasts have a double membrane.

list.title: Question 169
list.content: Which of the following equations is true for the number of bases in a double-stranded DNA molecule?A.\hspace{1em}1=A+TC+G1=\dfrac{\ce{A + T}}{\ce{C + G}}1=C+GA+T​B.\hspace{1em}AC=GT\dfrac{\ce{A}}{\ce{C}}=\dfrac{\ce{G}}{\ce{T}}CA​=TG​C.\hspace{1em}A×T=C×G\ce{A \times T = C \times G}A×T=C×GD.\hspace{1em}AT=CG\dfrac{\ce{A}}{\ce{T}}=\dfrac{\ce{C}}{\ce{G}}TA​=GC​
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Dis correct. Chargaff’s rule states that the ratio of Aand of Cis 1:1. Therefore A/T = C/G as both sides of the equation should be 1.Choice Ais not correct because within a double-strand of DNA different types of bases will exist in an equal percentage as their complementary base pair (e.g. % of C= % of G). However, the two sets of pairs will not necessarily be equal to each other.Choice Bis not correct because A and C / T and G are not complementary base pairs, so will not exist in equal numbers to each other. Therefore it is unlikely that both sides of the equation are equal.Choice Cis not correct because within a double-strand of DNA different types of bases will exist in an equal percentage as their complementary base pair (e.g. % of C = % of G). However, the two sets of pairs will not necessarily be equal to each other. Therefore, both sides of the equation are likely to be different.

list.title: Question 170
list.content:
Which of the following represents the correct structure of RNA?A.\hspace{2cm}B.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/ac6dd223-2d74-4170-a8cf-7210719060f1/images/8671af0f-da99-480e-80ca-0fdf4b17f42b/BI1565A.png)



![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/ac6dd223-2d74-4170-a8cf-7210719060f1/images/527f702a-baf1-4b73-babd-c3c83e22f26f/BI1565B.png)

C.D.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/ac6dd223-2d74-4170-a8cf-7210719060f1/images/7b9be57f-fb83-43ae-b478-a6656a0c6960/BI1565C.png)



![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/ac6dd223-2d74-4170-a8cf-7210719060f1/images/54ad8ec1-a9ea-4fc9-8c0d-3e39ee4a6651/BI1565D.png)

[© Revision Village 2024. Created with BioRender.com]
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Cis correct because RNA is a single-stranded nucleic acid that contains adenine (A), cytosine (C), uracil (U), and guanine (G) nucleotide bases, while DNA is a double-stranded nucleic acid containing thymine (T) instead of uracil. The nucleotide bases are covalently bonded to a pentose sugar, which is covalently bonded to a phosphate at the 5’ and 3’ ends.Choice Ais incorrect as this is the structure of a DNA molecule, including a thymine base.Choice Bis incorrect because RNA does not contain thymine.Choice Dis incorrect because the diagram shows a double-stranded molecule similar to DNA,  but the strands are incorrectly depicted as parallel instead of the correct anti-parallel orientation.

list.title: Question 171
list.content:
Below is a picture of a water strider (Gerrissp.\textit{Gerris sp.}Gerris sp.).

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/acd82ba4-e9b6-4ad4-9ae7-0cba2f0322ee/images/98250f20-3d55-4380-b054-95cf70aeb72c/BI0187i_2.2.png)

[Source: Schnobby. (2010).Water Strider. Wikimedia Commons. Retrieved April 27, 2022, from https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File: Water_strider_in_a_pond.jpg. Copyright by CC BY-SA 3.0]Explain why the water strider (Gerrissp.\textit{Gerris sp.}Gerris sp.) does not sink.[2]Describe, using an example, the importance of water as a solvent in living organisms.[3]
list.markScheme:
Anytwoof the following:→\ce{ -> }​cohesion,ORcohesive properties, of water is responsible[1]→\ce{ -> }​water molecules bind to other water molecules[1]→\ce{ -> }​water molecules form intermolecular hydrogen bonds[1]→\ce{ -> }​cohesion results in high surface tension of water[1]→\ce{ -> }​legs of the insect are hydrophobic[1][2 mark maximum]Sample Answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample Answer}}Sample Answer​:Cohesion(✓\checkmark✓) is the water property that is responsible for this phenomenon. Watermolecules bind with other water molecules(✓\checkmark✓) throughhydrogen bonds(✓\checkmark✓)to createhigh surface tension(✓\checkmark✓). The legs of the water strider are covered in a secreted wax, making themhydrophobic(✓\checkmark✓), which allows the water strider to move on top of the water.Anythreeof the following (maximum of 2 marks if no example is provided):→\ce{ -> }​metabolic reactions can only happen in solutions[1]→\ce{ -> }​water dissolves hydrophilic substances needed for life processes[1]→\ce{ -> }​substances can be transported through the water-based solutions[1]→\ce{ -> }​blood plasma dissolves and transports sodium chlorideORglucoseORamino acidsORany other valid example in animals[1]→\ce{ -> }​water dissolves and transports nutrientsORminerals needed by plantsORany other valid example in plants[1][3 mark maximum]Sample Answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample Answer}}Sample Answer​:Water dissolves hydrophilic substances(✓\checkmark✓)
required formetabolic reactions(✓\checkmark✓) which can only occur in solution.  Dissolved substances can react with each other and also betransported(✓\checkmark✓)to other parts of an organism. For example, water dissolves and transports glucose in theblood plasma(✓\checkmark✓).

list.title: Question 172
list.content:
The cladogram below shows three possible evolutionary origins of the platypus (Platypus X, Y, and Z), an egg-laying mammal with webbed feet. The italicised taxa are extinct.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b1d5b447-bd27-4715-ae01-364bf736d736/images/2b9787f4-b693-44f9-8732-f9b721309317/bi0565.png)

[Sources: adapted from Celik, M.A. and Phillips, M.J. (2020).Conflict Resolution for Mesozoic Mammals: Reconciling Phylogenetic Incongruence Among Anatomical Regions. Front. Genet. 11:0651. Retrieved January 4, 2023 from https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/32774343/. Copyright  under CC BY 4.0]State the taxa most closely related to marsupials.[1]Based on the taxa shown in the cladogram, deduce one reason for the difficulty in identifying the true divergence of the platypus.[1]The cladogram shown is based on morphological traits. Describeoneother type of evidence that can be used to deduce evolutionary relationships.[2]Suggestonetype of morphological evidence that could be used to provide support for Platypus Z over Platypus X as the origin of the platypus.[1]Taxonomists classify organisms according to their evolutionary origins using a hierarchical classification system.Outline the principal taxonomic ranks in the modern classification system.[2]
list.markScheme: →\ce{->}​placental mammals[1][1 mark maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Placental mammals(✓\checkmark✓) are most closely related to marsupials. They are both members of Theria.Anyoneof the following:→\ce{->}​most species are extinct[1]→\ce{->}​must rely on fossil evidence[1][1 mark maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Most of the speciesin the cladogramare extinct(✓\checkmark✓), so scientistsmust rely on fossils(✓\checkmark✓) of these organisms to identify relatedness and determine the divergence of the platypus.Anytwoof the following:→\ce{->}​DNA sequenceORgene sequencesORamino acid sequencesORprotein sequences[1]→\ce{->}​compare sequences for shared geneORprotein in different species[1]→\ce{->}​number of differences in sequences indicates degree of relatednessORthe more differences there are between species the more distantly related they are[1][2 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Scientists can useDNA sequences(✓\checkmark✓) to determine evolutionary relationships. For example, scientists mightcomparethe nucleotidesequence of a shared geneacross species (✓\checkmark✓). By comparing the sequences of nucleotides in the same gene, scientists can inferthe order in which the changes most likely occurred. This allows them to determine the most likelydivergence order(✓\checkmark✓) among the organisms.Anyoneof the following:→\ce{->}​identificationORcomparison of homologous structures[1]→\ce{->}​identification of vestigial structures[1][1 mark maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Scientists couldidentify and compare homologous structures(✓\checkmark✓) in the platypus to those of other mammals. For example, if the webbed feet of the platypus are more like the feet of marsupials than the feet of ancestral species likeDocodonta, the platypus may be more closely related to Theria than it is toDocodonta.OR Alternative answerScientists couldidentify vestigial structures(✓\checkmark✓) in the platypus and other mammals. For example, if the platypus and marsupials have similar vestigial structures that are also similar to functional structures that were present in earlier groups of mammals, the platypus likely emerged afterDocodontain the evolution of mammals.Anytwoof the following:→\ce{->}​domain is the largest rank[1]→\ce{->}​the three domains are Archaea, Eubacteria, and Eukarya[1]→\ce{->}​domain Eukarya is split into kingdoms[1]→\ce{->}​from largest to smallest, kingdoms are divided into phylaORphylum, classes, orders, families, generaORgenuses, and species[1]→\ce{->}​species are sometimes divided into subspecies[1][2 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Thelargest rankin the classification system is thedomain(✓\checkmark✓). There are three domains –Archaea, Eubacteria, and Eukarya(✓\checkmark✓). Thedomain Eukarya is divided into 4 kingdoms(✓\checkmark✓) – Protista, Fungi, Plantae, and Animalia. Eachkingdom is further divided, from largest to smallest into phyla, class, order, family, genus, and species(✓\checkmark✓).

list.title: Question 173
list.content: Outline the steps in calculating the magnification of a micrograph.[4]Describe the steps taken to focus on a specimen using the 40x objective lens of a light microscope.[4]
list.markScheme: Anyfourof the following:→\ce{->}​measure (using a ruler) the scale bar on the drawingORmicrograph[1]→\ce{->}​note the stated length which the scale bar represents[1]→\ce{->}​convert the represented and real length or scale bar into the same units[1]→\ce{->}​M= I/AORany correct example of the calculation[1][4 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:To calculate the magnification of a microphotograph, the first step is to measurethe scale bar using a ruler(✓\checkmark✓). The second step isto note the length the scale bar represents(✓\checkmark✓). This gives you the actual size of the image. These two measurements should be converted tothe same units(✓\checkmark✓). The last step is todivide the length measured by the ruler by the length represented by the scale bar(✓\checkmark✓). During this calculation, units cancel out.  Therefore, themagnification does not have units.Anyfourof the following:→\ce{->}​use the lowest powerOR4X objective lens first[1]→\ce{->}​place the specimenORslide directly below the objective lensORon the centre of the microscope stage[1]→\ce{->}​turn the coarse focus knob to focus on the specimen at 4X[1]→\ce{->}​adjust the turretORchange the objective lens so the medium powerOR10X objective lens is used[1]→\ce{->}​refocus on the specimen using a fine focus knob at 10X and 40X[1]→\ce{->}​adjust the turretORchange the objective lens, so the high powerOR40X objective lens is used[1]→\ce{->}​while fine focusing always move the lens away from the slide[1][4 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Place the specimenin the centreof the microscope stage  (✓\checkmark✓).  Use the4x objective lens first(✓\checkmark✓) and use thecoarse focus knob(✓\checkmark✓) to focus on the specimen.  Adjust the position of the specimen so it is in the middle of the field of view and thenswitch to the 10x(✓\checkmark✓) objective lens andrefocus using the fine focus knob, (✓\checkmark✓) by moving lensaway from the specimen(✓\checkmark✓) to prevent lens breakage.  Finally, switch to the40x objective lens(✓\checkmark✓) and use thefine focus knobto refocus on the specimen.

list.title: Question 174
list.content:
The micrograph below showsCyanobacteria, which contain chlorophyll.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/c3dfa29a-d486-40b4-9fc1-d44b66ce3fc7/images/937853fc-bf32-495b-aba7-33e0cf82a199/BI1197-SL.png)

[Source: Adapted from Thompson L. and Whatson N. (2007, January 1).Cyanobacteria.  Wikipedia.  Retrieved on September 6, 2023, from https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cyanobacteria#. Copyright under CCO]Using your knowledge and the micrograph, state two features that would indicate that this is a bacterium.[2]Outline the structural differences between animal and plant cells.[3]Explain how light energy is used in photosynthesis to carry out anabolic reactions.[3]
list.markScheme: Anytwoof the following→\ce{ -> }​cell wall of peptidoglycan[1]→\ce{ -> }​naked DNAORDNA not associated with histonesORproteins[1]→\ce{ -> }​nucleoidORDNA free in cytoplasm[1]→\ce{ -> }​no membrane bound organelles[1]→\ce{ -> }​70s ribosomes[1]→\ce{ -> }​cell smaller than 10μm[1][2 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Two features that would indicate that this is a bacterium are it hasno membrane-bound organelles(✓\checkmark✓) and70s ribosomes(✓\checkmark✓).Anythreeof the following:→\ce{ -> }​plant cells have a cell wall,WHEREASanimal cells do not[1]→\ce{ -> }​plant cells generally have a central vacuoleWHEREASanimal cells do not[1]→\ce{ -> }​plant cells have chloroplastsWHEREASanimal cells do not[1]→\ce{ -> }​animal cells may have lysosomesWHEREASplant cells do not[1]→\ce{ -> }​animal cells may have ciliaORflagellaWHEREASplant cells do not[1]→\ce{ -> }​animal cells have centriolesWHEREASplant cells do not[1][3 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Plant cells have acell wall, central vacuoleandchloroplasts, whereasanimalcellsdo not(✓\checkmark✓) (✓\checkmark✓) (✓\checkmark✓).Anythreeof the following:→\ce{ -> }​light energy is absorbed by chlorophyll[1]→\ce{ -> }​light energy is transferred to electronsORis used to excite electrons[1]→\ce{ -> }​light energy splitting water moleculesORphotolysis releases electrons for the electron transport chainORhydrogen ions for use in ATP production[1]→\ce{ -> }​light energy is used to synthesise ATP from ADP and inorganic phosphateORNADPH from electrons and one proton[1]→\ce{ -> }​NADPHORATP is used to make larger organic compoundsORglucoseORstarchORother named organic compound from carbon dioxide[1][3 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Light energy isabsorbedbychlorophyll(✓\checkmark✓) and is used toexcite electrons(✓\checkmark✓).  These electrons reduceNADP+to formNADPH, which is an anabolic reaction (✓\checkmark✓).  Energy present inNADPHis then used toproduce glucosefromcarbon dioxide(✓\checkmark✓).  This is also an anabolic reaction.

list.title: Question 175
list.content:
The diagram below shows the structure of DNA nucleotides.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d2ec462e-9faf-4026-9eb2-c56d6db3f2b2/images/74d13066-c44a-4c8c-ad4b-36170db36b8a/BI0899A.png)

[Source: Adapted from OpenStax Anatomy and Physiology, (2016, May).File:0322 DNA Nucleotides.jpg. Wikimedia commons. Retrieved July 6, 2023, from https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:0322_DNA_Nucleotides.jpg. Copyright under CC-BY-4.0]State the component of DNA that is attached at position X.[1]Identify the type of bonding shown as dotted lines in the diagram.[1]The 5’ and 3’ linkages in DNA play an important role in replication, transcription and translation.On the diagram, label the 5’ prime and 3’ prime ends on both strands to show the direction of the DNA.[1]Outline how the processes of transcription and translation occur with regards to the formation of  5’ and 3’ linkages.[2]Explain how the DNA helix maintains its stability.[2]Erwin Chargaff’s data on the relative amounts of purine and pyrimidine bases played an important role in determining the structure of DNA.Outline how Chargaff’s data contributed to our understanding of the structure of DNA.[2]State a proposed model of DNA that was falsified by Chargaff's data.[1]
list.markScheme:
\hspace{1em}→\ce{ -> }​phosphateORphosphate group[1][1 mark maximum]\hspace{1em}Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:\hspace{1em}Aphosphate groupis found at X (✓\checkmark✓).\hspace{1em}→\ce{ -> }​hydrogenORhydrogen bonds[1][1 mark maximum]\hspace{1em}Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:\hspace{1em}Hydrogenbonding (✓\checkmark✓).→\ce{ -> }​both strands are labelled correctly with 5’ at the available 5th carbon and 3’ at the available 3rd carbon[1][1 mark maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d2ec462e-9faf-4026-9eb2-c56d6db3f2b2/images/2506b383-fa8c-4d98-9f33-ad5bce798cdb/BI0899ANSA.png)

Anytwoof the following (AT LEASTONEfrom transcription andONEfrom translation):transcription→\ce{ -> }​RNA polymerase adds nucleotides to the 3’ end of the growing mRNA strand[1]→\ce{ -> }​RNA polymerase creates the RNA strand in the 5’ to the 3’ direction[1]→\ce{ -> }​RNA polymerase reads the DNA template strand in the 3’ to 5’ direction[1]→\ce{ -> }​the new nucleotides are added to the 3’ end through phosphodiester linkages between the 3’ carbon of the last nucleotide and the phosphate group of the incoming nucleotide[1]translation→\ce{ -> }​ribosome moves along the mRNA from the 5’ end to the 3’ end[1]→\ce{ -> }​codons of the mRNA are read from the 5’ end to the 3’ end to add amino acids that form the polypeptide[1][2 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:In transcription, RNA polymerasereads the DNA template strand in the 3’ to 5’ direction(✓\checkmark✓) and creates theRNA strand in the opposite direction(✓\checkmark✓). In translation, theribosome moves along the mRNA in the 5’ to 3’ direction(✓\checkmark✓).Anytwoof the following:→\ce{ -> }​purine-to-pyrimidine bondingORcomplementary base pairing[1]→\ce{ -> }​adenine-thymineORA-T and cytosine-guanineORC-G have equal lengths[1]→\ce{ -> }​hydrogen bonding between complementary bases[1]→\ce{ -> }​hydrophobic interaction between adjacent bases[1]→\ce{ -> }​phosphodiester bonds link the 3’ carbon of one deoxyribose sugar to the phosphate group on the 5’ carbon of the next, forming a strong sugar-phosphate backbone[1]→\ce{ -> }​by winding around central histone proteins in eukaryotes to form nucleosomes[1][2 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:The DNA double helix maintains its stability throughcomplementary base pairing of purine to pyrimidine(✓\checkmark✓). This base pairing is held together by 2hydrogen bondsbetween adenine to thymine and 3hydrogen bonds(✓\checkmark✓) between cytosine and guanine.Anytwoof the following:→\ce{ -> }​showed the ratio of adenine to thymine and guanine to cytosine are equal[1]→\ce{ -> }​showed that the four nucleotide bases are not in repeating sequencesORequally distributed[1]→\ce{ -> }​suggested that DNA consists of two complementary strands[1]→\ce{ -> }​showed that the composition of DNA varies across diverse life forms[1]→\ce{ -> }​helped Watson and Crick in building the double helix shape of their DNA model[1]→\ce{ -> }​base pairing data suggested A pairs with T and G pairs with C[1]→\ce{ -> }​base pairing data suggested  mechanisms whereby DNA could replicateORbe transcribed[1][2 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Chargaff’s data showed that the molarratio of adenine to thymineand theratio of guanine to cytosineare close to 1:1 (✓\checkmark✓). This data then helped Watson and Crick to deduce thatDNA consists of two complementary strands(✓\checkmark✓) and ishelical in shape(✓\checkmark✓).Anyoneof the following:→\ce{ -> }​tetranucleotide hypothesisORtheory of four nucleotide bases in repeating sequenceORrepeating tetramer nucleic acid[1]→\ce{ -> }​the purely protein-based genetic material[1][1 mark maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Thetetranucleotide hypothesis(✓\checkmark✓) was falsified by Chargaff’s data.

list.title: Question 176
list.content:
The diagram shows three dividing eukaryotic cells (not drawn to scale).

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d44418d9-eb6c-4a6b-9968-42a3f6f183f2/images/57370bbe-8a79-4a6c-a4b4-6083ac8eae6f/BI2852%20A2.2%20core%20MCQ.jpeg.JPEG)

[© Revision Village 2025. Created in BioRender.com]Which row correctly pairs each cell with its type?Cell XCell YCell ZA.\hspace{1em}Palisade mesophyllYeastLiverB.\hspace{1em}LiverPalisade mesophyllYeastC.\hspace{1em}YeastLiverPalisade mesophyllD.\hspace{1em}Palisade mesophyllLiverYeast
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Cell Xis undergoing budding, a process characteristic of unicellular fungi like yeast. The cell also has a cell wall, a large vacuole and no chloroplasts, reinforcing that this cell is indeed a fungal cell, such as yeast.Cell Yhas no cell wall, no visible vacuoles and there are centrioles in the dividing cells, indicating that this is a dividing animal cell, such as a liver cell.Cell Zhas is dividing into daughter cells, each of which has a cell wall, vacuole, and chloroplasts. The cell is also dividing evenly by laying down a cell plate between the cells, which will develop into the cell walls of the new cells. These are all features of plant cells, such as palisade mesophyll cells.Choice Cis therefore the correct answer to this question.

list.title: Question 177
list.content:
The image shows the skulls of a gorilla, chimpanzee, and human. What conclusion can be drawn from the anatomies of the skulls?

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/dae42746-c318-47a8-bb28-40949593158e/images/1dc8d91c-26ff-4b43-954b-8b30cb9b0c03/BI1522%20fig1.png)

[Source: Adapted from Zhang, K. (2015, May 1). Wikimedia Commons. Wikimedia commons. Retrieved February 29, 2024.https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File: The_Skulls_of_the_gorilla,chimpanzee_and_humans_-_Kaiwei_Zhang.jpg. Copyright free]A.\hspace{1em}Gorillas and chimpanzees are more closely related to each other than they are to humansB.\hspace{1em}Humans are more intelligent than chimpanzees and gorillasC.\hspace{1em}Gorillas, chimpanzees and humans share a recent common ancestorD.\hspace{1em}Chimpanzees and gorillas have a diploid chromosome number of 48, whereas humans have a diploid chromosome number of 46
list.markScheme: CSample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:The similar anatomies of the gorilla, chimpanzee and human skull suggest they have a common ancestor;Choice Cis correct.Choice Ais incorrect, as similar anatomy is not enough to say that gorillas and chimpanzees are more closely related to each other than humans due to convergent evolution.Choice Bis incorrect, as skull size is not necessarily correlated to intelligence.Choice Dis incorrect as skull size and shape do not provide any information on chromosome number.

list.title: Question 178
list.content: Viruses have specific components that allow them to infect host cells and replicate. However, some components are not found in both bacteriophages and coronaviruses. Which of the following is not present in BOTH types of viruses?A.\hspace{1em}Genetic information surrounded by a capsidB.\hspace{1em}RNA genomeC.\hspace{1em}Enzymes for replicationD.\hspace{1em}Structures for attachment to a host cell
list.markScheme:
CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Cis correct because lambda bacteriophages and coronavirus do not have enzymes for replication. The lambda bacteriophage relies entirely on the host cell's machinery for replication and
coronaviruses encode their replication enzyme but do not carry it in the virion.Choice Ais incorrect because both have a capsid containing genetic information.Choice Bis incorrect because although the lambda bacteriophage has a DNA genome, not an RNA genome, coronaviruses do have an RNA genome.Choice Dis incorrect because both of these types of viruses have structures for attachment to the host cells.

list.title: Question 179
list.content:
The figure below shows the results of a study on the evolution of multicellularity. Obligate multicellularity means the organism is always multicellular, facultative multicellularity means the organism is usually unicellular but can sometimes form multicellular structures.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e940829b-1b89-44cf-8a66-34d55df8cf92/images/6b245b5b-8c5e-4ec0-ad11-47b0515ebe5a/Ed2727.png)

[Source: Adapted from Fisher, R. (2013).Group Formation, Relatedness, and the Evolution of Multicellularity. Current Biology, 23. Retrieved April 2025  from https://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0960982213005678. CC BY 3.0.]What can be deduced from this phylogenetic tree?I.All mammals are obligately multicellularII.Multicellularity evolved once in eukaryotesIII.All prokaryotes are unicellularA.\hspace{1em}I onlyB.\hspace{1em}I and IIC.\hspace{1em}I and IIID.\hspace{1em}I, II and III
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Statement Iis true because mammals are animals, and from the phylogenetic tree, the word animals is boxed(obligately multicellular).Statement IIis false because multicellularity appears on multiple separate branches that do not share a recent common ancestor, suggesting independent evolution.Statement IIIis false because cyanobacteria are prokaryotes, and the tree shows them boxed, indicating they are multicellular.Therefore,Choice Ais correct as it only contains the one trueStatement I.Choices B, C, andDare all incorrect as they include one or more of the falseStatements IIandIII.

list.title: Question 180
list.content: Which of the following is the correct pairing of a nucleotide component and its description?ComponentDescriptionA.\hspace{1em}SugarVaries between RNA and DNA to form genetic codeB.\hspace{1em}BaseProvides structure to the backboneC.\hspace{1em}PhosphateForms bonds with the base and sugarD.\hspace{1em}BaseVaries along nucleic acid to form genetic code
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Dis correct because the sequence of nitrogenous bases is what encodes genetic information in DNA and RNA. This is the only row with a fully correct and precise description.Choice Ais incorrect because, while the sugar differs between DNA (deoxyribose) and RNA (ribose), it does not form the genetic code. The code is carried in the base sequence, not the sugar.Choice Bis incorrect because Bases are not part of the backbone (which is made of sugar–phosphate units). Bases project from the backbone and form the coding region, not the structure.Choice Cis incorrect because phosphate forms bonds with sugars, not with bases. Bases attach to the sugar (at carbon 1'), not to phosphate.

list.title: Question 181
list.content: Which of the following has/have directly contributed to biodiversity loss?I.The overhunting of African elephants for their ivoryII.The expansion of cities like São Paulo, BrazilIII.The spread of the invasive zebra mussels in North America through ballast water from shipsA.\hspace{1em}I onlyB.\hspace{1em}II onlyC.\hspace{1em}I and IIID.\hspace{1em}I, II, and III
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Statement Iis true because overhunting is one cause of the biodiversity crisis.Statement IIis true because urbanisation is a cause of the biodiversity crisis.Statement IIIis true because the introduction/spread of pests, diseases and alien species due to global transport are causes of the biodiversity crisis.Therefore,Choice Dis the correct answer asStatements I, IIandIIIare true.

list.title: Question 182
list.content: What sequence of events usually occur during the process of speciation?A.\hspace{1em}Reproductive isolation → one species becomes two species → random mutationsB.\hspace{1em}Random mutations → reproductive isolation → one species becomes another speciesC.\hspace{1em}Geographic isolation → reproductive isolation → one species becomes another speciesD.\hspace{1em}Geographic isolation → reproductive isolation → one species becomes two species
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Dis correct because geographic isolation leads to a buildup of different mutations between two populations, leading to reproductive isolation and the production of two species from one.Choice Ais incorrect, as reproductive isolation cannot occur prior to a buildup of random mutations.Choices BandCare incorrect because speciation involves one species becoming two, not one.

list.content:
The diagram below shows a cell.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/09240f75-28ab-4db2-9f85-68151d24eb30/images/8076c23f-4ff1-4c9f-a945-da77994cb0a9/BI0804A.png)

[Source: Adapted from Gonzalez, R., & Kerfeld, C. (2022, June 13).Synechococcus elongatus. Wikipedia. Retrieved June 19, 2022, from https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Synechococcus_elongatus Copyright under CC BY 3.0]Deduce with a reason, what type of cell this is.[1]Calculate the magnification of the cell.[1]Outline two functions of life carried out by the cell in the diagram.[2]State the type of microscope used to produce the image.[1]Explain your choice of microscope for part (i).[1]
list.markScheme: Prokaryote(needed for mark)Then anyoneof the following:→\ce{ -> }​no nucleus[1]→\ce{ -> }​has a nucleoid[1]→\ce{ -> }​no membrane bound organellesORa named organelle such as a Golgi apparatus, rough endoplasmic reticulum or mitochondria[1]→\ce{ -> }​size is typical of prokaryote (0.1μm - 5μm)[1]→\ce{ -> }​rod shaped[1][1 mark maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:The cell is aprokaryoticcell as it containsno nucleus(✓\checkmark✓) ormembrane bound organelles(✓\checkmark✓).→\ce{ -> }​110,000 x[1][1 mark maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:magnification= image size ÷  actual sizeimage size = 11 mm = 11,000,000 nmactual size = 100 nm11,000,000nm ÷ 100 nm =110,000x (✓\checkmark✓)Anytwoof the following:→\ce{ -> }​nutrition: consuming food for energyORmetabolic processesORgrowthORreproduction[1]→\ce{ -> }​reproduction: producing offspring[1]→\ce{ -> }​metabolism: chemical reactions that occur within the cell[1]→\ce{ -> }​homeostasis: maintaining a stable internal environment[1]→\ce{ -> }​growth: a permanent  increase in numberORsize of cells[1]→\ce{ -> }​excretion: the removal of metabolic waste[1]→\ce{ -> }​response: the ability to react to changes in the environment[1]→\ce{ -> }​movement: change in position OR location in relation to the surroundings[1][2 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Two functions of life carried out by the cell areexcretion, which is theremoval of metabolic waste(✓\checkmark✓) andreproductionwhich isproducing offspring(✓\checkmark✓).Anyoneof the following:→\ce{ -> }​electron microscopeORtransmission electron microscope[1][1 mark maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Anelectron microscope(✓\checkmark✓).Anyoneof the following:→\ce{ -> }​it allows you to see the ultrastructure of the cell[1]→\ce{ -> }​it has a high resolution[1]→\ce{ -> }​it has a high magnification[1][1 mark maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:An electron microscope would be used to create the image, as it allows one to see theultrastructureof the cell (✓\checkmark✓) due to itshigh resolutionandmagnification(✓\checkmark✓).

list.title: Question 184
list.content: Which of the following isnotevidence for organisms being in the same clade?A.\hspace{1em}Chimpanzees (P. troglodytes) share 99% of their DNA with humans (H. sapiens).B.\hspace{1em}African elephants (L. africana) and manatees share a common ancestor (T. manatus).C.\hspace{1em}Bonobo  (P. paniscus) and humans (H. sapiens) both choose to play with gender specific toys.D.\hspace{1em}E. colihave a 95% similarity amino acid sequence toS. enterica.
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Two organisms having similar behaviour is not evidence that they belong in the same clade soChoice Cis correct. A clade is a group of organisms that have evolved from a common ancestor, and is usually determined by similarity in amino acid and DNA sequences, thereforeChoices A,BandDcould be used as evidence for organisms to be in the same clad and are thus incorrect for this question.

anythreeof the following:→\ce{ -> }​pentose sugarORriboseORdeoxyribose drawn in the centre and correctly  labelled[1]→\ce{ -> }​phosphate group drawn attached to C5 of pentose sugar and labelled (C5 does not need to be labelled)[1]→\ce{ -> }​nitrogenous base drawn correctly on C1 of the pentose sugar and labelled (C1 does not need to be labelled)[1][3 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/145a1f0c-e604-4287-ad0a-3d2854b8dd77/images/2464f150-4b65-41d2-848f-49cde2c8bfed/BI1849MSii.png)

[© Revision Village 2024]answer can be as annotated diagram→\ce{ -> }​deoxyriboseORDNA sugar has a hydrogen atomORH attached to C2WHEREASriboseORRNA sugar has a hydroxyl groupOROH attached to C2[1][1 mark maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:

list.title: Question 186
list.content: The table shows the number of chromosomes found in the gametes of various species.SpeciesHaploid chromosome number (n)Parascaris equorum(horse threadworm)2Vicia faba(field bean)6Oryza sativa(rice)12Homo sapiens(human)23Pan troglodytes(chimpanzee)24Canis familiaris(dog)39What can be concluded from the data in the table?I.Diploid cells usually have an even number of chromosomes.II.Species with more chromosomes have a larger genome size.III.Humans are most closely related toPan troglodytes.A.\hspace{1em}I onlyB.\hspace{1em}I and III onlyC.\hspace{1em}II and III onlyD.\hspace{1em}I, II, and III
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Ais correct because diploid cells have an even number of chromosomes (Statement I) unless affected by errors such as non-disjunction. This can be obtained by doubling the haploid number in the table and recognising that an odd number of diploid chromosomes cannot be evenly distributed to form gametes.Statement IIis false because the number of chromosomes an organism has is not an accurate reflection of its genome size.Oryza sativa, for example, has a much larger genome than any of the other species in the table despite having fewer chromosomes.Statement IIIis false because although humans are closely related to chimpanzees, this cannot be concluded from the data in the table alone.Stipa spartea(porcupine grass), for example, has the same number of chromosomes as humans but is not closely related.Choices B, C, andDare incorrect because they contain one or more false statements.

list.title: Question 187
list.content: The table below compares two specialised cells found in the human body:Cell TypePrimary FunctionProteins ExpressedSkeletal MuscleMovementActin & MyosinNeuronCommunicationNeurotransmitters & Ion Channel ProteinsWhich of the following explains the differences between the specialised cells?A.\hspace{1em}Muscle cells and neurons have different DNA, so they produce different proteinsB.\hspace{1em}Each cell type expresses only the genes needed for its functionC.\hspace{1em}Differentiation permanently deletes unused genes from a cell’s DNAD.\hspace{1em}Neurons and muscle cells switch functions over time, depending on environmental conditions
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Bis correct. Each cell type expresses only the genes needed for its function, while other genes remain inactive. This selective gene expression leads to structural and functional differences between cells.Choice Ais incorrect. All cells in an organism (except gametes and red blood cells) contain the same DNA. Differences in protein production result from differences in gene expression, not in DNA sequence.Choice Cis incorrect. Differentiation silences genes but does not remove them.Choice Dis incorrect. Once differentiated, cells do not differentiate again — a neuron will not become a muscle cell later in life.

list.title: Question 188
list.content:
The diagram below shows a water column inside a xylem vessel:

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/3f1b2aab-acf0-4771-9f33-131080adcc07/images/50f324b6-f19a-4ec4-ad52-e24066bb9bc2/BI2865%20A1.1%20core%20MCQ.jpeg.JPEG)

[Sources: Adapted from Chan, T (26 May 2025),File: Capillary Action in Plants [image]. Retrieved 5 June 2025 from https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/9/9c/Capillary_Action_in_Plants.jpg. CC BY-SA 4.0]Which of the following best explains how the property illustrated contributes to plant survival?I.Cohesion between molecules allows tension to be transmitted up the xylem.II.Cohesion enables    water to evaporate more easily.III.Adhesion prevents the water column from breaking.A.\hspace{1em}I onlyB.\hspace{1em}II and III onlyC.\hspace{1em}I and III onlyD.\hspace{1em}I, II, and III
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Statement Iis true because cohesion refers to the attraction between water molecules due to hydrogen bonding. This cohesive property allows the water column to behave as a continuous stream, enabling tension created by transpiration at the leaves to be transmitted all the way down the xylem. This is central to the cohesion-tension theory of water transport.Statement IIis false because cohesion actually resists evaporation. The hydrogen bonds between water molecules make it harder for individual molecules to escape into the air. Evaporation is more closely influenced by temperature and humidity, not directly by cohesion.Statement IIIis true because adhesion is the attraction between water molecules and the walls of the xylem vessel. This helps to counteract gravity and supports the column, reducing the chance of it breaking, especially under tension during transpiration. So this contributes to the integrity of the water column.Choice Cis therefore the correct answer because it only includes the two trueStatements IandIII.Choice Ais incorrect as it is missing the trueStatement III.Choices BandDare incorrect as they include the falseStatement II.

list.title: Question 189
list.content: Which statement(s) provide evidence for the endosymbiotic theory?I.\hspace{1.6em}Mitochondria and chloroplasts have adaptations that increase their surface areaII.\hspace{1.3em}Mitochondria and chloroplasts can make ATPIII.\hspace{1em}Mitochondria and chloroplasts have their own ribosomesA.\hspace{1em}I and II onlyB.\hspace{1em}III onlyC.\hspace{1em}II and III onlyD.\hspace{1em}I, II and III
list.markScheme: BSample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:The endosymbiotic theory explains that modern eukaryotic cells evolved from prokaryotic cells, when larger prokaryotes engulfed, but did not digest, other prokaryotes that are the precursors of modern chloroplasts and mitochondria. Evidence for this includes mitochondria and chloroplasts being the only organelles in eukaryotes that have their own ribosomes (Statement III).Choice Bis correct.Statement Iis incorrect as the adaptations that increase the surface area of mitochondria and chloroplasts are not evidence for endosymbiosis.Statement IIis incorrect as before they were engulfed, the ancient prokaryotic precursors to mitochondria and chloroplasts had the ability to generate ATP, so this ability was not acquired as a result of endosymbiosis.Choices A, CandDare incorrect as they containStatements Iand/orII.

list.title: Question 190
list.content: What is the relationship between the number of differences in DNA base sequences and time since divergence from a common ancestor?A.\hspace{1em}The lower the number of differences, the more recently organisms diverged from each other.B.\hspace{1em}The number of differences is equal to the number of years since the organisms diverged.C.\hspace{1em}The higher the number of differences, the more recently organisms diverged from each other.D.\hspace{1em}There is no relationship between the number of differences in DNA base sequences and time since divergence.
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The number of sequence differences acts as a molecular clock, so the lower the number of differences accumulated in the DNA base sequence, the more closely related and more recently the organisms diverged from each other.Choice Ais correct.Choice Bis incorrect because the number of differences is not an exact measurement of time.Choice Cis incorrect as it’s the opposite ofChoice A.Choice Dis incorrect as there is a relationship.

list.title: Question 192
list.content: Which approach, carried out by conservationists in zoos and botanical gardens, defines the transition betweenex-situconservation andin-situconservation?A.\hspace{1em}Building more capacity in zoos and botanical gardens.B.\hspace{1em}Carrying out artificial selection within zoos and botanical gardens.C.\hspace{1em}Building the population of captive-bred species across zoos and botanical gardens in many countries.D.\hspace{1em}Release of captive-bred species from zoos and botanical gardens into nature reserves.
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Dis correct because the transfer of ex-situ to in-situ means the return of species from captivity to areas that could become their natural habitats again. Nature reserves increase the chances of successful re-introduction, although many other measures would have to be taken to ensure success.Choice Ais incorrect because building more captive breeding areas will not increase the chances of being able to reintroduce species back into the wild.Choice Bis incorrect because, whilst artificial selection would allow desirable traits to be selected for in captivity, this would not necessarily guarantee that species would thrive or even survive in a wild habitat again. Artificial selection would also take a long time (measured in years and decades for some species in particular), as successive generations are bred.Choice Cis incorrect because having more animals in captivity and plants in botanical gardens would do little to increase the chances of those species being successfully reintroduced to the wild. A large captive population serves no natural purpose to conservation unless a species is released into the wild at some stage. Keeping species in captive breeding might be called ‘preservation’, but it is not ‘conservation’ in its truest sense.

Discuss the environmental and economic implications the Indonesian government must consider before volunteering the Javan Rhinoceros to the EDGE programme.[5]Explain why rapid human population growth is linked to the current biodiversity crisis.[7]
