considerations→\ce{ -> }​disruption of current food chainsORwebs[1]Environmental positive considerations→\ce{ -> }​restoration of food websORchains[1]→\ce{ -> }​habitatsORforests will have to be restored[1]→\ce{ -> }​the Javan Rhinoceros is a keystone species, so conserving this species would indirectly protect the ecosystem[1]Economic negative considerations→\ce{ -> }​can be expensive to put rhinos in breeding programmesORzoos,OREDGE program would require financial investments in researchORmonitoring,ORconservation initiatives[1]→\ce{ -> }​land that has been used for urbanisationORbusinessesORagriculture  will have to be reforested[1]→\ce{ -> }​local communities might rely on the same resources as the rhinoceros,ORlocal communities' livelihoods might be impacted by conservation measures[1]Economic positive considerations→\ce{ -> }​increase tourism in the area[1]→\ce{ -> }​may improve international cooperationORtrade agreements,ORforeign investments[1][5 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Before volunteering the Javan rhinoceros to the EDGE programme, economic considerations must be taken into account.  For example, protecting the Javan rhinoceros would likelyincrease tourismin the area (✓\checkmark✓) as people will travel to the country to see the rhinos. However, it can beexpensiveto put rhinos intobreeding programmes(✓\checkmark✓) orreforestland that has beenurbanised(✓\checkmark✓), and this may beunaffordablefor the Indonesian government. A positive environmental consideration is thatreforestation will increase biodiversity(✓\checkmark✓) in the area. However, it may also result indisruption of current, stable food chains(✓\checkmark✓)in the area.Anysevenof the following:→\ce{ -> }​more huntingORpoachingORfor foodORresources, which endangers animals[1]→\ce{ -> }​loss of habitats due to urbanisationORagriculture[1]→\ce{ -> }​increased agriculture can lead to a monocultureORa loss in diversity[1]→\ce{ -> }​deforestation for building infrastructureORresources such as paperORagriculture[1]→\ce{ -> }​increased pollution due to increased vehiclesORglobal transportORindustryORfactories can cause damage to organismsORcontribute to global warming[1]→\ce{ -> }​increased use of fertilisers leading to eutrophication[1]→\ce{ -> }​increased spread of diseases to plantsORanimals due to increased global transport[1]→\ce{ -> }​increased risk of spread of invasive species due to increased global transport[1]→\ce{ -> }​increased spread of pests due to increased air travel damaging agricultureORforest ecosystems[1][7 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Rapid human population growth is linked to the current biodiversity crisis because as the global population grows, there is an increased need for resources which can result inloss of habitatdue toincreased agriculture(✓\checkmark✓), an increase in the use offertiliserswhich can result ineutrophication(✓\checkmark✓) and morehuntingof animals (✓\checkmark✓) which lowers animal populations.  An increase in agriculture which utilisesmonocultureslowers species diversity in the area (✓\checkmark✓).  An increase in the human population is also correlated withincreased global transport, which can result in increasedpollution, which contributes toglobal warming(✓\checkmark✓), which can have a detrimental effect on ecosystems and also can result in an increasedspread of invasive species(✓\checkmark✓) andpests(✓\checkmark✓), which lowers biodiversity within ecosystems.A quality mark is awarded if each part of the question (a, b, c) is answered to earn at least half of the points available, answers do not require re-reading to be understood, and there are almost no errors and little irrelevant information.[1]

list.title: Question 194
list.content:
Based on the structure of each forelimb shown below, which one is likely to be analogous?A.B.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9a97e321-e9ca-4e8f-8b33-9b3cb18ee915/images/39606d35-df65-410c-9d8b-ed6f9af2b422/BI0230_A.png)



![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9a97e321-e9ca-4e8f-8b33-9b3cb18ee915/images/52471306-733f-4dfc-bcae-3f4e8ce6d7de/BI0230_B.png)

C.D.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9a97e321-e9ca-4e8f-8b33-9b3cb18ee915/images/d8fd25b2-43d4-49b1-9f06-91470c27995e/BI0230_C.png)



![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9a97e321-e9ca-4e8f-8b33-9b3cb18ee915/images/91947f34-f7c5-454c-b802-9fe1906e95f9/BI0230_D.png)

[Adapted from: Source Владислав Петрович , В. (2011).Filevertebrates-en.svg. Wikimedia Commons. Retrieved June 8, 2022, from https ://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File.svg copyright freeGraham, V. B. (2016, May 31).File& homologous structures.svg.Wikimedia Commons. Retrieved June 8, 2022, from https ://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Analogous_%26_Homologous_Structures.svg CC-BY-SA-4.0]
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:An analogous structure is one that has a similar function to other structures but does not come from a common ancestor.Choice Bis a forelimb, but does not have a structure similar to the other three limbs, which indicates that it does not come from a common ancestor, so is likely to be analogous.Choices A,CandDare incorrect as they are all homologous to each other i.e. they share a common ancestor, evidenced by the similarities in their structures.

list.title: Question 195
list.content: How did radioisotopes help make the investigations by Hershey and Chase possible?A.\hspace{1em}They identified the helical shape of DNA.B.\hspace{1em}They tracked elements that are incorporated into cells.C.\hspace{1em}They separated mixtures according to size and charge.D.\hspace{1em}They stopped DNA replication for base sequencing.
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Bis correct because radioisotopes are used to track elements. Hershey and Chase used radioactive35S and32P to provide evidence that DNA is the genetic material.Choice Ais incorrect because X-ray diffractions were used to identify the helical shape of DNA and not radioisotopes. Although Hershey ad Chase did use centrifugation to separate the bacteria from the viral particles,Choice Cis incorrect because centrifugation does not require radioisotopes and it does not separate mixtures according to charge.  Gel electrophoresis is the process that tends to be used to separate mixtures according to size and charge.Choice Dis incorrect because dideoxyribonucleotides are used to stop DNA replication and not radioisotopes.

list.title: Question 196
list.content: The table shows the number of differences in amino acid sequences for the Insulin-A protein, between pigs and other organisms.\hspace{3em}Organism\hspace{3em}Number of differences in amino acid sequence for Insulin-AHuman2Cow5Giraffe50Goat4Warthog1Chimpanzee10Flamingo25Which organism would be furthest from pigs in a cladogram?A.\hspace{1em}Warthogs because they have the least number of differencesB.\hspace{1em}Giraffes because they have the largest number of differencesC.\hspace{1em}Humans because they are most different physicallyD.\hspace{1em}Flamingoes because they have a different number of limbs
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Organisms with the largest differences in the amino acid sequence are the most evolutionarily diverged, so would be the furthest apart.Choice Bis correct.Choice Ais incorrect as warthogs and pigs have the least number of differences so would be the closest organisms on a cladogram.Choices CandDare incorrect because cladograms are not based on physical appearance.

list.title: Question 197
list.content:
The diagram below shows transcription.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b52a0f7e-44bc-41fb-b520-68f9f818e40a/images/7788d2fb-8bfa-4572-9a23-2786736e9a6e/BI0039.png)

[© Revision Village 2022. Created with BioRender.com]What do structures X and Y have in common?A.\hspace{1em}Both are made up of phosphate groups, ribose sugar and nitrogenous bases.B.\hspace{1em}Both contain hydrogen bonds between adenine and thymine.C.\hspace{1em}Both contain sugar-phosphate bonds between phosphate groups and monosaccharides.D.\hspace{1em}Both have six-carbon monosaccharides in their structure.
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Structure X is DNA, and structure Y is RNA. Both structures are made up of phosphate groups, sugars and nitrogenous bases. Both structures contain sugar-phosphate bonds, a type of covalent bond, between phosphate groups and sugars.The sugar in DNA is deoxyribose and the sugar in RNA is ribose (Choice A). The sugar molecule in both DNA and RNA is a pentose sugar which means it has five carbon atoms, not six (Choice D).RNA does not contain thymine (Choice B) and it is single-stranded.

list.title: Question 198
list.content:
Refer to the diagram showing a section of a DNA strand.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/cda96db5-d1f8-4821-bfb9-ddd33e4caa82/images/af63cd61-e4b6-436d-853c-27b1cbae8bda/Picture1.png)

[© Revision Village 2025. Created in BioRender.com]Which carbon on the deoxyribose sugar is bonded to the phosphate group in the phosphodiester bond?A.\hspace{1em}Carbon 1'B.\hspace{1em}Carbon 2'C.\hspace{1em}Carbon 3'D.\hspace{1em}Carbon 4'
list.markScheme:
CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/cda96db5-d1f8-4821-bfb9-ddd33e4caa82/images/a1f3dc2e-b1f0-4602-a55b-087562538587/ANS.png)

The phosphodiester bond forms between the 3' carbon of the sugar in one nucleotide (which has an –OH group), and the 5' phosphate group of the next nucleotide. So, the 3' carbon is directly involved in forming the bond that links nucleotides within a single strand of DNA or RNA, makingChoice Ccorrect.The 1' carbon of the sugar is the attachment point for the nitrogenous base, not for the phosphate group;Choice Ais incorrect.In deoxyribose, the 2' carbon lacks an –OH group (it has just –H), distinguishing DNA from RNA.  It is not involved in bonding to phosphate, soChoice Bis incorrect.The 4' carbon connects to the 3' carbon and the 5' carbon within the sugar ring, but does not form bonds with the phosphate group;Choice Dis incorrect.

list.title: Question 199
list.content: The plasma membrane, a structure common to all cells, is primarily composed of a phospholipid bilayer. What is the fundamental reason for this specific lipid arrangement?A.\hspace{1em}To provide a flexible boundary for the cell and a source of stored energy.B.\hspace{1em}To create a rigid barrier impermeable to most substances for protection.C.\hspace{1em}To form a selectively permeable barrier due to the hydrophobic nature of the lipids.D.\hspace{1em}To actively transport molecules using energy from the lipids.
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Cis correct because it accurately describes the plasma membrane as selectively permeable, allowing some things to pass and some not, and this is because the tails of the phospholipids comprising the membrane are hydrophobic.Choice Ais incorrect. While it’s true that the membrane provides a flexible boundary for the cell, it is not a source of energy. If the membrane is broken down to release energy, the boundary of the cell will be destroyed, and the cell will cease to exist.Choice Bis incorrect because the membrane is not rigid or impermeable. It is flexible and partially permeable.Choice Dis incorrect because the energy used to transport molecules across the membrane is typically provided by the hydrolysis of ATP.

list.title: Question 200
list.content:
The diagram shows two kinds of specialised cells found in the same individual.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/df8e8502-1eca-482c-9133-b157a8e47ce1/images/6ad214c5-d6f9-4452-93c7-7dc8ad775d97/BI1556.png)

[© Revision Village 2024. Created with BioRender.com]Which of the following statements would be true for both cell types?I.They share the same genome.II.They develop based on the expression of some genes and not others.III.They develop from the same stem cell populations.A.\hspace{1em}I and II onlyB.\hspace{1em}II and III onlyC.\hspace{1em}I and III onlyD.\hspace{1em}I, II and III
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Ais correct because both cells contain the same genes/genome in their diploid nucleus (Statement I). They differentiate or become specialised during their development due to the expression of some genes but not others (Statement II).Statement IIIis not true because although both types of cells originate from stem cells, they come from different lineages and therefore develop from different stem cell populations or niches.Choices B, C, andDare incorrect because they containStatement III.

list.title: Question 201
list.content: The cyanobacteriaLeptolyngbya nigrescenshas recently been reclassified asPhormidesmis nigrescens. What is a  possible reason for this?A.\hspace{1em}Observation of similar sensitivities to light between bacteria in thePhormidesmisgenus and the newly classifiedPhormidesmis nigrescensB.\hspace{1em}Discovery of structural similarities of cyanobacteria to other bacteria in theLeptolyngbyagenusC.\hspace{1em}Discovery of similarities in ribosomal RNA sequences betweenPhormidesmis nigrescensand other bacteria in thePhormidesmisgenusD.\hspace{1em}New evidence thatPhormidesmis nigrescensshare a common ancestor with other cyanobacteria in theLeptolyngbyagenus
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Similarities between ribosomal RNA sequences betweenPhormidesmis nigrescensand other bacteria in thePhormidesmisgenus indicates that they are likely to share a common ancestor, belong in the same genus and therefore should be reclassified.Choice Cis correct.Similarities in behaviour do not indicate thatPhormidesmis nigrescensshare a common ancestor with other bacteria in thePhormidesmisgenus;Choice Ais incorrect. To be reclassified, thePhormidesmis nigrescensshould be more similar to bacteria in the Phormidesmis genus than theLeptolyngbyagenus, also structural similarities are not grounds for reclassification;Choice Bis incorrect. To be reclassified, thePhormidesmis nigrescensshould share a common ancestor with cyanobacteria in thePhormidesmisgenus rather than theLeptolyngbyagenus;Choice Dis incorrect.

list.title: Question 202
list.content:
What bases are P, Q, and R if S is a pyrimidine?

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/f497fb1a-2df4-4043-a760-f2d78e9bc76a/images/3b6c2a4e-8c5c-4c00-a882-93d69b4c4568/BI0897A.png)

[© Revision Village 2023]PQRA.\hspace{1em}\hspace{1em}Guanine\hspace{1em}\hspace{1em}Cytosine\hspace{1em}\hspace{1em}Thymine\hspace{1em}B.\hspace{1em}GuanineAdenineCytosineC.\hspace{1em}CytosineGuanineAdenineD.\hspace{1em}AdenineThymineCytosine
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Adenine and guanine are purines. Cytosine and thymine are pyrimidines.If S is a pyrimidine (~20%), it is either cytosine or thymine. Purines pair with pyrimidines, so Q, which also makes up about 20% of the molecule, must be guanine or adenine. This meansChoices AandDcan be eliminated as correct answers.P and R must pair up as they make up approximately the same proportion of the DNA. So P and R must either be adenine and thymine or guanine and cytosine. This meansChoice Cis incorrect.This leaves us with the correct answer ofChoice B.  P is guanine, which pairs with R, cytosine, and Q is adenine, which pairs with S, which must be thymine.

list.title: Question 203
list.content: Outline the different uses of karyograms.[3]Distinguish between cells with haploid and diploid nuclei.[4]Compare and contrast different types of chromosomes.[8]
list.markScheme:
Anythreeof the following:→\ce{ -> }​karyograms are images of the chromosomes in an organism[1]→\ce{ -> }​homologous chromosomes are arranged in pairs of decreasing length OR Sex chromosomes are the 23rd pair in human karyograms[1]→\ce{ -> }​karyograms can be used to identify the sex of an individual[1]→\ce{ -> }​karyograms can be used to identify conditions caused by trisomy, e.g. Down syndromeORPatau syndromeORKlinefelter syndrome[1]→\ce{ -> }​karyograms can be used to determine if a chromosome is missingORif part of a chromosome is missing[1][3 mark maximum]Sample Answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample Answer}}Sample Answer​:Karyograms(✓\checkmark✓) are images of the chromosomes in an organism. In a karyogram, the pairs of homologous chromosomes are arranged in pairs ofdecreasing length(✓\checkmark✓). The sex chromosomes are shown as the 23rd pair in human karyograms.
Karyograms can be used to determine if an individual is a biologicalmale or female(✓\checkmark✓). Two X chromosomes are present in a human female cell, and one X chromosome and one Y chromosome are present in a human male cell.
Karyograms can be used to identify conditions caused by trisomy (three copies of a chromosome) e.g.Down syndrome, Patau syndrome, Edward’s syndrome and Klinefelter syndrome).Anyfourof the following:→\ce{ -> }​haploid nuclei have one set of chromosomes,ORone chromosome per typeWHEREASdiploid nuclei have two setsORtwo chromosomes of each type[1]→\ce{ -> }​haploid nuclei have one allele for each geneWHEREASdiploid nuclei have two alleles for each gene[1]→\ce{ -> }​haploid nuclei in humans have 23 chromosomes, and diploid nuclei in humans have 46 chromosomesORany other valid species example[1]→\ce{ -> }​haploid cells are usually gametesWHEREASdiploid cells are usually somatic cells[1]→\ce{ -> }​haploid cells are usually the result of meiosis,WHILEdiploid cells are usually the result of mitosis.[1][4 mark maximum]Sample Answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample Answer}}Sample Answer​:Haploid nuclei haveone set of chromosomes(✓\checkmark✓), whereas diploid nuclei have two sets of chromosomes.  For example, inhumans(✓\checkmark✓), gametes have 23 chromosomes, while somatic cells have 46 chromosomes. Haploid nuclei haveone allele for each gene, (✓\checkmark✓)  whereas diploid nuclei have two alleles for each gene. In humans, onlygametes(✓\checkmark✓)  have haploid nuclei, whereas the rest of the somatic cells have diploid nuclei.Anyeightof the following:→\ce{ -> }​(within one species) different chromosomes are composed of DNA molecules with different lengths[1]→\ce{ -> }​(within one species) different chromosomes have different numbers of genes[1]→\ce{ -> }​(within one species) different chromosomes have different typesORdifferent numbers of genes[1]→\ce{ -> }​both prokaryoticANDeukaryotic chromosomes contain DNA[1]→\ce{ -> }​bacterial chromosomes are not associated with proteins,WHILEeukaryotic and archaeal chromosomes are associated with proteins[1]→\ce{ -> }​prokaryotic chromosomes are looped molecules of DNA,WHILEeukaryotic chromosomes are linear molecules of DNA[1]→\ce{ -> }​BOTHautosomes and sex chromosomes contain genes[1]→\ce{ -> }​the human Y chromosome carries information mainly coding for male sex determination and development,WHILEthe X chromosome carries information for other body characteristics[1]→\ce{ -> }​there is only one pair of sex chromosomes,WHILEthere can be more than one pair of autosomes (in different species)[1]→\ce{ -> }​autosomes are pairs of homologous chromosomes of equal length,WHILEtwo sex chromosomes can be different lengths[1]→\ce{ -> }​chromosomes can be homologous and non-homologous[1]→\ce{ -> }​homologous chromosomes are pairs of chromosomes of equal length carrying the same genes, but different alleles,WHILEnon-homologous chromosomes, carry different genes[1][8 mark maximum]Sample Answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample Answer}}Sample Answer​:All chromosomes are made of DNA and contain genes, but theydiffer in length(✓\checkmark✓) and in thenumber of genes(✓\checkmark✓) andtype of genes(✓\checkmark✓). Similarities and differences between prokaryotic and eukaryotic chromosomes: Both prokaryotic and eukaryotic chromosomescontain DNA(✓\checkmark✓). Bacterial chromosomes are not associated with proteins, but eukaryotic chromosomes areassociated with proteins(✓\checkmark✓). Prokaryotic chromosomes are looped, while eukaryotic chromosomes arelinear(✓\checkmark✓).Similarities and differences between autosomes and sex chromosomes:Both autosomes and sex chromosomes are made of DNA and contain genes. Autosomes are chromosomes that do not determine sex and do not have genes for sex-linked characteristics; sex chromosomes determine sex and have genes for sex-linked traits. There is one pair of sex chromosomes in a somatic nucleus, but there can bemore than one pair of autosomes(✓\checkmark✓) in a somatic nucleus. X and Y chromosomes are of different lengths, while autosomal homologous chromosome pairs areequal in length(✓\checkmark✓)Comparing non-homologous chromosomes and homologous chromosomes:Homologous chromosomes are pairs of chromosomes that have genes for the same characteristics and can have the same or different alleles. Non-homologous chromosomes have genes fordifferent characteristics(✓\checkmark✓).A quality mark is awarded if each part of the question (a, b, c) is answered to earn at least half of the points available, answers do not require re-reading to be understood, and there are almost no errors and little irrelevant information.[1]

list.title: Question 204
list.content: Compare and contrast the biological species concept and the morphological concept.[3]Explain the difficulties with applying the biological species and morphological concept to all organisms.[5]Describe the similarities and differences within and between species.[7]
list.markScheme: Anythreeof the following (students must give at least one similarity and one difference to achieve full marks):Similarities→\ce{ -> }​BOTHconcepts seek to define a species[1]→\ce{ -> }​BOTHconcepts acknowledge that there can be variation within species[1]→\ce{ -> }​BOTHconcepts are connected to the broader concept of evolution[1]Differences→\ce{ -> }​the biological species concept defines a species as a group of organisms which can interbreed to produce fertile offspring,WHEREASthe morphological concept defines a species as a group of organisms with shared traits[1]→\ce{ -> }​Mayr proposed the biological species conceptWHEREASthe morphological concept was proposed by Linnaeus[1]→\ce{ -> }​the morphological species concept was proposed before the biological species concept[1]→\ce{ -> }​the morphological species concept is applicable to sexual and asexual organisms,WHEREASthe biological species concept is applicable only to sexually reproducing organisms[1]→\ce{ -> }​the biological species concept reflects the evolutionary relationship OR speciation OR gene flow,WHEREASthe morphological species concept may not represent genetic relatedness or evolutionary relationships[1][3 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Both concepts are used todefine species(✓\checkmark✓), but Mayr proposed the biological species concept, whereas the morphological concept was proposed byLinnaeus(✓\checkmark✓). The morphological concept also camefirst(✓\checkmark✓). The biological species concept defines a species as a group of organisms that can interbreed to producefertile offspring; however, the morphological concept defines a species as a group of organisms withshared traits(✓\checkmark✓).Anyfiveof the following:→\ce{ -> }​the morphological species concept cannot be applied to species that show variation due to reproductive isolationORthe morphological concept cannot be applied to species with different formsORpolymorphismORnamed example of a species with different forms[1]→\ce{ -> }​the morphological species concept does not take into account DNAORgenetic information[1]→\ce{ -> }​the biological species concept is defined in terms of sexual reproductionHOWEVER, not all organisms reproduce sexually[1]→\ce{ -> }​example of species that reproduce asexually, e.g. budding in yeastORhorizontal gene transfer in bacteria[1]→\ce{ -> }​the biological species concept relies on the ability to observe and study interbreeding in real-time, which is not possible with extinct speciesORfossilised organisms[1]→\ce{ -> }​some different species can interbreed and produce viable offspring, but these hybrids might have reduced fitness or be sterile, which challenges the clear-cut boundaries proposed by the biological species concept[1]→\ce{ -> }​convergent evolution can make it difficult to accurately group organisms based solely on morphological characteristics[1]→\ce{ -> }​rapid evolution and morphological changes in response to the environment might make individuals appear distinct, even if they share a recent common ancestor, which challenges the reliability of morphological traits as indicators of species relationships[1][5 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:The biological species concept defines a species as a group of organisms that can interbreed to produce fertile offspring, however, not all species reproducesexually(✓\checkmark✓), for example, yeast reproduce asexually bybudding(✓\checkmark✓). It also relies on the ability to see species interbreeding, which cannot be done withextinctspecies orfossils(✓\checkmark✓). The morphological concept defines a species as a group of organisms with shared traits, however, due to variation caused byreproductive isolationand mutation, not all members of a specieslook the same(✓\checkmark✓). In addition,rapid evolutionmight make individuals appear distinctly related when in fact, they shared a recent common ancestor. This could make the morphological species conceptless reliable(✓\checkmark✓).Anysevenof the following:→\ce{ -> }​species can be defined as a group of organisms that are capable of interbreeding to produce fertile offspring[1]→\ce{ -> }​species usually share the same number of chromosomes[1]→\ce{ -> }​species usually share identical karyotypes[1]→\ce{ -> }​example of chromosome complement of a species, e.g. humans have 46 chromosomes[1]→\ce{ -> }​the chromosome complement of a species can vary due to genetic conditions such as Down syndrome[1]→\ce{ -> }​the size genome of a species can vary within a species[1]→\ce{ -> }​the base sequence of the genome can vary within a species[1]→\ce{ -> }​due to mutations or single-nucleotide polymorphisms[1]→\ce{ -> }​homologous genesORsimilarities in gene pathwaysORsimilarities in the functions of genes can be found between species that share evolutionary origins[1]→\ce{ -> }​species-specific genes are not found in other closely related species[1]→\ce{ -> }​horizontal gene transfer between different species, often through mechanisms like viral infections or symbiotic relationships, leads to the acquisition of genes in the recipient that may not be shared by other members of the species[1][7 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:According to the biological species concept, a species can be defined as a group of organisms that are capable of interbreeding to producefertile offspring(✓\checkmark✓). They can produce fertile offspring as a species usually have thesame chromosome number(✓\checkmark✓), for example, in humans, this is46(✓\checkmark✓) unless genetic conditions such asDown syndromeaffect their karyotype (✓\checkmark✓). Thesizeof a species' genome can vary slightly within a species (✓\checkmark✓), as can thebase sequenceof the genome (✓\checkmark✓) and these are both due tomutations(✓\checkmark✓).A quality mark is awarded if each part of the question (a, b, c) is answered to earn at least half of the points available, answers do not require re-reading to be understood, and there are almost no errors and little irrelevant information.[1]

list.title: Question 205
list.content:
The image on the left shows a cross-section of a symmetrical flower. The image on the right shows the same flower but looking upwards from below.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/09109e4f-739a-4be6-9f76-8c9ae9a8da25/images/4efabe18-9f85-4bba-878c-f0ed970e5145/BI2660.png)

[© Revision Village 2025. Created with BioRender.com]Use the following key to identify the plant which this flower is from:1.Animal pollinated ….Go to 2Wind pollinated ….Plant P2.Flower with 10 stamens ….Plant QFlower with more than 10 stamens ….Go to 33.Ovary as tall as wide….Plant ROvary taller than wide….Go to 44.Flower has more sepals than petals ….Plant SFlower has fewer sepals than petals….Plant TWhich plant does the flower belong to?A.\hspace{1em}Plant PB.\hspace{1em}Plant QC.\hspace{1em}Plant TD.\hspace{1em}Plant R
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Cis correct. The plant is animal-pollinated (the flower has large petals and internal reproductive structures (stigma and anthers), indicating animal pollination). It also has more than 10 stamens and an ovary that is taller than it is wide. This takes us to step 4. From the diagram on the right, we can see that the flower has fewer sepals than petals which means it must be plant T.Choice Ais incorrect because the flower in the diagram is animal-pollinated as it has anthers and a stigma held inside the large, colourful petals.Step 2: The image only shows half the flower, which has 11 stamens visible. This means the full flower has more than eleven stamens;Choice Bis, therefore, incorrect.Choice Dis incorrect because, in step 3, the ovary is taller than it is wide, so it can't be flowerR.

list.title: Question 206
list.content: Which of the following statements explain why classifying diverging populations as species can be arbitrary?I.Traits may diverge at different rates in different populationsII.Some populations may remain reproductively compatible despite divergenceIII.Morphological changes always occur before genetic differences appearA.\hspace{1em}I and II onlyB.\hspace{1em}I and III onlyC.\hspace{1em}II and III onlyD.\hspace{1em}I, II, and III
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Statement Iis true because, during speciation, some traits (e.g., behaviour, physiology, morphology) can evolve faster than others. This means two populations might look different but still interbreed, or might appear similar but already be reproductively isolated. Because divergence doesn’t follow a fixed pattern, deciding when to define them as separate species becomes subjective.Statement IIis true because Populations might develop noticeable differences in traits (such as colouration or mating calls), but still produce fertile offspring when they interbreed. According to the biological species concept, they’re technically the same species, but these differences can confuse classification.Statement IIIis false because often, the opposite is true. Genetic differences (mutations, allele frequency changes) may accumulate before any visible morphological change occurs. For example, two populations may look identical but carry distinct genetic markers and be reproductively isolated.Saying morphological change “always” comes first is incorrect and overly simplistic.Choice Ais correct because it includes only the two trueStatements IandII.Choices B, CandDare incorrect as they include the falseStatement III.

list.title: Question 207
list.content: When a horse, which has 64 chromosomes, and a donkey, which has 62 chromosomes reproduce, a mule offspring is produced.  Which are correct descriptions of mules?I.Mules frequently produce offspring with other mules.II.Cells in mules cannot undergo meiosis but can undergo mitosis.III.Mule gametes have 63 chromosomes.A.\hspace{1em}I onlyB.\hspace{1em}II and III onlyC.\hspace{1em}II onlyD.\hspace{1em}I and II only
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Cis correct because onlystatement IIis correct.  Mules have 63 chromosomes, so gametes cannot be produced, as 63 chromosomes cannot be equally divided into daughter cells.Statement Iis incorrect, as mules cannot reproduce with other mules.Statement IIIis incorrect because the somatic cells, not the gametes of mules, have 63 chromosomes.

list.title: Question 208
list.content:
The images below represent haploid or diploid cells from different individuals. Based on their cells, which pairs could produce fertile offspring if they interbreed?I.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/0e07ee1d-2174-4c9f-b030-faa106d5f85b/images/9a2f92c1-ef3b-4ebf-ae97-0592003e8699/BI1029A.png)

A.\hspace{1em}I onlyB.\hspace{1em}I and II onlyC.\hspace{1em}II and III onlyD.\hspace{1em}I, II and III
