list.title: Question 251
list.content: All organisms evolve through natural selection. Which of the following is a direct effect of natural selection on living organisms?A.\hspace{1em}It promotes the accumulation of beneficial traits in organismsB.\hspace{1em}It allowed the last universal common ancestor to outcompete other organisms within one generationC.\hspace{1em}It allows organisms that are best adapted to their environment to surviveD.\hspace{1em}It explains how life began on Earth
list.markScheme: CSample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Natural selection allows organisms that are best adapted to their environment to survive and pass on their genes;Choice Cis correct.Promoting the accumulation of beneficial traits in organisms is a consequence of natural selection, not the direct effect. As organisms with beneficial traits survive and reproduce more, those traits become more common in the population over time. Natural selection is driven by random mutations that may or may not benefit an organism;Choice Ais incorrect. Although natural selection via evolution did allow the last universal common ancestor to outcompete other organisms, it is likely to have been a gradual process that did not occur within one generation;Choice Bis incorrect. Natural selection does not address the origin of life itself; it explains how life changes and evolves after it has already begun. ;Choice Dis incorrect.

list.title: Question 252
list.content: Outline how water is formed at the end of aerobic respiration.[3]Explain how the properties of water allow it to be transported around a plant.[5]Describe how plants transport carbohydrates from source to sink.[7]
list.markScheme: anythreeof the following:→\ce{ -> }​electrons donated by reduced NAD and FADORNADH and FADH at the beginning of the electron transport chain[1]→\ce{ -> }​electrons are passed along electron carriers[1]→\ce{ -> }​final electron acceptor is oxygenOR1/2O2[1]→\ce{ -> }​excess hydrogen ionsORprotons, from intermembrane spaceORcoenzymesORreduced NADORreduced FAD found in matrixORaccumulate in the matrix[1]→\ce{ -> }​hydrogen ionsORprotons react with oxygen to form water[1]→\ce{ -> }​4e-+ 4H++ O2→ 2H2OOR4 electrons + 4 protons + 1 molecule of oxygen →  2 molecules of water[1][3 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Electronsdonated byreduced NADandFADat the beginning of the electron transport chain (✓\checkmark✓) are passed alongelectron carriers(✓\checkmark✓), with thefinalelectron acceptor beingoxygen(✓\checkmark✓).Hydrogen ionsin thematrixreact withoxygento form water (✓\checkmark✓).anyfiveof the following:→\ce{ -> }​polar so can form hydrogen bonds[1]→\ce{ -> }​strong cohesive forces between water molecules help pull other water molecules up the xylem[1]→\ce{ -> }​strong adhesive properties mean water can stick to ligninORcelluloseORinside of the xylem[1]→\ce{ -> }​cohesion and adhesion work together to enable capillary actionORallow water to move against gravity in xylem vessels[1]→\ce{ -> }​evaporation from leaves creates a negative pressureORtension in the xylem vessels, which helps to “pull” more water up the plant[1]→\ce{ -> }​cohesion-tension theoryORcohesive forces between water molecules and the tension created in the xylem vessels create a continuous column of water[1]→\ce{ -> }​high latent heat of vaporisation so water can evaporate from the stomata and stimulate the transpiration stream[1]→\ce{ -> }​low viscosity, so can flow easily through small pores in the plant[1]→\ce{ -> }​root pressure results from the active pumping of ions into the root cells, creating an osmotic gradient that causes water to enter the roots[1][5 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Water is able to move around a plant because it ispolar, sohydrogen bondscan form (✓\checkmark✓) between different water molecules, which allow them to becohesiveso they canstick togetherto be pulled up thexylem(✓\checkmark✓) at low pressure. Water molecules areadhesivewhich allows them to stick tocellulosein the plant (✓\checkmark✓). Thecohesionandadhesionwork together to enablecapillary actionup the xylem vessels (✓\checkmark✓).  Water has ahigh latent heat of vaporisation, so water canevaporatefrom thestomataand maintain the transpiration stream (✓\checkmark✓).anysevenof the following:→\ce{ -> }​sources are where carbohydrates are synthesised[1]→\ce{ -> }​sinks are where carbohydrates are utilised[1]→\ce{ -> }​sucrose and H+are co-transported into the companion cells (in apoplastic route) near the source[1]→\ce{ -> }​sucrose concentration increases in the companion cells[1]→\ce{ -> }​sucrose diffuses into sieve tube via plasmodesmata[1]→\ce{ -> }​sucrose diffuses through cytoplasm of neighbouring cells, via plasmodesmata into phloem (in symplastic route)[1]→\ce{ -> }​the increase in concentration of carbohydratesORsucroseORdecrease in solute potential results in water flowing into the phloem via osmosis[1]→\ce{ -> }​raises the hydrostatic pressure in the sieve tube elements near the source cell[1]→\ce{ -> }​organic compounds,ORcarbohydratesORnamed example, are unloaded from phloem,ORsieve tubes near the sink[1]→\ce{ -> }​decreases the solute concentration (in sieve tubes at sinks)[1]→\ce{ -> }​water moves out of the sieve tubes reducing hydrostatic pressure[1]→\ce{ -> }​waterORsap containing the sucroseORcarbohydrates moves down the hydrostatic pressure gradient towards the sink[1][7 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Sourcesare where carbohydrates aresynthesisedin plants, such as photosynthesising leaves (✓\checkmark✓) andsinksare where carbohydrates areused, such as growing shoots (✓\checkmark✓). In plants,sucrose and H+areco-transportedinto companion cells near the source (✓\checkmark✓), this causes thesucrose concentrationtoincreasein companion cells (✓\checkmark✓). Sucrose thendiffusesintosieve tubesviaplasmodesmata(✓\checkmark✓) and thendiffusesthrough thecytoplasm of neighbouring cells, into the phloem (✓\checkmark✓). This causes water to move into the phloem viaosmosisfrom thexylem(✓\checkmark✓),raisingthehydrostatic pressure(✓\checkmark✓). At thesink, thecarbohydratesareunloadedfrom the phloem (✓\checkmark✓),decreasingthesolute concentration(✓\checkmark✓),water follows, therebyreducing hydrostatic pressure(✓\checkmark✓). The sap containing the carbohydratesmove downthehydrostatic pressure gradienttowards the sink (✓\checkmark✓).A quality mark is awarded if each part of the question (a, b, c) is answered to earn at least half of the points available, answers do not require re-reading to be understood, and there are almost no errors and little irrelevant information.[1]

list.title: Question 253
list.content: The table shows factors that can result in speciation. Which word is matched to the correct definition?WordDefinitionA.\hspace{1em}PolyploidyHaving two complete sets of chromosomesB.\hspace{1em}Sexual reproductionThe combining of genetic information from two individualsC.\hspace{1em}Reproductive isolationSpecies breeding to produce infertile offspringD.\hspace{1em}MutationsRandom changes to the amino acid sequence
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Sexual reproduction involves the fusion of gametes from two individuals, resulting in offspring with a combination of genetic material. This process increases genetic variation, which is essential for evolution and natural selection.Choice Bis the correct answer.Polyploidy occurs when an organism has more than two complete sets of chromosomes (e.g., triploid 3n, tetraploid 4n). The definition given in the table describes diploidy (2n), which is the standard chromosome number in most sexually reproducing organisms;Choice Aincorrect.Interbreeding between different species can sometimes produce infertile offspring, such as a horse × donkey = mule. This is an example of reproductive isolation because the hybrid offspring is sterile, preventing gene flow between the two species. However, because horses and donkeys are already separate species, this does not result in speciation—it simply reinforces their reproductive barrier. For reproductive isolation to lead to speciation, it must occur within a single species, preventing interbreeding between different populations.Choice Cis incorrect.Mutations are random changes in DNA sequences, not in the amino acid sequence;Choice Dis incorrect.

list.title: Question 254
list.content: Why is the cytochrome oxidase I gene the region most commonly used for DNA barcoding in animal species?A.\hspace{1em}Because this gene is highly conserved, resulting in nearly identical sequences across all animal species.B.\hspace{1em}Because this gene is sufficiently different between species while remaining relatively constant within a species.C.\hspace{1em}Because this gene is found exclusively in animals and not in any other organisms.D.\hspace{1em}Because this gene is part of the nuclear DNA and evolves rapidly, ensuring distinct differences even among closely related species.
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Bis correct.  The cytochrome oxidase I gene has the ideal balance of variability. Its sequence differs enough between species to allow clear differentiation, yet it remains consistent within individuals of the same species. This makes it highly effective for DNA barcoding.Choice Ais incorrect: If the cytochrome oxidase I gene were too highly conserved (i.e., nearly identical across species), it wouldn’t provide enough variation to distinguish one species from another.Choice Cis incorrect. The cytochrome oxidase I gene is not exclusive to animals; it is found in the mitochondria of many eukaryotes. Its utility for animal barcoding comes from its pattern of variability, not its exclusivity.Choice Dis incorrect. The cytochrome oxidase I gene is mitochondrial, not nuclear, and its evolutionary rate is moderate rather than extremely rapid. A gene that evolves too quickly might accumulate too many mutations, complicating species-level identification.

list.title: Question 255
list.content: Outline the role of the active site in an enzyme.[3]Outline how members of the same species can become separate populations via speciation.[4]Describe the regulation and use of hormones during in vitro fertilisation (IVF).[8]
list.markScheme: anythreeof the following:→\ce{ -> }​it is the binding site for a substrateORspecific region where the substrate binds[1]→\ce{ -> }​it allows for induced fit binding of the substrate[1]→\ce{ -> }​it facilitates enzyme-substrate specificityORhas a specific shape that allows the substrate to bind effectively[1]→\ce{ -> }​it causes a conformational change in the enzyme-substrate complex, which leads to the formation of products[1]→\ce{ -> }​it is the site where a substrate is converted into a productORwhere a substrate is held while a chemical reaction takes place[1]→\ce{ -> }​it lowers the energy of the transition stateORactivation energy so that a chemical reaction can take place more efficiently[1][3 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:The active site of an enzyme is a specific region where asubstrate binds(✓\checkmark✓). Within the active site, the enzymelowerstheenergy of the transition state(✓\checkmark✓), facilitating the chemical reaction so that the substrate can be successfullyconverted into a product(✓\checkmark✓).anyfourof the following:→\ce{ -> }​a population consists of all organisms of one species living in the same place at the same time, capable of breeding together[1]→\ce{ -> }​members of the species can become geographically isolatedORseparated by a physical barrier such as a riverORmountain[1]→\ce{ -> }​members of the species can become temporally isolatedORbecome separated by producing gametes at different timesORseasons[1]→\ce{ -> }​members of the species can become behaviourally isolatedORbecome separated by displaying distinctive courtship behaviours[1]→\ce{ -> }​when populations of the same species become separated, genetic drift will cause the allele frequencies to change[1]→\ce{ -> }​reproductive isolation mechanisms, such as incompatibility of reproductive organs, can prevent interbreeding between separated populations[1]→\ce{ -> }​mutations can introduce new genetic variations in each isolated population, contributing to genetic divergence over time[1]→\ce{ -> }​selective pressures will act on the separated species, leading to an accumulation of genetic differences in each populationORnatural selection will act on each population so that traits that are beneficial to each group will accumulate[1]→\ce{ -> }​over many generations, speciation will occurORthe separate populations will not be able to breed to produce fertile offspring[1][4 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Members of the same species can become separate populations if they becomegeographically isolated(✓\checkmark✓) orbehaviourally isolated(✓\checkmark✓). Once populations of the same species are separated,genetic driftwill cause theallele frequencies to change(✓\checkmark✓).Selective pressureswill act on the separated populations, leading to anaccumulation of genetic differences(✓\checkmark✓). Eventually,speciation(✓\checkmark✓) will occur, resulting in populations that can no longer interbreed to produce fertile offspring.anyeightof the following:→\ce{ -> }​drugs are used to downregulate several hormonesORFSHORfollicle stimulating hormone AND LHORluteinising hormone, to better control the releaseORmaturation of follicles later on[1]→\ce{ -> }​the function of FSHORfollicle-stimulating hormone is to promote follicle growthORmature eggs[1]→\ce{ -> }​the function of LHORluteinising hormone is to trigger ovulationORtrigger the release of mature eggs from the ovaries[1]→\ce{ -> }​the downregulation of LH and FSH also results in the downregulation of oestrogen and progesterone[1]→\ce{ -> }​oestrogen normally stimulates the uterineORendometrial lining to build up[1]→\ce{ -> }​progesterone normally stimulates the maintenance of the uterineORendometrial lining for implantation[1]→\ce{ -> }​high doses of FSH are injected to stimulate superovulationORthe development of many follicles[1]→\ce{ -> }​the development of many follicles increases the chances of successful fertilisation during the IVF process[1]→\ce{ -> }​gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) agonists are injected to prevent premature ovulationORcontrol the timing of ovulation[1]→\ce{ -> }​human chorionic gonadotropinORhCG is injected to stimulate the follicles to mature[1]→\ce{ -> }​progesterone is injected before the fertilised egg is implanted to improve the chances of successful implantation[1][8 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:In vitro fertilisation (IVF) is a process used by couples with fertility issues, where mature eggs are fertilised outside the body. To start the process,drugsare used todownregulate several reproductive hormonesto better control therelease and maturation of follicleslater on (✓\checkmark✓). The downregulation ofFSH stops follicles from growing(✓\checkmark✓). Drugs are also used todownregulate LH, which results in theprevention of ovulation(✓\checkmark✓). The downregulation of LH and FSH also results in thedownregulationofoestrogen and progesterone(✓\checkmark✓), which normally function to stimulate thebuild-up of the uterine lining(✓\checkmark✓) andmaintain the uterine lining(✓\checkmark✓), respectively. Once these hormones are successfully downregulated,high doses of FSHare injected to trigger thedevelopment of multiple folliclesin the ovary(✓\checkmark✓). The development of many folliclesincreases the chance of successful fertilisationduring the IVF process (✓\checkmark✓).GnRH agonistsare injected toprevent premature ovulation(✓\checkmark✓), andhCGis injected to stimulate thefollicles to mature(✓\checkmark✓).A quality mark is awarded if each part of the question (a, b, c) is answered to earn at least half of the points available, answers do not require re-reading to be understood, and there are almost no errors and little irrelevant information.

list.title: Question 256
list.content: Outline how mitochondrial DNA can be used to construct a cladogram.[4]Explain why organisms classified in the past may be reclassified.[4]Compare and contrast cladograms made using molecular evidence and structural evidence.[7]
list.markScheme: Anyfourof the following:→\ce{ -> }​mitochondrial DNA from different organisms can be sequenced[1]→\ce{ -> }​mutations occur at a roughly constant rateORcan act as a molecular clock[1]→\ce{ -> }​the lower the number of differences in the base sequence between organisms, the more closely related the organisms are[1]→\ce{ -> }​the number of differences in the base sequence can be used to determine how long ago species diverged from a common ancestor[1]→\ce{ -> }​which can be used to deduce where the nodes are on cladograms[1][4 marks maximum]Sample Answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample Answer}}Sample Answer​:Sections of mitochondrial DNA fromdifferent organisms can be sequenced(✓\checkmark✓), which allows scientists to observe differences in the base sequence. Thelower the number of differencesin the base sequence between organisms, themore closely relatedthe organisms are (✓\checkmark✓). Thenumber of differencesin the sequence of mitochondrial DNA can also be used to determinehow long ago species divergedfrom a common ancestor (✓\checkmark✓), which can be used to deduceposition of nodeson cladograms (✓\checkmark✓).Anyfourof the following:→\ce{ -> }​organisms (used to be) classified based on shared anatomical characteristicsORstructuresORphysical features[1]→\ce{ -> }​shared anatomical characteristicsORstructuresORphysical features may be analogousORnot due to common ancestry[1]→\ce{ -> }​analogous structures as a result of convergent evolution[1]→\ce{ -> }​organisms (are now) classified using amino acidORDNA sequences[1]→\ce{ -> }​increased accuracyORreliability of cladograms made using DNAORamino acid sequences[1][4 marks maximum]Sample Answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample Answer}}Sample Answer​:In the past, organisms were classified based on sharedphysical features(✓\checkmark✓), howeverphysical features could be analogousand therefore not the result of common ancestry (✓\checkmark✓). Cladograms which are constructed usingDNA or amino acid sequences(✓\checkmark✓) are morereliable(✓\checkmark✓) and can highlight new evolutionary relationships which would lead to organisms potentially being reclassified.Anysevenof the following:→\ce{ -> }​BOTHseek to demonstrateORdeduce evolutionary relationships[1]→\ce{ -> }​BOTHcontain a rootORancestor common to all organisms within the cladogram[1]→\ce{ -> }​BOTHcontain nodesORpoints at which species diverged from one another[1]→\ce{ -> }​BOTHcontain cladesORan ancestor and all of its evolutionary descendants[1]→\ce{ -> }​BOTHcan contain outgroupsORthe most distantly related species[1]→\ce{ -> }​species inBOTHmay be reclassified (in response to new evidence)[1]→\ce{ -> }​species organised based on anatomical structuresORphysical characteristicsWHEREASspecies are organised based on amino acidORDNA sequence[1]→\ce{ -> }​in the past cladograms were constructed using similarities in physical featuresWHEREASnow DNAORamino acid sequences are used[1]→\ce{ -> }​molecular evidenceORDNA sequencesORamino sequences more reliableORaccurate than structural evidenceORphysical characteristics[1]→\ce{ -> }​analogous structures can be an issue in cladograms made using structural similaritiesBUTnot in cladograms using molecular evidenceORDNAORamino acid sequences[1]→\ce{ -> }​cladograms made using structural evidence require less technologyCOMPAREDto cladograms using molecular evidenceORDNA or amino acid sequences[1][7 marks maximum]Sample Answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample Answer}}Sample Answer​:Cladograms which are made using structural evidence and those made using molecular evidence have several things in common, for example,both havefeatures such as aroot(✓\checkmark✓),nodes(✓\checkmark✓) andclades(✓\checkmark✓), theybothalso attempt to showevolutionary relationshipsbetween species (✓\checkmark✓). However there are some differences in these cladograms. In cladograms made using structural evidence, thephysical characteristicsof species are used to organise them into groups, but in cladograms using molecular evidence, scientists use the number of differences in the DNA oramino acid sequence(✓\checkmark✓), which is known to be the morereliable(✓\checkmark✓) method and is more commonly used now, compared to structural features being used more in thepast(✓\checkmark✓).A quality mark is awarded if each part of the question (a, b, c) is answered to earn at least half of the points available, answers do not require re-reading to be understood, and there are almost no errors and little irrelevant information.[1]

list.markScheme:

Moreover, zoos are instrumental inreintroducing programsthat releaseanimalsback into thewild, directly contributing to restoringnatural populations(✓\checkmark✓) and ecosystems.Anytwoof the following→\ce{ -> }​research to make sure control organism specifically targets invasive speciesORdoes not affect native speciesORdoes not damage ecosystemORhabitatsORfood chains[1]→\ce{ -> }​conditions in the target environment should support the survival of the control species[1]→\ce{ -> }​control species should have a natural controlORpredator[1]→\ce{ -> }​control species should not spread outside the targeted areaORshould not become an invasive species themselves[1]→\ce{ -> }​long-term monitoring plans to observe the effects of the biocontrol species[1]→\ce{ -> }​possible socio-economic impactsORconsider ethicalORculturalORsocial implications of control species should be assessed[1]→\ce{ -> }​plan should be developed in case species need to be controlledOReradicated[1][2 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Before using biological control, it is crucial to conductthorough researchto ensure that the control organismspecifically targetstheinvasivespecieswithout impacting nativespecies or theecosystem(✓\checkmark✓). Additionally, theconditionsin the target environment mustsupportthesurvivalof thecontrolspecies (✓\checkmark✓)

list.title: Question 258
list.content: Which statement(s) provide evidence for the common ancestry of all existing forms of cellular life?I.The universality of the genetic codeII.The machinery for protein synthesisIII.Use of ATP as a common energy currencyA.\hspace{1em}I and II onlyB.\hspace{1em}I and III onlyC.\hspace{1em}II and III onlyD.\hspace{1em}I, II and III
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Statements I, IIandIIIare true, makingChoice Dthe correct answer to the question.The universality of the genetic code(Statement I)suggests that all modern organisms inherited this code from a single common ancestor. The nearly identical genetic code across all known forms of life. implies that the code was established very early in the history of life and has been conserved through billions of years of evolution. If different forms of life had arisen independently, it is highly unlikely that they would all use the same genetic code.The machinery for protein synthesis,(Statement II)which includes ribosomes, transfer RNA (tRNA), and messenger RNA (mRNA), is remarkably conserved across all forms of cellular life. This high degree of similarity suggests that these complex molecular mechanisms were inherited from a common ancestor, known as the Last Universal Common Ancestor (LUCA).ATP as a common energy currency(Statement III)used by organisms as diverse as bacteria, archaea, and eukaryotes suggests that this energy system was established early in the evolutionary history of life and inherited from a single ancestral organism. If different forms of life had evolved independently, it is unlikely that they would all rely on the same molecule for energy, reinforcing the idea of a shared origin.

This allows the virus toenter the host cell(✓\checkmark✓).→\ce{ -> }​capsid[1][1 mark maximum]→\ce{ -> }​RNAORsingle stranded RNA[1][1 mark maximum]\hspace{1em}→\ce{ -> }​humansORHomo sapiens[1][1 mark maximum]Anythreeof the following:→\ce{ -> }​reverse transcriptase is an enzyme used in HIV replication[1]→\ce{ -> }​uses viral RNA as template[1]→\ce{ -> }​synthesises viral DNA from RNAORreverses transcription to make viral DNA from RNA[1]→\ce{ -> }​viral DNA is integrated into host chromosome with the help of reverse transcriptase[1]→\ce{ -> }​integrated viral DNA is transcribed by host cell to synthesise viral proteins[1][3 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:HIV is categorised as a retrovirus. list.title: Question 260
list.content: Outline the role of auxin in positive phototropism.[3]Explain the evidence that supports the theory that eukaryotic cells evolved from prokaryotic cells.[5]Explain how the products of the light-dependent stage of photosynthesis are used in the light-independent stage to convert carbon dioxide into organic substances.[7]
list.markScheme:
Anythreeof the following:→\ce{ -> }​light is detected by group of proteinsORphototropins which trigger the movement of auxins by active transport[1]→\ce{ -> }​auxin efflux pumps move auxin so the concentration of auxins is more on the shadier side
and lesser on the side with more light[1]→\ce{ -> }​plant cells have auxin receptors[1]→\ce{ -> }​when auxin binds to these receptors ,transcription of genes for enzymeORexpansin[1]→\ce{ -> }​auxin causes movement of  hydrogen ions from cytoplasm into the cell walls[1]→\ce{ -> }​hydrogen ions and expansionORenzyme loosens cellulose fibresORfibres of cell wall[1]→\ce{ -> }​causes cells on the shaded side of shoot tip to elongate[1][3 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Light is detectedbyphototropinsand this triggers the movement of auxins byactive transport(✓\checkmark✓). Auxinefflux pumpsmove auxins fromcytoplasmintocell walls, so that theconcentrationof auxin ismoreon theshadier side(✓\checkmark✓) and less on the side with more light. When auxin binds toreceptorson the cells,genesfor the enzymeexpansinareexpressed(✓\checkmark✓).Expansin, and thepumping of protonsfrom the cytoplasm into the cell wall cause thelooseningofcellulose fibres(✓\checkmark✓) in the cell walls, leading toelongationof thecells(✓\checkmark✓).Anyfiveof the following:→\ce{ -> }​theory of endosymbiosis proposes that mitochondriaORchloroplasts have evolved from free-living prokaryotes that were engulfedORtaken in by endocytosis, by larger cells[1]→\ce{ -> }​mitochondriaORchloroplasts have naked DNA[1]→\ce{ -> }​mitochondriaORchloroplasts divide by binary fission[1]→\ce{ -> }​mitochondriaORchloroplasts divide independently of cell cycleORcell[1]→\ce{ -> }​mitochondriaORchloroplasts about same size as prokaryotes[1]→\ce{ -> }​mitochondriaORchloroplasts have 70S ribosomes[1]→\ce{ -> }​mitochondriaORchloroplasts can synthesise their own proteins[1]→\ce{ -> }​mitochondriaORchloroplasts have double membranes[1]→\ce{ -> }​mitochondriaORchloroplasts have inner membrane likeORsimilar in structure to prokaryotesANDouter membrane likeORsimilar in structure to eukaryotes[1]→\ce{ -> }​DNA of mitochondriaORchloroplasts is more closely relatedORmore similar to prokaryotic DNA than to nuclear DNA of eukaryotic cells,ORrRNAORribosomal RNA more closely relatedORmore similar to prokaryotes than eukaryotes[1]→\ce{ -> }​observations of modern examples of endosymbiosis OR given examples of present day endosymbiosis, provide support for the theory[1][5 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:The endosymbiotictheorysupports the evidence thatmitochondriaandchloroplastsin eukaryotic cellsevolved from prokaryoticcells, which were taken in by larger cells throughendocytosis(✓\checkmark✓). The evidence supporting this theory includes the fact that these organelles havenaked DNA(✓\checkmark✓), divide bybinary fission(✓\checkmark✓), cansynthesisetheirown proteins(✓\checkmark✓) and havedouble membranesaround the outside (✓\checkmark✓).Anysevenof the following: (drawing showing the Calvin cycle with the steps described below):→\ce{ -> }​products of the light-dependent reaction are essential for the light-independent reactions[1]→\ce{ -> }​light-dependent reactions produce ATP, NADPH and oxygen[1]→\ce{ -> }​ATP and NADPH are used in the light-independent reactionsORCalvin cycle[1]→\ce{ -> }​light-independent reactions convert carbon dioxide into glucose and other organic molecules[1]→\ce{ -> }​enzyme RuBisCO fixes carbon dioxide[1]→\ce{ -> }​causes 1 x RuBP to bind to 1 x carbon dioxide[1]→\ce{ -> }​6 C compound is unstable and forms two 3C compounds of glycerate-3-phosphateORGP[1]→\ce{ -> }​ATP and NADPH are used to convert glycerate-3-phosphateORGP to triose phosphateORTP[1]→\ce{ -> }​some of the triose phosphateORTP leaves the cycle to form carbohydrates, most is used to reform RuBP[1]→\ce{ -> }​regeneration of RuBP requires energy in the form of ATP[1][7 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Light-dependentreactions of photosynthesis produceATP, NADPH(✓\checkmark✓) and oxygen. Oxygen is a by-product, ATP and NADPH are used in the light-independent reactions. In the stroma of the chloroplast,carbon dioxidecombines withRuBP(✓\checkmark✓), a 5C compound catalysed by the enzymeRubisco(✓\checkmark✓). The6C compoundformed isunstableand splits intotwo molecules of glycerate-3-phosphate(✓\checkmark✓).ATP and NADPH(✓\checkmark✓) are used to convertglycerate-3-phosphate into triose phosphate(✓\checkmark✓). Some of themoleculesoftriose phosphate leavethecycleto formglucose(✓\checkmark✓) or other carbohydrates,mostof it isusedtoregeneratethe5C RuBP(✓\checkmark✓).RegenerationofRuBPagain requiresATP(✓\checkmark✓) obtained from the light-dependent reactions.For additional detail‾\underline{\textrm{For additional detail}}For additional detail​:  see 5:26 in Photosynthesis Key Concept Video:https://www.revisionvillage.com/ib-biology/hl/key-concepts/?keyConceptId=cd710a11-a37d-4f93-aed3-30e4e1d75e55A quality mark is awarded if each part of the question (a, b, c) is answered to earn at least half of the points available, answers do not require re-reading to be understood, and there are almost no errors and little irrelevant information.[1]

list.title: Question 261
list.content: Which of the following statements best describes how horizontal gene transfer (HGT) challenges the biological species concept in bacteria?A.\hspace{1em}HGT occurs only between closely related bacteria, reinforcing species boundaries.B.\hspace{1em}HGT is a mechanism of vertical inheritance, where genetic material is passed directly from parent to offspring.C.\hspace{1em}HGT enables bacteria to acquire genes from distantly related organisms, blurring the boundaries defined by reproductive isolation.D.\hspace{1em}HGT increases the mutation rate within a bacterial population, leading to rapid speciation.
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Cis correct because horizontal gene transfer allows bacteria to incorporate genetic material from unrelated species. This confounds the biological species concept, which relies on reproductive isolation to define species boundaries.Choice Ais incorrect because HGT is not limited to closely related bacteria; it can occur between very different bacterial species.Choice Bis incorrect as HGT is a form of lateral (non-vertical) gene transfer, not the typical parent-to-offspring inheritance.Choice Dis incorrect because while HGT can introduce new genes, it does not inherently increase the mutation rate or directly lead to rapid speciation.

However, at thehighest concentration of oestrogen(29.6 ngL-1),X.laevishad a muchlowermean mating callduration, 4 seconds less than the control (✓\checkmark✓).Anyoneof the following:→\ce{ -> }​to
