list.title: Question 263
list.content:
The graph shows the results of an experiment by Hershey and Chase. Bacteria (E. coli) were infected with virus particles labelled with either (radioactive phosphorus)X32X2232P\ce{^{32}P}X32​X2232​Por (radioactive sulfur)X35X2235S\ce{^{35}S}X35​X2235​S. A blender was used to remove attached viruses from the bacterial cells and samples collected from the suspension were centrifuged to record the percentage of isotope remaining in the cells.“\text{\textquotedblleft}“infected bacteria” refers to the percentage of live bacteria that survived the blending process.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/8ed5cb9a-b4cc-48f2-9a43-a583465327c3/images/6586b9a3-accb-446e-a5a0-30c7e2670160/Edit.png)

[© Revision Village 2024. Created with BioRender.com]Which of the following statements explain(s) why the extracellularX32X2232P\ce{^{32}P}X32​X2232​Pincreased as the running time in the blender increased?I.When bacteriophages infect bacteria, not all viral particles successfully inject their DNA into the host cells. Some phages remain attached to the cell surface or fail to transfer their DNA.II.During blending, the infected bacteria take up moreX32X2232P\ce{^{32}P}X32​X2232​P.III.During blending, some of the infected bacterial cells are lysed (the reason the“\text{\textquotedblleft}“infected bacteria” percentage decreases). The lysed cells release theirX32X2232P\ce{^{32}P}X32​X2232​P.A.\hspace{1em}I and IIIB.\hspace{1em}I and II onlyC.\hspace{1em}III onlyD.\hspace{1em}I, II and III
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Statement Iis true because not all bacteriophages successfully inject their DNA into the bacterial host cells during infection. Some phages may remain attached to the bacterial surface or fail to inject their DNA. During blending, these surface-bound phages are detached, and theirX32X2232P\ce{^{32}P}X32​X2232​P-labelled DNA is released into the extracellular medium, contributing to the increase in extracellularX32X2232P\ce{^{32}P}X32​X2232​Pin the graph.Statement IIis false. Bacteria do not "take up more”X32X2232P\ce{^{32}P}X32​X2232​Pduring blending. The blending process is designed to remove surface-bound phages and shear unattached components, not to facilitate further DNA uptake by bacterial cells.Statement IIIis true. Some of the infected bacterial cells can be lysed during the blending process. When this happens, theX32X2232P\ce{^{32}P}X32​X2232​P-labelled viral DNA inside these lysed cells is released into the extracellular environment, further increasing extracellularX32X2232P\ce{^{32}P}X32​X2232​P.Choice Ais correct because it is the only choice that includes both the trueStatements IandIII.Choice Cis incorrect because it only includes one true statement.Choice BandDare incorrect because they include the falseStatement II.

list.title: Question 264
list.content: Which of the following statements accurately describes characteristics of homologous structures?I.Homologous structures are defined as functionally similar anatomical features that arise through divergent evolution.II.Although bats and dolphins exhibit distinct external morphology, their forelimbs evolved from a common ancestor.III.Bird wings and insect wings originate from the same embryonic tissues and are therefore homologous.A.\hspace{1em}I onlyB.\hspace{1em}II onlyC.\hspace{1em}II and III onlyD.\hspace{1em}I, II and III
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:While homologous structures do arise via divergent evolution, they are not defined by functional similarity. In fact, their function may differ considerably, for example, the forelimbs of bats for flight versus the flippers of dolphins for swimming. Homology is established based on shared structural origin, not shared function;Statement Iis false.Homologous structures are anatomical features found in different species that share a common evolutionary origin, even if they have diverged in form or function. Both bats and dolphins have a pentadactyl limb structure in their forelimbs, despite a differing external appearance and function. This reflects divergent evolution from a shared ancestor;Statement IIis true.Bat wings and insect wings are analogous structures. Although they perform a similar function (flight), they evolved independently in different evolutionary lineages and do not share embryological origin. Bat wings derive from the vertebrate limb, while insect wings arise from outgrowths of the arthropod exoskeleton.Statement IIIis false.Choice Bis the correct answer because it only includes the one trueStatement II.Choices A, CandDare incorrect as they include one or more of the falseStatements IandIII.

list.title: Question 265
list.content:
The image shows a cross-section of the vascular tissue of a woody dicot stem, showing the annual rings of phloem and xylem.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/a0648fba-391a-4ca2-952b-fa672ea03b0c/images/8191483b-15e2-4be1-b746-75ba3038686a/BI0834.jpg)

[Source: Adapted from: Berkshire Community College Bioscience Image Library. (2014, February 10). FileDicot stem primary xylem in late one year  - wikimedia. Wikimedia commons. Retrieved July 07, 2023, from https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Woody_Dicot_Stem_Ray_System_in_Two_Year_Tilia_%2834997659262%29.jpg. Copyright free]Explain how the properties of water allow it to be transported in the xylem.[3]Describe a physical property of water, other than those that are important for the movement of water through the plant, that makes water essential for the survival of plants.[1]Outline why plants cannot use water to transport lipids.[1]If the temperature drops to -1oC for a few hours suggest a reason why the water in xylem may not freeze.[1]
list.markScheme: Anythreeof the following:→\ce{ -> }​water is cohesiveORhydrogen bonding between water moleculesORstrong intermolecular forces so can form a continuous column of waterORcounteract gravity[1]→\ce{ -> }​water is adhesiveORwater molecules can adhere to other polar surfacesORwater adheres to walls of xylem vesselsORto lignin and cellulose of xylem vessels, so prevent collapse of water columnORseparation from xylem vessel walls[1]→\ce{ -> }​capillary action occurs as water moves upwards against gravity in the narrow xylem vessels[1]→\ce{ -> }​the hydrogen bonds between water molecules mean that as water evaporates  from the leaf  negative pressureORtension occurs, so water moves upwards against gravity[1]→\ce{ -> }​low viscosity reduces resistance to flow within the xylem[1][3 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Water can be transported efficiently through the xylem as the water molecules adhere to the inside of the xylem vessels (✓\checkmark✓) and cohere to each other, therefore forming a continual column of water (✓\checkmark✓). As the water evaporates from the leaves, the hydrogen bonds between the molecules mean that a negative pressure occurs at the top of this column of water, enabling the water to move upwards, against gravity (✓\checkmark✓).  This is the cohesion-tension theory.Anyoneof the following:→\ce{ -> }​water is a solvent so can dissolve nutrients which can be used by the plantORprovides a medium for various biochemical reactions[1]→\ce{ -> }​high specific heat capacity prevents extreme temperature fluctuations that could damage plant tissuesORmaintain optimal enzyme activity and metabolic processes in plants[1]→\ce{ -> }​transparency allows light to penetrate and reach submerged plants for photosynthesis[1][1 mark maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Water is known as a universal solvent, so nutrients can be dissolved in it and be transported to where they are needed (✓\checkmark✓).Anyoneof the following:→\ce{ -> }​lipids are hydrophobicORnon-polar, so cannot dissolve in water[1][1 mark maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Water cannot be used to transport lipids in plants as they are hydrophobic  (✓\checkmark✓).Anyoneof the following:→\ce{ -> }​water has a high specific heat capacity,ORit has to lose a lot of energy to freeze[1]→\ce{ -> }​due to the high solute concentration of the contents of the xylem[1]→\ce{ -> }​increase in pressure in the xylem raises the freezing point of water[1]→\ce{ -> }​high specific heat capacity means water can release stored heat slowly, maintaining a stable temperature above freezing point[1][1 mark maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Water in the xylem may not freeze when the temperature drops below -1oC, as it has a high specific heat capacity  (✓\checkmark✓).

list.title: Question 266
list.content:
The graph below shows Biodiversity Intactness, a long-term indicator that measures how much original biodiversity remains within terrestrial communities on the continents, based on levels from around 1500 A.D., when records began.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/af00fec2-0075-40c9-8a41-072c06650376/images/1ad75b4e-1e66-416a-87f8-4d878e1c4179/BI2808%20-%20Bi2813%20A4.2%20PQ%20MCQ%20and%20SAQ%20PhilCh.jpeg.JPEG)

[Source: adapted from WWF (2024)Living Planet Report 2024 – A System in
Peril. WWF, Gland, Switzerland http://bit.ly/4jzPxrE. Retrieved 30 April 2025, Public Domain]Using data from the graph, compare and contrast biodiversity in Asia and Europe.[2]Suggest reasons for the difference(s) you highlighted in part (a) (i)[3]Outlinetworeasons why the graph might give an inexact picture of global biodiversity loss.[2]Certain Asian species, including the Chinese Crocodile Lizard (Shinisaurus crocodilurus), have been selected for the EDGE of Existence programme in Asia, whereas another endangered species, the Asian elephant (Elephas maximus), is not on the EDGE of Existence list. Suggest why.[3]
list.markScheme: anytwoof the following (must includeonesimilarity andonedifference to gain full marks)Similarity:→\ce{ -> }​BOTHshowed a high level (close to 1.0) in 1800[1]→\ce{ -> }​BOTHdeclined from 1800 to 1950[1]→\ce{ -> }​BOTHshowed an overall decline 1800 - 2024ORin the period of study[1]Difference:→\ce{ -> }​Asia fell steeply from 1950-2000WHEREASEurope recovered in that period[1]→\ce{ -> }​Asia continues to decline (in 2024)WHEREASEurope is stableORincreasing[1][2 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:A similarity is thatbothcontinents’ biodiversityfell from 1800 to 1950(✓\checkmark✓). By contrast, Europe’s biodiversityincreasedfrom 1950 onwards, whereas Asia’scontinues to declinein the present day ‘any two of the following (must include one similarity and one difference to gain full marks) (✓\checkmark✓).anythreeof the following:→\ce{ -> }​better awarenessOReducation in Europe[1]→\ce{ -> }​weaker environmental protection law in Asia[1]→\ce{ -> }​less povertyORmore access to money to fund biodiversity work in Europe[1]→\ce{ -> }​more reliance on subsistence farming in Asia[1]→\ce{ -> }​less human population growth in Europe since 1950ORhigh population density in Asia[1]→\ce{ -> }​more deforestationORurbanisation in Asia since 1950[1]→\ce{ -> }​EuropeanORAmerican companies operating in Asia; accept palm oil plantation[1]→\ce{ -> }​theftORtraffickingORpoachingORillegal wildlife tradingORof Asian native species[1]→\ce{ -> }​conflictORpolitical instability in some Asian regions limits long-term biodiversity policy implementation[1]→\ce{ -> }​higher rate of industrialisationORinfrastructure development in Asia since 1950[1]accept converse arguments[3 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Asia’s rapideconomic growthandpopulation growthhave put pressure on natural resources (✓\checkmark✓). An example could be the draining of wetlands and deforestation to create city space for housing (✓\checkmark✓).Weaker laws and law enforcementin Asia (✓\checkmark✓) have led to a rise inpoaching and traffickingof endangered species, and this can lead to eventual extinction. Non-Asian companies have madelarge agricultural investmentsin Asia such as large-scale palm oil plantations, which damage the ecosystem in native tropical forest areas (✓\checkmark✓).anytwoof the following:→\ce{ -> }​only terrestrial ecosystemsORland are covered in the dataORthere is no information on aquaticORseasORocean ecosystems[1]→\ce{ -> }​there is no distinction between subcontinents such as North and South America[1]→\ce{ -> }​there is no distinction between kingdomsORbetween plants and animalsORmicroorganisms[1]→\ce{ -> }​data collection in 1800 will have been less sophisticatedORaccurate than 2024[1]→\ce{ -> }​biodiversity in 1500ORbaseline data was already influenced by human activity[1]→\ce{ -> }​indicator may rely on modelledORestimated data rather than direct field measurements[1][2 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:The dataonlycoversterrestrial ecosystems, so takes no account of aquatic organisms (✓\checkmark✓). Also,methodsof measuring biodiversity in 2024 will be a lotmore accuratethan those used in previous centuries (✓\checkmark✓).anythreeof the following:→\ce{ -> }​the elephant has close genetic relativesORmore close relatives (than the crocodile)[1]→\ce{ -> }​the lizard is more evolutionarily unique (than the elephant)[1]→\ce{ -> }​conservation data on the elephant is insufficientORnot up-to-date (to qualify for EDGE)[1]→\ce{ -> }​the elephant may not be globally endangeredORit may be endangered in one country onlyORhave a healthy population in other countries[1]→\ce{ -> }​there is better ex-situ conservationORbetter global zooORcaptive populations of the elephant than the  lizard[1]→\ce{ -> }​lizard may occupy a more restrictedORfragmented habitat, increasing extinction risk[1][3 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:The Chinese crocodile lizard may bevery distinct genetically from its nearest relative, which gives it priority for selection into the EDGE programme, whereas the elephant has more close relatives (✓\checkmark✓). The elephant is a popular species for zoos and conservation projects, so there will behigher populations in captivity(✓\checkmark✓), making its extinction risk lower. Also, the elephant may be endangered in one country but mayexist in large populations elsewhere, lowering its risk of global extinction danger (✓\checkmark✓).

list.title: Question 267
list.content:
Marbled crayfish,Procambarus virginalis(shown below) only reproduce through parthenogenesis, a type of asexual reproduction.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/ba0e6004-4d7f-48a7-bf9e-a8069777b737/images/c8f8303c-ea98-4db3-beb6-4205e32b355a/BI2655.png)

[Adapted from Lyko, F. (2017).The marbled crayfish (Decapoda: Cambaridae) represents an independent new species. Zootaxa 4363(4): 544–552. Retrieved 10/03/2025, DOI: 10.11646/zootaxa.4363.4.6. CC PY]Which of the following statements about classifying these crayfish is/are correct?I.They produce genetically identical offspring, making species classification impossibleII.They cannot be classified using the biological species conceptIII.They can produce many offspring so cannot be classified using the biological species conceptA.\hspace{1em}II onlyB.\hspace{1em}II and IIIC.\hspace{1em}I and IID.\hspace{1em}I, II, and III
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Statement Iis false. Although marbled crayfish produce genetically identical offspring, this does not make classification impossible; it just means the biological species concept (which relies on interbreeding) isn’t applicable. Other species concepts can be used.Statement IIis true. The biological species concept defines species based on their ability to interbreed and produce fertile offspring, with reproductive isolation preventing gene flow between different species. However, it does not apply to organisms that reproduce exclusively asexually.Statement IIIis false. The number of offspring does not affect the applicability of the biological species concept. The issue is the absence of sexual reproduction, not the offspring count.Choice Ais correct because it contains only the true statement and none of the false ones.Choice Bis incorrect because it contains the falseStatement III.Choice Cis incorrect because it contains the falseStatement I.Choice Dis incorrect because it contains the falseStatements IandIII.

list.title: Question 268
list.content:
Below is a diagram ofEuglenaa photosynthetic protist. It is a living cell which can carry out all the functions of life.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/baae8d3c-4677-4caa-8ce1-9fda48741d8b/images/0e7cb70d-2847-4e53-88b4-d3e0f7ba6098/BI1068.png)

[© Revision Village 2023]State which function of life the flagellum is adapted for.[1]State which function of life is enabled by the contractile vacuole.[1]Outline why viruses are not regarded as living organisms.[2]State two main principles of the cell theory[2]Explain how the properties of phospholipids mean they naturally form vesicles when in aqueous solution.[2]Explain how the formation of vesicles was important in the evolution of cells.[3]
list.markScheme: Anyoneof the following:→\ce{ -> }​movement[1][1 mark maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:The flagellum allows theEuglenatomove(✓\checkmark✓).Anyoneof the following:→\ce{ -> }​homeostasisORcontrol of a constant internal environment[1][1 mark maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:The contractile vacuole allows the Euglena to carry out thehomeostatic process(✓\checkmark✓) of osmoregulation.Anytwoof the following:→\ce{ -> }​consist of genetic material enclosed in a protein coatORcapsidORlack cellular structuresORorganellesORexamples of organelles[1]→\ce{ -> }​cannot carry out metabolic processes on their ownORcannot carry out homeostasis[1]→\ce{ -> }​depend on host cells to replicateORto produce new viral particlesORcannot reproduce independently[1]→\ce{ -> }​lack the ability to respond to stimuliORadapt to changes in their environment on their own[1][2 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Viruses are regarded as non-living as theylack cellular structures(✓\checkmark✓), such as organelles and cell membranes. They areunableto carry outmetabolic reactions(✓\checkmark✓), such as respiration. They alsocannot reproduce independently(✓\checkmark✓), they have to enter a cell and use the host’s cell machinery to form new viral particles.Anytwoof the following:→\ce{ -> }​cells are the smallest units of lifeORthe cell is the basic unit of structure and function in living organisms[1]→\ce{ -> }​all living organisms are composed of one or more cells[1]→\ce{ -> }​all cells arise from pre-existing cellsORthrough cell division[1][2 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Two principles of the cell theory are thatall organisms are composed of one or more cells(✓\checkmark✓), andall cells arise from pre-existing cells(✓\checkmark✓)  through cell division.Anytwoof the following:→\ce{ -> }​phospholipids have a hydrophilic OR polar head OR polar phosphate group which is attracted to water[1]→\ce{ -> }​phospholipids have a hydrophobicORnon-polar tail that is repelled by water[1]→\ce{ -> }​phospholipids are amphipathic[1]→\ce{ -> }​form double layer in aqueous solutionORwater,  with hydrophobic tails in centre and hydrophilic heads facing outwards into aqueous environment[1]→\ce{ -> }​spontaneous process driven by the tendency to minimise interactions between hydrophobic regions and water[1]→\ce{ -> }​as lipid bilayer forms it curves creating a closed spherical structureORvesicle[1][2 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Theamphipathic(✓\checkmark✓) nature of phospholipids, withhydrophilic phosphate headsandhydrophobic fatty acid tails, causes them to self-organise intobilayers in aqueous solutions(✓\checkmark✓). Thephosphate headsstick outwardsintotheaqueous environmentas they are attracted to water (✓\checkmark✓), and thehydrophobic tailsarrange themselves in thecentre of the bilayeras they are repelled by water (✓\checkmark✓). As thebilayerforms itcurves(✓\checkmark✓)  to formclosed vesicles.Anythreeof the following:→\ce{ -> }​probably led to formation of protocellsORformation of early vesicles may have led to protocells[1]→\ce{ -> }​formation of vesiclesORlipid bilayer structure led to development of cell membranes[1]→\ce{ -> }​plasma membranes separate internal cellular environment from external surroundings, allowing for controlled interactions with the environment[1]→\ce{ -> }​allow compartmentalisation of different cellular functions[1]→\ce{ -> }​as cells became more complex, different vesicles or membrane-bound organelles evolved to carry out specific tasks within the cell[1]→\ce{ -> }​this specialisation led to increased efficiency and complexity in cellular processes[1]→\ce{ -> }​facilitated concentration of molecules and enzymes in specific areas, which enhanced the efficiency of biochemical reactions[1]→\ce{ -> }​acted as a barrier, preventing reactive molecules from interacting with the surroundings and protecting the delicate molecular structures within[1]→\ce{ -> }​this isolation provided stability in diverse environments[1]→\ce{ -> }​protection of genetic material from the external environment[1][3 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:It is believed that, early in the evolution of life, before the existence of fully developed cells, simple lipid structures similar to vesicles could have formedprotocells(✓\checkmark✓), likely precursors to modern cells. The formation of vesicles and the lipid bilayer structure provided a basis for thedevelopment of cell membranes(✓\checkmark✓). These membranesseparatedtheinternalcellular environment from theexternalsurroundings, allowing forcontrolled interactionswith the environment (✓\checkmark✓). As cells became more complex,different vesiclesor membrane-boundorganellescould haveevolvedto carry outspecific taskswithin the cell (✓\checkmark✓). As cellular life evolved, vesicles provided a means toprotect genetic material(✓\checkmark✓) from the external environment, which was crucial for the stability and transmission of genetic information across generations.

list.title: Question 269
list.content: The following dichotomous key can be used to identify unknown molecules:1. Does the molecule have a sugar linked to a nitrogenous base?-Yes: Go to Step 2-No: It is molecule V2. Does the sugar have a hydroxyl group (-OH) at the 2' carbon?-Yes: It is a type of molecule W. Go to Step 3-No: It is a deoxyribonucleotide3. If the nitrogenous base is a purine, is the base adenine or guanine?-Adenine: Go to Step 4-Guanine: It is molecule X4. How many phosphate groups are present?-Three: It is molecule Y-Two: It is molecule ZWhich row shows the correct identification of the molecules?Molecule VMolecule WMolecule YMolecule ZA.\hspace{1em}RibonucleotideDeoxyribonucleotideATPADPB.\hspace{1em}DeoxyribonucleotideRibonucleotideATPADPC.\hspace{1em}Ribose sugarRibonucleotideATPDeoxyribonucleotideD.\hspace{1em}Ribose sugarRibonucleotideATPADP
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Dis correct because molecule V must be ribose sugar as it is the only option that is not linked to a nitrogenous base. If the sugar lacks the 2′-OH group, it indicates deoxyribose, so molecule W must be a type of ribonucleotide. The base in Y and Z is adenine (as determined by subsequent steps), so for molecule Y  where there are three phosphate groups, the molecule is classified as ATP (adenosine triphosphate). If there are two phosphate groups instead, the molecule is to ADP (adenosine diphosphate) (molecule Z).Choice Ais incorrect because molecules V and W are incorrect.Choice Bis incorrect because molecule V is incorrect.Choice Cis incorrect because molecule Z is incorrect.

list.title: Question 270
list.content: Which factor determined primarily whether water from asteroids remained on Earth rather than escaping into space?A.\hspace{1em}The presence of greenhouse gases which insulates Earth and prevents the loss of water vapour to space.B.\hspace{1em}The presence of autotrophic prokaryotes which photolysed water from the atmosphere in photosynthesis.C.\hspace{1em}The strength of Earth’s gravitational field which prevents water from diffusing into space.D.\hspace{1em}The favourable range of temperatures on Earth allowing water to exist in solid, liquid and gaseous states.
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Earth’s gravity pulls all matter, including water, toward the centre of the Earth, preventing water from escaping into space.Choice Cis correct.Greenhouse gases such as carbon dioxide insulate the Earth, however, greenhouse gases trap heat, not water;Choice Ais incorrect.Autotrophic prokaryotes appeared on Earth after the Earth had already retained a large amount of water;Choice Bis incorrect.Although the temperature on Earth is favourable for the condensation and freezing of water, temperature alone is not sufficient to keep water on Earth. Without gravitational force, water would not remain on Earth;Choice Dis incorrect.

list.title: Question 271
list.content: Distinguish between the structure and location of chromosomes found in eukaryotes and prokaryotes.[5]Describe the stages of meiosis and how genetically unique, haploid gametes are created during the process.[7]Explain the information that can be deduced from a human karyogram.[3]
list.markScheme: Anyfiveof the following:→\ce{ -> }​eukaryotic chromosomes are found in the nucleusWHEREASprokaryotic chromosomes are found in the nucleoid regionORchromosomes of eukaryotes are contained within a membraneWHEREASprokaryotic chromosomes are not membrane bound[1]→\ce{ -> }​prokaryotes have a circular chromosomeWHEREASeukaryotes have linear chromosomes[1]→\ce{ -> }​prokaryotes typically have one chromosomeWHEREASeukaryotes typically have multiple chromosomes[1]→\ce{ -> }​in eukaryotic chromosomes, DNA is associated with histone proteinsWHEREASprokaryotic chromosomes do not contain histones[1]→\ce{ -> }​prokaryotic chromosomes do not contain centromeresWHEREASeukaryotic chromosomes do[1]→\ce{ -> }​prokaryotic chromosomes do not contain telomeresWHEREASeukaryotic chromosomes do[1]→\ce{ -> }​eukaryotic chromosomes carry more genetic informationORDNAORgenesTHANprokaryotic chromosomes[1][5 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Eukaryotic chromosomes are found in thenucleuswhereas prokaryotic chromosomes are found in thenucleoidregion (✓\checkmark✓). Prokaryotes typically containone, circularchromosome (✓\checkmark✓)  whereas eukaryotes  havemultiple, linearchromosomes (✓\checkmark✓). Prokaryotic chromosomesdo notcontaincentromeresandtelomeres(✓\checkmark✓), whereas eukaryotic chromosomes do (✓\checkmark✓).Anysevenof the following:→\ce{ -> }​all the DNA in a cell is replicated during interphase[1]→\ce{ -> }​so cells are diploidORcontain homologous chromosomes when they enter meiosis[1]→\ce{ -> }​homologous chromosomes pairANDbecome visibleORcondense  in prophase I[1]→\ce{ -> }​crossing over occurs between the non-sister chromatids of homologous chromosomes during prophase I[1]→\ce{ -> }​homologous chromosomes are moved to the equator of the cell by spindle microtubulesANDrandomly orientated OR independently assorted in metaphase I[1]→\ce{ -> }​homologous chromosomes are pulled to opposite sides of the cell by spindle microtubules in anaphase I[1]→\ce{ -> }​one diploid cell is split into two haploid cells[1]→\ce{ -> }​chromatids condenseORbecome visible during prophase II[1]→\ce{ -> }​pairs of sister chromatids are moved to the equator of the cell by spindle microtubules during metaphase IIANDrandomly orientatedORindependently assorted[1]→\ce{ -> }​pairs of sister chromatids are separated by spindle fibres in anaphase II[1]→\ce{ -> }​nuclear membrane reforms in telophase IIANDfour haploid cells are formed from the two haploid cells of 	meiosis[1]→\ce{ -> }​crossing over during prophase IANDindependent assortmentORrandom alignment of homologous chromosomes in metaphase IORmetaphase II result in unique gametes[1][7 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:All of the DNA in a cell isreplicatedduringinterphase(✓\checkmark✓), so cells arediploidwhen they enter meiosis (✓\checkmark✓).Homologouschromosomespair up, becomevisible(✓\checkmark✓) andcrossing overof non-sister chromatids occur duringprophase I(✓\checkmark✓). Then, homologous chromosomes are moved to theequatorof the cell byspindle microtubulesandrandomly orientatedduringmetaphase I(✓\checkmark✓). Homologous chromosomes are pulled to theopposite polesof the cell by spindle fibres inanaphase I(✓\checkmark✓) and onediploid cellis split intotwo haploidcells during telophase I (✓\checkmark✓). The cells then enter meiosis II. Thepairsofsister chromatidsareindependently assortedto form a single line along the equator of the cell, inmetaphase II(✓\checkmark✓). Duringanaphase IIthe centromeres split and thesister chromatidsare pulled toopposite polesof the cell (✓\checkmark✓). Intelophase IIthenuclear membrane reformsaround the chromosomes, and after cytokinesis,4 new haploid, non-identical,  daughter cells are formed from the2 haploid cellsthat resulted frommeiosis I(✓\checkmark✓).Anythreeof the following:→\ce{ -> }​a karyogram is an image showing the positions of centromeres and banding patterns of stainedORdyed homologous chromosomes ordered by decreasing length[1]→\ce{ -> }​biological sex determined by XX and XYORsex chromosomes[1]→\ce{ -> }​whether non-disjunction has occurred is determined by the presence or absence of chromosome (s)[1]→\ce{ -> }​presence of chromosomal abnormalities (such as breakages or translocation) determined by the banding patternORsize of chromosome[1]→\ce{ -> }​indication of chromosome disorders such as Down syndrome, which is caused by trisomy 21[1][3 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:A karyogram is an image showing the positions ofcentromeresandbanding patternsof stainedhomologous chromosomesordered by decreasing length (✓\checkmark✓). A karyogram can be used to deducebiological sex(✓\checkmark✓) or the presence ofchromosomal abnormalities(✓\checkmark✓).A quality mark is awarded if each part of the question (a, b, c) is answered to earn at least half of the points available, answers do not require re-reading to be understood, and there are almost no errors and little irrelevant information.[1]

list.title: Question 272
list.content:
The diagram below shows a cell.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e319f2ff-2759-4a29-a432-86b278d912d1/images/921bf923-691c-4540-aaea-d868eb9c341e/BI0805A.png)

[Source: Adapted from Gonzalez, R., & Kerfeld, C. (2022, June 13).Synechococcus elongatus. Wikipedia. Retrieved June 19, 2022, from https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Synechococcus_elongatus Copyright under CC BY 3.0]Compare and contrast the structure of a mictochondrion with the structure of the cell shown in the diagram.[2]Explain why the cell in the diagram is structurally similar to a mitochondrion.[2]
list.markScheme: Anytwoof the following:Similarities→\ce{ -> }​bothhave plasma membranes[1]→\ce{ -> }​bothcontain circularORnaked DNA[1]→\ce{ -> }​mitochondrial ribosomes are more similar in sizeORstructure to prokaryotes than eukaryotesOR bothcontain 70S ribosomes[1]→\ce{ -> }​bothare similar in size[1]→\ce{ -> }​bothare similar shapesORovalORelongated[1]→\ce{ -> }​bothhave ATPase proteins embedded in surrounding membrane[1]Differences→\ce{ -> }​mitochondria do not have a cell wallORa capsule whereas, prokaryotes do[1]→\ce{ -> }​prokaryotes may have flagellaORpili but mitochondria do not[1]Answer must include at least one difference and one similarity to gain full marks[2 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:The cell in the diagram is a prokaryotic cell and is similar in structure to a mitochondrion, as mitochondrialribosomesare moresimilar in sizeandstructureto prokaryotes than eukaryotes, (✓\checkmark✓), and they both havenaked circular DNA(✓\checkmark✓). However mitochondriado not have a cell wall(✓\checkmark✓), whereasprokaryotic cells do.Anytwoof the following:→\ce{ -> }​endosymbiotic theory[1]→\ce{ -> }​mitochondria evolved from free-living prokaryotes[1]→\ce{ -> }​that were engulfedBUTnot digested by larger prokaryotes[1][2 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:The prokaryotic cell in the diagram has structural similarities to a mitochondrion, due to theendosymbiotic theory(✓\checkmark✓) which explains that mitochondria evolved fromfree-living prokaryotes(✓\checkmark✓) that wereengulfed though not digested(✓\checkmark✓) by larger cells.

list.title: Question 273
list.content:
Haem is the non-protein, iron-binding component found in haemoglobin.  Haem and chlorophyll are similar in structure but chlorophyll contains a magnesium ion instead of iron. The biochemical pathways that make haem and chlorophyll involve enzymes that are highly conserved across many distantly related species.  The diagram shows an amino acid sequence alignment for part of one such enzyme, delta-aminolevulinate dehydratase. Each amino acid is represented by a single-letter code.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/ead7be09-9196-4de7-99cd-8c7fad3ab982/images/dea9dbde-ae55-4c23-a6af-855ba79a2b83/Edit1.png)

[Source: Alignment created with and adapted from Cobalt with Refseq and Genbank sequences from National Center for Biotechnology Information (NCBI)[Internet].Bethesda (MD): National Library of Medicine (US), National Center for Biotechnology Information; [1988] – [cited 2024]. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/]The diagram suggests that certain metabolic pathways are conserved across diverse organisms. Discuss how these conserved pathways provide evidence for LUCA.[2]Suggest two environmental conditions found in hydrothermal vents that may have facilitated the evolution of early metabolic pathways.[2]Explain how genomic analysis can be used to estimate the time period in which the last universal common ancestor (LUCA) existed.[2]Scientists discovered a bacterial enzyme with a significantly different amino acid sequence from its human counterpart but nearly identical function.  Suggest possible reasons why this function is conserved despite sequence divergence.[2]
list.markScheme: anytwoof the following:→\ce{ -> }​conserved metabolic pathwaysORsimilar enzymes in conserved pathways suggest a shared evolutionary originORfundamental processes like glycolysisORATP synthesisORprotein translation are found in all life forms[1]→\ce{ -> }​highly conserved pathways demonstrate biochemical efficiency favoured in natural selectionORstrong selective pressure[1]→\ce{ -> }​the lack of any other widespread metabolic mechanisms suggests competition and extinction of other forms of life[1][2 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Manyfundamental processeslikeglycolysisareconservedacrossall known life forms(✓\checkmark✓).  This indicates a shared evolutionary origin and supports the idea of LUCA (the last universal common ancestor).  Thelack of other metabolic mechanisms suggeststhat they may have existed in early species but were outcompeted andbecame extinct(✓\checkmark✓).anytwoof the following:→\ce{ -> }​heat energy to increase the rate of chemical reactions[1]→\ce{ -> }​high pressure at thermal vents stabilised complex chemical reactions that could not occur in less extreme environments[1]→\ce{ -> }​minerals to serve as catalysts promoting biochemical reactions[1]→\ce{ -> }​mineral-rich vents may have mimicked cell membranes, concentrating molecules and enabling the development of metabolic pathways[1]→\ce{ -> }​proton gradientsORpH gradient for ATP synthesis via chemiosmosis[1]→\ce{ -> }​energy sources such as hydrogenORmethaneORsulfide gases as electron donors for metabolic reactions[1]→\ce{ -> }​highly reduced compounds from vents coming into contact with the ocean’s oxidised compounds provided redox gradients driving early metabolism[1]→\ce{ -> }​lack of oxygen prevented oxidative damage to early organic moleculesORsupported anaerobic metabolism development[1][2 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:The heat and high-pressure environment of the hydrothermal vents may have enabled the evolution of metabolic pathways asheat energy increasestherateofchemical reactions(✓\checkmark✓) andhigh pressure stabilises complex chemical reactions(✓\checkmark✓) that may not have been able to occur in less extreme environments.anytwoof the following:→\ce{ -> }​phylogenetic trees constructed from genomic data illustrate evolutionary relationships[1]→\ce{ -> }​comparing conserved genetic sequences helps infer evolutionary timelines, as more conserved sequences indicate older ancestry[1]→\ce{ -> }​genomic evidence combined with other evidenceORfossils helps establish LUCA’s timefram[1]→\ce{ -> }​molecular clocks estimate divergence time by assuming mutations accumulate at a constant rate[1]→\ce{ -> }​highly conserved ribosomal RNAORrRNA sequences are useful for estimating divergence events[1][2 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Phylogenetic trees, constructed from genomic data, illustrateevolutionary relationships, helping estimate when LUCA existed by identifyingdivergence points(✓\checkmark✓)Molecular clocksfurther refine this by comparinggenetic differencesand applying aknown mutation rateto infer thetimingof common ancestry (✓\checkmark✓).anytwoof the following:→\ce{ -> }​proteins with different primary sequences can fold into similar three-dimensional conformationsORstructures[1]→\ce{ -> }​an enzyme's function depends on its 3-D structure[1]→\ce{ -> }​variations in sites other than the active site may not affect function[1]→\ce{ -> }​convergence in evolution can lead to functionally similar enzymes despite a difference in sequence[1]→\ce{ -> }​some amino acid substitutions are neutral and do not alter protein foldingORstabilityORactive site configuration[1]→\ce{ -> }​other structural adaptationsORflexible binding sitesORother suitable named adaptation allow variations in sequence without affecting overall enzyme function[1][2 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Proteins withdifferent primary sequencesfold intosimilar three-dimensional structures(✓\checkmark✓). Since anenzyme’s functiondepends on its3D structure, especiallythe shape of theactive site(✓\checkmark✓), as long as it has asimilar structure, it should be able to perform asimilar function(✓\checkmark✓).

list.title: Question 274
list.content: Which of the following isnotan example of speciation?A.\hspace{1em}Evolution of different beak shapes in finches (C. olivacea)B.\hspace{1em}Breeding varieties of green apples (M. domestica) with desirable characteristicsC.\hspace{1em}Squirrels on the North and South rims of the grand canyon, who cannot interbreedD.\hspace{1em}Buffalo grass (B. dactyloides) is able to grow in polluted soil but other species of grass cannot
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Bis correct because it refers to selective breeding, not speciation.Choices A,CandDare all examples of speciation.

list.title: Question 275
list.content:
What is the correct magnification of this image?

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/07e9979a-f2b9-4ab8-a9ce-3e18e0fd6058/images/f345e14c-8773-402b-bcc4-ddb8b6a5d28c/bi0752.png)

[Source: Adapted from Itayba, Hebrew Wikipedia (2006, March 1).FileMicroscope Siemens, 1960.jpg - wikimedia commons. Wikimedia commons. Retrieved March 4, 2023, from https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File: Electron_microscope_Siemens,_1960.jpg Copyright under CC BY 3.0]A.\hspace{1em}1000 xB.\hspace{1em}100 xC.\hspace{1em}0.1 xD.\hspace{1em}10000 x
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Magnification is calculated using the equation image size divided by actual size. Both numbers must be the same units. The image size of the magnification bar is 5 mm, or 5000 µm, the actual size of the magnification bar is 5 µm. 5000 µm ÷ 5 µm = 1000 x.Choice Ais correct.Choices B, CandDare incorrect.

list.title: Question 276
list.content: Outline how the properties of water contributed to the origin of life on Earth.[4]Drawtwowater molecules, labelling the partial charges and the bond between them.[3]Explain how the solubility of different types of substances in water affects their transport in the blood, giving named examples.[8]
list.markScheme:
anyfourof the following:→\ce{ -> }​polarity of water molecules enables formation of hydrogen bonds[1]→\ce{ -> }​hydrogen bonding assisted formation of stable moleculesORassembly of complex structuresORlipid bilayerORother suitable named structures[1]→\ce{ -> }​solvent properties facilitated dissolutionORinteraction of organic molecules[1]→\ce{ -> }​enabled formation of more complex structuresORprotocellsORprecursors to first living cells[1]→\ce{ -> }​high specific heat capacity prevented rapid temperature changes, enabling chemical reactions to occur[1]→\ce{ -> }​provided medium for enzymesORchemical reactionsORsynthesis of biological molecules[1][4 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Water’spolarityenables the formation ofhydrogen bonds(✓\checkmark✓), which are crucial for thestabilityandassemblyofcomplex structuressuch asDNA, proteinsandlipid bilayers(✓\checkmark✓). As auniversal solvent, water facilitated thedissolutionandinteractionoforganic molecules(✓\checkmark✓), leading to the formation ofprotocells(✓\checkmark✓). Additionally, water’shigh specific heat capacityprovided astable environment, preventingrapidtemperature changesand allowing essentialenzymaticcontrolledreactionsto occur (✓\checkmark✓).anythreeof the following:→\ce{ -> }​two water molecules each made up of one oxygen atom attached to two hydrogen atoms[1]→\ce{ -> }​slight negative charge on oxygen atom and slight positive charge on both hydrogen atoms on at least one of the water molecules[1]→\ce{ -> }​hydrogen bond drawn as dashed lines and labelled[1][3 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/0f8ac320-dd55-4e2c-8523-3fbe967de58c/images/39e5c1ff-dbf6-4ef4-be6d-da3d4ccbc552/BI1758b.png)

anyeightof the following:→\ce{ -> }​transport of molecules in the blood depends on their solubility in water[1]→\ce{ -> }​transport occurs in blood plasma and red blood cells[1]→\ce{ -> }​hydrophilicORwater-soluble substances travel freely in solution[1]→\ce{ -> }​ionic compoundsORions transported in plasma[1]→\ce{ -> }​NaCl dissociates into Na+ and Cl- ions and carried in plasmaORNaCl is transported as free ions in plasma[1]→\ce{ -> }​glucose is polar, so dissolves in water and travels in plasma[1]→\ce{ -> }​solubility of amino acids determined by side chain[1]→\ce{ -> }​amino acids are transported in an ionised state[1]→\ce{ -> }​hydrophobicORwater-insoluble substances can not travel in solution[1]→\ce{ -> }​oxygen is non-polarORhas limited solubility in plasma[1]→\ce{ -> }​majority of oxygen binds to haemoglobinORis transported by red blood cells[1]→\ce{ -> }​cholesterolORfatsORlipidsORtriglycerides are non-polarORhydrophobic and bind to proteinsORform lipoproteins to become soluble[1][8 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Thetransportof molecules in the blood isdetermined bytheirsolubilityin water (✓\checkmark✓).Hydrophilicsubstances, such asglucose(✓\checkmark✓) andionised amino acids(✓\checkmark✓),dissolveeasilyin plasmaandtravel freelyinsolution(✓\checkmark✓).Ionic compoundslikesodium chloride dissociateand are carried asfree ions, such asNa+^++and Cl−^-−(✓\checkmark✓), in theplasma(✓\checkmark✓). In contrast,non-polar substanceslikeoxygenandlipidsarenot solublein water. Only asmall proportionofoxygenisdissolvedin theplasma; it isprimarily transportedby binding tohaemoglobin(✓\checkmark✓)  inred blood cells(✓\checkmark✓).Lipids, includingcholesterolandtriglycerides,bind to proteinsto formlipoproteins, which makes themsolubleand allows their transport in the bloodstream (✓\checkmark✓).A quality mark is awarded if each part of the question (a, b, c) is answered to earn at least half of the points available, answers do not require re-reading to be understood, and there are almost no errors and little irrelevant information.[1]

list.title: Question 277
list.content: Why does chromosome number affect hybrid fertility?A.\hspace{1em}Species with different chromosome numbers can always produce fertile offspring because meiosis is not affected by chromosome pairing.B.\hspace{1em}Hybrids with mismatched chromosome numbers have increased genetic diversity, making them more fertile.C.\hspace{1em}Chromosome number only affects physical traits, not reproductive ability.D.\hspace{1em}Hybrids with different chromosome numbers cannot produce functional gametes because homologous chromosomes fail to pair during meiosis.
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Dis correct because meiosis requires homologous chromosomes to pair correctly. If the chromosome numbers do not match, pairing cannot occur properly, leading to errors in gamete formation and often resulting in sterility.Choice Ais incorrect because mismatched chromosomes disrupt meiosis, preventing successful gamete production and leading to sterility in many hybrids.Choice Bis incorrect because increased genetic diversity does not necessarily lead to higher fertility—chromosome mismatches usually cause sterility rather than increased reproductive success.Choice Cis incorrect because chromosome number directly affects meiosis and fertility.

list.title: Question 278
list.content: Outline how overpopulation is an important part of natural selection.[3]Discuss why sympatric speciation is less common than allopatric speciation[5]Explain how gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) and steroid sex hormones control the developmental changes during puberty.[7]
list.markScheme: anythreeof the following:→\ce{ -> }​overpopulation can lead to a higher rate of mutationORincrease effects of genetic drift[1]→\ce{ -> }​overpopulation increases genetic diversityORincreases variation in the gene pool[1]→\ce{ -> }​overpopulation increases competition for resourcesORleads to struggle for survivalORcreates selection pressure[1]→\ce{ -> }​individuals with favourable characteristicsORadvantageous traitsORbetter adapted, survive and reproduce more[1]→\ce{ -> }​over time, frequency of advantageous traits increases in the population driving evolution through natural selection[1][3 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Overpopulation increases variationin thegene poolof a population (✓\checkmark✓) and alsocompetition for resources(✓\checkmark✓). This meansbetter-adapted individualsaremore likelytosurvive, pass on theirallelesand soadvantageous traitsbecomemore common, drivingevolutionthroughnatural selection(✓\checkmark✓).anyfiveof the following:→\ce{ -> }​sympatric speciation occurs within the same geographic areaWHEREASallopatric speciation occurs due to geographic isolation of populations[1]→\ce{ -> }​sympatric speciation relies on reproductive isolationORbehaviouralORtemporalORecological isolationWHEREASallopatric speciation is caused by geographic barriersORsuitable named example of barrier[1]→\ce{ -> }​in sympatric speciation, populations remain in contact, so gene flow must be strongly reduced by other mechanismsWHEREASin allopatric speciation, gene flow is completely prevented due to physical separation[1]→\ce{ -> }​in sympatric speciation, divergence occurs due to strong natural selection within the same environmentWHEREASin allopatric speciation, divergence occurs due to genetic drift, mutation, and natural selection in separate environments[1]→\ce{ -> }​sympatric speciation is less common because preventing gene flow in the absence of geographic barriers is difficultWHEREASallopatric speciation is more common because physical barriers easily prevent interbreeding[1]→\ce{ -> }​in sympatric speciation, hybrids may form between diverging groups, slowing the speciation processWHEREASin allopatric speciation, hybrids are unlikely due to the complete physical separation of populations[1]→\ce{ -> }​sympatric speciation generally takes longer due to persistent gene flowWHEREASallopatric speciation can occur more quickly if geographic isolation is complete[1]→\ce{ -> }​sympatric speciation is often seen in insects, plants (e.g., polyploidy), or cichlid fishWHEREASallopatric speciation is observed across most taxa, including birds, mammals, and reptiles[1][5 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Sympatric speciationoccurs within thesame geographic area, whereasallopatricspeciation occursdue to geographic isolation(✓\checkmark✓). Insympatric speciation,reproductive isolation mechanismslikebehavioural, temporal, orecological isolation reduce gene flow, whileallopatricspeciation relies onphysical barrierslikemountainsorriversto completelyprevent interbreeding(✓\checkmark✓).Gene flowis morechallenging to preventinsympatricspeciation, making itless commoncompared toallopatric speciation(✓\checkmark✓).Divergenceinsympatricspeciation often requiresstrong natural selection, whereasallopatricspeciation is driven bygenetic drift, mutation, andnatural selectioninseparate environments(✓\checkmark✓). For example,sympatricspeciation can occur incichlid fishexploitingdifferent nichesin thesame lake, whileDarwin’s finchesevolved throughallopatricspeciation due toisolationondifferent islands(✓\checkmark✓).anysevenof the following:→\ce{ -> }​gonadotropin-releasing hormoneORGnRH released from hypothalamus triggers puberty[1]→\ce{ -> }​GnRH stimulates anterior pituitary gland to release luteinising hormoneORLHANDfollicle-stimulating hormoneORFSH[1]→\ce{ -> }​LHORFSH target gonadsORtestesANDovaries to promote production of steroid sex hormones[1]→\ce{ -> }​in males, LH stimulates Leydig cellsORtestes to produce testosterone[1]→\ce{ -> }​testosterone promotes secondary sexual characteristics such as increased muscle massORdeepening of the voiceORgrowth of facialORbody hair[1]→\ce{ -> }​testosterone stimulates spermatogenesisORsperm production[1]→\ce{ -> }​in females, FSH stimulates the growthORmaturation of ovarian follicles[1]→\ce{ -> }​surge in LH triggers ovulation[1]→\ce{ -> }​LH causes ruptured follicle to develop into corpus luteum[1]→\ce{ -> }​corpus luteum secretes progesteroneANDoestradiolORoestrogen[1]→\ce{ -> }​oestradiolORoestrogen promotes secondary sexual characteristics such as breast developmentORwidening of the hipsORfat deposition[1]→\ce{ -> }​oestradiolORoestrogen brings about thickening of endometrium to prepare for implantation[1]→\ce{ -> }​progesterone stimulates developmental changes in the breasts to prepare for lactationORprepares uterus for pregnancyORmaintains thickening of endometrium[1]→\ce{ -> }​testosteroneORoestradiol provide negative feedback to the hypothalamusORanterior pituitary to maintain hormone levels[1]→\ce{ -> }​steroid sex hormones contribute to the closure of epiphyseal growth platesORhalt further height increase[1][7 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Pubertyisinitiatedwhen thehypothalamussecretesgonadotropin-releasing hormone(GnRH) in a pulsatile manner (✓\checkmark✓), stimulating theanterior pituitary glandto releaseluteinising hormone(LH) andfollicle-stimulating hormone(FSH) (✓\checkmark✓). These hormones target thegonadsto promote the production of thesteroid sex hormones, testosteroneandoestradiol(✓\checkmark✓). Inmales, testosteronepromotessecondary sexual characteristicssuch asincreased musclemass andfacial hair(✓\checkmark✓), and infemales, oestradiolbrings aboutsecondary sexual characteristicssuch asbreast developmentand thewideningof thehips(✓\checkmark✓). Also, in females,FSHstimulates thegrowth and maturationofovarian follicles(✓\checkmark✓), and then asurgeinLHinducesovulationof a mature follicle (✓\checkmark✓). LH also causes theruptured follicleto develop into thecorpus luteum, which secretesoestradiolandprogesterone(✓\checkmark✓).A quality mark is awarded if each part of the question (a, b, c) is answered to earn at least half of the points available, answers do not require re-reading to be understood, and there are almost no errors and little irrelevant information.[1]

list.title: Question 279
list.content: When early lifeforms first emerged on Earth, the levels of UV radiation were much higher than they are today. How did higher levels of UV radiation affect the conditions of the early Earth?A.\hspace{1em}Provided energy for photosynthesis, so plants produced higher levels of oxygenB.\hspace{1em}Broke down gases into smaller moleculesC.\hspace{1em}Mutated DNA nucleotide sequences so that a variety of polypeptides were formedD.\hspace{1em}Caused volcanoes to release gases into the atmosphere
list.markScheme: BSample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:The high levels of UV radiation broke down gases in the early atmosphere, which provided smaller, highly reactive molecules that eventually formed the building blocks of life, such as amino acids, peptides and ribose.Choice Bis correct.Billions of years ago, there were no plants, and high levels of UV can affect plants adversely by damaging DNA;Choice Ais incorrect. Although UV radiation affects DNA, DNA was not thought to be present when the first life forms appeared;Choice Cis incorrect. UV radiation did not cause volcanoes to release gases into the atmosphere, this was caused by Earth cooling down after the Hadean aeon;Choice Dis incorrect.

list.title: Question 280
list.content: Explain four properties of water that make it important in supporting life on Earth.[4]Describe the recent methods used to reclassify plant groups, such as the figwort family (Scrophulariaceae), based on cladistic evidence.[4]Explain how the structure of synovial joints is adapted for movement and why this influences the range of motion.[7]
list.markScheme: anyfourof the following:→\ce{ -> }​solvent so enables reactions to occurORtransport of substances[1]→\ce{ -> }​large latent heat of vaporisationORA large amount of energy is needed to evaporate water so provides a cooling effect[1]→\ce{ -> }​high specific heat capacityORwater absorbsORretains heat without large changes in temperature, providing thermal stability in aquatic environmentsORorganisms[1]→\ce{ -> }​cohesionORhydrogen bonding between water molecules aids water transport in plantsORcreates surface tension, enabling small organismsORinsects to move on water[1]→\ce{ -> }​adhesionORwater molecules stick to other polar surfaces, supporting capillary action in plants[1]→\ce{ -> }​ice floatsORice is less dense than liquid waterORwater’s density decreases as it cools below 4°\degree°C insulating aquatic ecosystems in cold climatesORhelping aquatic life survive in cold conditions[1]→\ce{ -> }​water is transparent, allowing light to penetrate for photosynthesis in aquatic plantsORalgaeORenables visibility in aquatic environments[1]→\ce{ -> }​provides buoyancy, enabling aquatic organisms to remain suspendedORsupports the body structure of soft-bodied aquatic organisms[1]→\ce{ -> }​amphoteric natureORcan act as both an acid and a base, maintaining pH balance in biological systems[1]→\ce{ -> }​non-compressible helps maintain cell turgorORstructure of plant cells[1][4 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Water has ahigh specific heat capacitywhich allows it toabsorbandretain heat, providingthermal stabilityforaquatic environmentsandliving organisms(✓\checkmark✓). It is also auniversal solventdue to itspolarity, enabling it todissolve ionsandorganic moleculesfortransportandbiochemical reactions(✓\checkmark✓). Thecohesionbetween water moleculessupportsthetransport of waterinplantsthrough thexylem, whilesurface tensionallowssmall organisms, like insects, tomove on water(✓\checkmark✓).Ice is less densethan liquid water, which ensures itfloatsandinsulates aquatic ecosystemsincold environments, protecting life below (✓\checkmark✓).anyfourof the following:→\ce{ -> }​early classification was based on morphologyORgrouped plants based on visible traits[1]→\ce{ -> }​early classification often led to misclassification due to convergent evolution[1]→\ce{ -> }​recent cladistics relies on molecular data,ORDNAORRNA nucleotideORamino acid sequencingORsequence comparisons[1]→\ce{ -> }​molecular clock estimates divergence timesORDNA mutations occur at a relatively constant rate, allowing estimation of when species diverged from a common ancestor[1]→\ce{ -> }​phylogenetic tree construction from genetic data[1]→\ce{ -> }​common derived characteristics define clades[1]→\ce{ -> }​number of differences in genetic sequences indicates evolutionary distance from a common ancestor[1]→\ce{ -> }​use of outgroups to determine which traits are homologousORancestralORwhich traits are analogousORresult from convergent evolution[1]→\ce{ -> }​cladistics has led to reclassification of plant familiesORfigwort familyORScrophulariaceaewas reclassified after genetic analysis revealed it contained multiple unrelated lineages[1][4 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Earlyplantclassificationwas based onmorphology, grouping plants byvisible traitssuch as leaf and flower structure  (✓\checkmark✓). However, this often led tomisclassificationdue toconvergent evolution, whereunrelated speciesdevelopedsimilar features(✓\checkmark✓).Modern cladisticsnow relies onDNA sequencingtoanalyse genetic differencesand determineevolutionary relationships(✓\checkmark✓). Themolecular clockhelpsestimate divergence times, asmutationsaccumulate at arelatively constant rate(✓\checkmark✓). This has led to thereclassificationofplant families, such as thefigwort family(Scrophulariaceae), aftergenetic analysisrevealedmultiple unrelated lineages(✓\checkmark✓).anysevenof the following(must contain at leasttwofrom each section to gain full marks):how the structure of a synovial joint allows movement→\ce{ -> }​joint cavity filled with synovial fluid,WHICHreduces frictionORallows smooth movementORnourishes the cartilageORlubricates the joint[1]→\ce{ -> }​articulating surfaces of bones are covered by cartilageWHICHreduces frictionORcushions the jointORprevents bone-to-bone contact[1]→\ce{ -> }​ligaments provide stability by connecting bonesANDpreventing excessive or harmful movement[1]→\ce{ -> }​synovial membrane produces synovial fluid[1]→\ce{ -> }​capsuleORcapsular ligament seals the jointANDprovides additional stability while allowing movement[1]→\ce{ -> }​bones provide a firm anchorage for musclesANDact as levers to amplify movement[1]→\ce{ -> }​tendons attach muscles to bones, enabling movement when muscles contract[1]factors that influence the range of motion→\ce{ -> }​shape of the articulating surfaces determines the range of movement possible[1]→\ce{ -> }​joint capsuleORligaments - restrict movement to prevent injury, limiting excessive range while allowing flexibility[1]→\ce{ -> }​hinge joints only allow movement in one plane flexionANDextension[1]→\ce{ -> }​ball and socket joints allow protractionANDretractionORabductionANDadductionORrotation[1]→\ce{ -> }​range of motion is influenced by the shape and fit of the bones at the joint[1]→\ce{ -> }​the flexibility and strength of surrounding ligaments affect how far a joint can move without injury[1]→\ce{ -> }​damage to cartilage reduces range of movement due to painORfriction[1]→\ce{ -> }​strongerORmore flexible muscles can support a greater range of motion[1][7 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Synovial joints facilitate movement through their unique structure. Articulatingbonesare covered withcartilagetoreduce friction(✓\checkmark✓), andsynovial fluidwithin thejoint cavity lubricatesthe joint (✓\checkmark✓).Ligaments stabilizethe joint by connecting the bones (✓\checkmark✓), whiletendons transmit forcesfrommusclestobones, as they areattached to both(✓\checkmark✓). Theshapeof the joint, such as ball-and-socket or hinge types, determines thetypesofmovementspossible (✓\checkmark✓). Therangeofmotionis influenced by thefit of the bones(✓\checkmark✓), theflexibilityofligaments(✓\checkmark✓), and thestrengthofsurrounding muscles(✓\checkmark✓).A quality mark is awarded if each part of the question (a, b, c) is answered to earn at least half of the points available, answers do not require re-reading to be understood, and there are almost no errors and little irrelevant information.[1]

list.title: Question 281
list.content: Two species of smartweed (genusPersicaria) hybridise and form a new species.  Which of the examples of parent chromosome number would result in a barrier to reproduction?I.2nII.3nIII.4nA.\hspace{1em}I onlyB.\hspace{1em}II onlyC.\hspace{1em}I and III onlyD.\hspace{1em}I, II, and IIII
list.markScheme:
BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Bis correct because 3n cells cannot undergo meiosis and, therefore, they would be a barrier to reproduction.If both parents have the regular diploid chromosome number (2n) then the resulting offspring would also be 2n, due to normal meiotic cell division and formation of viable gametes. A parent with a diploid number of chromosomes would, therefore, not be a barrier to reproduction.
Even though tetraploidy (4n) can lead to more complex pairing of chromosomes during meiosis, the even number of chromosomes allows meiosis to occur and viable gametes can be produced. A tetraploid parent would, therefore, not necessarily be a barrier to reproduction.Choices A,CandDdo not include 3n, and so are not correct answers.

Retrieved March 24, 2025 from https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0016703718304095. Copyright under CC BY 4.0]Explain why analysis of carbonaceous chondrites has led to the hypothesis that meteorites are most likely to be the source of water on Earth.[2]Explaintwoproperties of water that make it an essential molecule for life.[2]Other than water, deduce with a reasonone other substancefound on the Murchison meteorite that is essential for life.[1]The ‘Goldilocks’ zone is the area around a star, where the conditions are optimal for the presence of liquid water.Other than liquid water, statetwoproperties that a planet in the Goldilocks zone may need for life to evolve.[2]Carbonaceous chondrites have also collided with planets in the solar system that are outside the ‘Goldilocks zone’. Suggest why life may not have appeared on those planets.[2]If a planet within the ‘Goldilocks zone’does nothave an atmosphere, suggest how this would affect the retention of liquid water.[1]

substancesWHICHfacilitates cellular metabolic reactionsORtransport of dissolved substances[1]→\ce{ -> }​water is cohesiveORwater molecules can stick to each other due to hydrogen bondingWHICHallows for droplet formationORcapillary actionORsurface tension in plants[1]→\ce{ -> }​water is adhesiveORwater molecules stick to other surfaces due to hydrogen bondingWHICHallows for processes such as the transpiration stream in plants[1]→\ce{ -> }​water has a high specific heat capacityORit resists sudden changes in temperatureWHICHhelps organisms maintain homeostasisORstabilises temperatures in large bodies of water[1]→\ce{ -> }​water has a high heat of vaporisationORit requires a large amount of energy to convert liquid water into gasWHICHallows organisms to regulate body temperature through sweating or transpiration[1]→\ce{ -> }​solid water (ice) is less dense than liquid water therefore, ice can floatWHICHmeans that aquatic ecosystems are insulated from large fluctuations in temperature[1][2 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Water is auniversal solventwhich facilitates a range ofcellular metabolic reactions(✓\checkmark✓), and it iscohesive, which allows for processes such aswater droplet formationor the formation oflarge bodiesof water (✓\checkmark✓).anyoneof the following:→\ce{ -> }​amino acidsBECAUSEthey are used to build proteins which can be used to make enzymes, build tissues or regulate processes[1]→\ce{ -> }​purinesORpyrimidinesBECAUSEthey can be used to build RNAORDNA nucleotides[1][1 mark maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Amino acids, because they are thebuilding blocks of all proteins(✓\checkmark✓), such as enzymes.anytwoof the following:→\ce{ -> }​presence of organic moleculesORpresence of key chemical elementsORthree named key elements from carbon, oxygen, hydrogen, nitrogen, phosphorus, sulfur[1]→\ce{ -> }​a large enough sizeORsufficient planetary massto generate enough gravitational pull to retain an atmosphere[1]→\ce{ -> }​a solid surfaceORlithosphereORcrust[1]→\ce{ -> }​a source of energyORa central starORa nearby SunORsolar energyORlightningORgeothermalORhydrothermal activity to drive metabolicORprebiotic chemical reactions[1]→\ce{ -> }​a magnetic field to shield the surface from solar windORcosmic radiationORpreserve DNA integrityORto protect life from harmful radiation[1]→\ce{ -> }​stable climate  orbital stability to allow sufficient time for chemical evolution and life to emerge[1]→\ce{ -> }​presence of an atmosphere to support temperature regulation, pressure for liquid water,ORprotection from radiation[1][2 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Two factors that a planet in the ‘Goldilocks zone’ may need for life to evolve are  thepresence of organic molecules(✓\checkmark✓) and  asolid surface(✓\checkmark✓) that allows the accumulation and organisation of complex compounds.anytwoof the following:→\ce{ -> }​the planet may be too small so may not have sufficient gravity to sustain an atmosphereORretain liquid water[1]→\ce{ -> }​the planet may be too large resulting in excessive gravityORa dense atmosphere which results in surface temperatures which are too high for chemicalORmetabolic reactions[1]→\ce{ -> }​the planet may be too coldORtoo far there are no suitable surfacesORhabitats for organisms[1][2 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Although carbonaceous chondrites may have delivered water and Also, the planet may betoo warmorclose to the Sunforliquid water to be present(✓\checkmark✓).anyoneof the following:→\ce{ -> }​there would be no retention of liquid waterBECAUSEwater would evaporate quicklyORsublime[1]→\ce{ -> }​there would be no water retentionORliquid waterBECAUSEUVORultraviolet radiation could break down water molecules[1]→\ce{ -> }​there would be no retention of liquid water BECAUSE water would quickly freeze due to heat not being trapped by the atmosphere[1][1 mark maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:There would beno water retentionbecause water wouldevaporate quicklydue to the lack of atmosphere (✓\checkmark✓).

list.title: Question 283
list.content:
A diagram of HIV is shown below. Which structure is composed of glycoproteins?

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/27b39965-0279-44f4-aba6-2afb109e63e2/images/24bba3f7-b735-4ee4-a260-c806279fb3d8/BI0850.png)

[© Revision Village 2023. Created with Biorender.com]
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Bis correct because HIV spikes are glycoproteins. Reverse transcriptase (Choice A) is an enzyme, and made of protein, not glycoprotein. The matrix (Choice D) and capsid (Choice C) are made of protein but not glycoprotein.

list.title: Question 284
list.content: The table shows the number of tree species in two similarly sized forests.  Which statement about the two communities is correct?Tree speciesForest 1Forest 2\hspace{1em}Quercus alba3025\hspace{1em}Acer rubrum1225\hspace{1em}Fagus sylvatica5025\hspace{1em}Betula occidentalis825\hspace{1em}Total number of trees100100[©Revision Village 2023.]A.\hspace{1em}Forest 2 has the same species richness as Forest 1B.\hspace{1em}Forest 1 has a higher species evenness than Forest 2C.\hspace{1em}Forest 1 has a higher species richness than Forest 2D.\hspace{1em}Forest 2 has an equal species evenness to Forest 1
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Species richness is the number of different species present in an area.  There are 4 species present in both forests soChoice Ais correct.Species evenness is the relative abundance of different species in an area.Choices BandDare incorrect as Forest 2 has a higher species evenness than Forest 1 as there is an equal number of each tree species.Choice Cis incorrect as species richness is the same in both forests.

list.title: Question 285
list.content: Which of the following could be used to identify different species?I.Dichotomous keyII.KaryogramsIII.Binomial naming systemA.\hspace{1em}III onlyB.\hspace{1em}I and II onlyC.\hspace{1em}I and III onlyD.\hspace{1em}I, II and III
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Bis correct because onlyStatements IandIIare correct. Dichotomous keys could be used to identify two different species based on their characteristics, and karyograms could be used to identify two different species based on their chromosome number and size.Choices A, C, andDare incorrect because they containStatement III, which is incorrect. The Binomial naming system can be used to give species a name but does not identify species.
