list.title: Question 287
list.content:
The diagram below shows the results obtained from the genetic fingerprinting of environmental DNA in a soil sample.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/5e705752-e411-4234-80d2-483684b7f199/images/c4b3367b-1955-4405-94ae-2dc7ee425b61/BI2663.png)

[© Revision Village 2025. Created with BioRender.com]How many different species are present in this sample?A.\hspace{1em}9B.\hspace{1em}8C.\hspace{1em}4D.\hspace{1em}6
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Cis correct because there are four different types of DNA profiles with the same banding patterns visible. The well on the left contains the DNA ladder and so should not be counted as a species. Samples 1, 7, and 8 are all the same species, as are samples 3 and 6 and samples 4 and 5. Sample 2 is a unique species.Choice Ais not correct because many of the DNA profiles are identical so they must be from the same species, not different ones. It also includes the DNA ladder in the countChoice Bis not correct because it counts repeating DNA profiles as different species.Choice Dis not correct because it also counts organisms with the same profiles as different species.

list.title: Question 288
list.content:
Chimpanzees (Pan troglodytes) and bonobos (Pan paniscus) diverged from a common ancestor around 1.25 million years ago. This event is thought to have been influenced by the formation of the Congo River.The diagram shows the ranges of chimpanzees and bonobos.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/5ef05d29-cba6-41dc-951e-55b208901826/images/f07512ca-f354-46f2-a2d2-8218db2ed843/BI2806.png)

[Source: Adapted from Guy, Cp. (2016, May 24).File: Bonobo vs chimp.png- Wikimedia Commons. Wikimedia commons. Retrieved January 12 , 2024 from URL https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File: Bonobo_vs_chimp.png. Copyright under CC BY 4.0]Chimpanzees and bonobos are two different species that share a recent common ancestor. Statethreesimilarities or differences between them that would result from this shared ancestry and subsequent divergence.[3]Name and explain which type of speciation is likely to have occurred between chimpanzees and bonobos.[2]Describe the role of differential selection in the speciation event between chimpanzees and bonobos.[2]Explain how the process of speciation affects biodiversity.[1]Suggest why gradual evolutionary change within a single species is not considered speciation in the absence of reproductive isolation.[2]
list.markScheme: anythreeof the following(at leastonefrom each section):Similarities:→\ce{ -> }​similar DNA base sequencesORsimilar mitochondrial DNA sequences[1]→\ce{ -> }​similar amino acid sequencesORcytochrome cORnamed example[1]→\ce{ -> }​similar featuresORmorphologyORhomologous structuresORnamed example[1]Differences:→\ce{ -> }​differences in some gene sequencesORproteins due to gene mutations since divergence[1]→\ce{ -> }​differences in specific behavioursORsocial structures[1]→\ce{ -> }​differences in morphology due to adaptations since divergence[1]→\ce{ -> }​unable to breed and produce fertile offspring[1][3 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Chimpanzees and bonobos havesimilar DNA base sequences(✓\checkmark✓) andamino acid sequencesinproteins(✓\checkmark✓) because they share a recent common ancestor. However, they are nowunable to breed and produce fertile offspring(✓\checkmark✓), which is why they are not the same species.anytwoof the following:→\ce{ -> }​allopatric speciation[1]→\ce{ -> }​a geographical barrierORa river separates the two populations, preventing gene flow between them[1][2 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:It is likely to beallopatricspeciation (✓\checkmark✓) because theCongo River separatesthe two populations,preventing gene flow(✓\checkmark✓).anytwoof the following:→\ce{ -> }​different environmental conditionsORselection pressures in the separated populations favoured different phenotypes[1]→\ce{ -> }​natural selection acted differently on each population, increasing the frequency of different alleles in each group[1]→\ce{ -> }​over time, genetic differences accumulated[1]→\ce{ -> }​this led to reproductive isolation as the populations became too genetically distinct to interbreed[1][2 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:DIfferential selection helped lead to speciation because there weredifferent environmental conditions(✓\checkmark✓) in the different places, This meantdifferent alleleswere selected andincreased in frequency(✓\checkmark✓).\hspace{1em}→\ce{ -> }​speciation increases biodiversityBECAUSEit raises the total number of species on Earth[1][1 mark maximum]\hspace{1em}Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:\hspace{1em}Speciation leads to two species where there was previously one, so it willincreasethe totalnumber of species, whichincreases biodiversity(✓\checkmark✓).anytwoof the following:→\ce{ -> }​reproductive isolation is needed to prevent interbreedingORto separate gene pools[1]→\ce{ -> }​without this, individuals can still mate and produce fertile offspringORalleles are shared within the population[1]→\ce{ -> }​gradual changes within a species without reproductive isolation represent variation within a speciesNOTthe formation of a new species[1][2 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Reproductive isolation is needed toprevent interbreeding(✓\checkmark✓). If individuals can still interbreed, they canshare alleles across the gene pool(✓\checkmark✓). This means there is no accumulation of differences, which leads to speciation.

list.title: Question 289
list.content: Which statement best illustrates the process of evolution?A.\hspace{1em}A horse that increases its maximum running speed has faster offspring.B.\hspace{1em}A random mutation gives resistance to a disease and spreads in the population.C.\hspace{1em}Mutations occur as needed to increase fitness in individuals and populations.D.\hspace{1em}The most complex organisms are the most evolved.
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Bis correct because evolution is the change in heritable characteristics of a population, and random mutations alter heritable traits.  In this case the mutation confers resistance to a disease, making these individuals more likely to survive and pass on the mutation to their offspring.  Over time resistance to the disease becomes more prevalent in the population.Choice Ais incorrect because traits acquired through an organism's lifetime cannot be passed on to the next generation.Choice Cis incorrect because mutations are random and do not occur because an individual or population requires a different trait.Choice Dis incorrect because complexity is not a measure of evolutionary progress, as evolution refers to change over time.

list.title: Question 290
list.content: What feature of the DNA molecule was utilised by Hershey and Chase in order to identify that viral DNA is able to enter host cells, but most of their protein is not?A.\hspace{1em}DNA nucleotides contain phosphorus.B.\hspace{1em}DNA can supercoil around nucleosomes.C.\hspace{1em}DNA contains a short repetitive nucleotide sequence.D.\hspace{1em}DNA strands are held together by hydrogen bonds.
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:In Hershey and Chase's experiment, the radioactive isotope phosphorus,32^{32}32P and radioactive isotope sulfur,35^{35}35S were used to determine whether DNA or protein is responsible for carrying the genetic material.32^{32}32P was incorporated into the DNA core because the nucleotides of DNA contain a phosphate group containing the element phosphorus (choice A). Hydrogen bonding in DNA molecules is unrelated to Hershey and Chase experiment (choice D).DNA being able to supercoil around nucleosomes and having short repetitive nucleotide sequences are not features that were used by Hershey and Chase (choice Bandchoice C).

list.title: Question 291
list.content:
Conservationists must consider the size and arrangement of in situ nature parks when creating and managing them. The diagram below shows the theoretical design of three sets of nature reserves.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/7b63a6d0-f974-4bec-818e-4d366ad65974/images/c4568193-831f-4c41-8602-e860820c7d0c/nature%20reserve%20design%20BI1599ii.png)

[©Revision Village 2024]For each pair of designs labelled A and B, compare the two and determine which design is better suited for the long-term preservation and management of animal populations. For each comparison, provide a reason to justify your choice.[3]
list.markScheme: AI vs BIanyoneof the following:AI is better than BI sincee a larger reserve:→\ce{ -> }​supports more speciesORa wider variety of species[1]→\ce{ -> }​ensures a more stable food chainORprovides more resources[1]→\ce{ -> }​reduction in the chance of inbreedingORextinction[1]→\ce{ -> }​can better buffer species against environmental changes because it includes a variety of microhabitatsORclimates[1]→\ce{ -> }​more likely to support keystone species, critical for structure of community[1]AII vs BIIanyoneof the following:AII is better than BII since a less fragmented reserve:→\ce{ -> }​has better connectivity for breedingORgene flow[1]→\ce{ -> }​has reduced edge effect so fewer disturbancesORpredatorsORinvasive speciesORreduces habitat degradation preserving the core habitat for sensitive species[1]→\ce{ -> }​provides enough resources to sustain viable populations in the long term[1]→\ce{ -> }​might reduce human-wildlife conflict, as animals less likely to stray into human-populated areas[1]AIII vs BIIIanyoneof the following:AIII is better than BIII since corridors:→\ce{ -> }​facilitate movement of animalsORmigration which is crucial for breedingORfinding foodORescaping predatorsORfor maintaining genetic diversity[1]→\ce{ -> }​can make the reserve more accessible for maintenance and management purposes[1][3 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:AI is betterthan BI because thelarger reservearea in AI cansupport more species, as it providesmore resources(✓\checkmark✓).AII is betterthan BII because it isless fragmented. Thisminimisestheedge effect, whichreduces exposureto threats such aspoaching,predation, andinvasive species. (✓\checkmark✓).AIII is betterthan BIII because thecorridorsin AIIIfacilitate animal movement, which is essential formaintaining genetic diversity, accessingresources, andescaping predators. (✓\checkmark✓).

list.title: Question 292
list.content: Electron microscopy provides images of cells with significantly higher resolution when compared to light microscopy. Evaluate the implications and limitations of relying primarily on electron micrographs to understand cell function.[3]Explain how advances in microscopy have contributed to our understanding of cell structure and function.[4]Discuss the evidence for and against the idea that prokaryotic cells are “simple” compared to eukaryotic cells.[8]
list.markScheme: anythreeof the following,must include at leastoneimplication andonelimitationImplications→\ce{ -> }​fine detail resolution has led to a more detailed understanding of structure-function relationships[1]→\ce{ -> }​discovery of new organelles and structures[1]Limitations→\ce{ -> }​requires complex sample preparation[1]→\ce{ -> }​sample preparation can leave artefacts[1]→\ce{ -> }​samples must be fixed, dead, meaning no dynamic cellular processes can be observed[1]→\ce{ -> }​pigmentation or colour is not detected[1]→\ce{ -> }​maximum understanding comes from combining information from both light and electron microscopy[1][3 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Electron microscopy gives us verydetailed images, which let us see how the tiny parts of a cell arestructured to fulfiltheirfunctions(✓\checkmark✓). It has also led to the discovery ofnew things insidecells (✓\checkmark✓). Unfortunately, toprepare specimensfor electron microscopy, they must be treated in such a way that they arekilled, and so wecannot observe processeshappening in real time (✓\checkmark✓).anyfourof the following:→\ce{ -> }​light microscopy allowed for the initial visualisation of cells and basic structures[1]→\ce{ -> }​staining techniques have enhanced the visibility of cell components[1]→\ce{ -> }​fluorescence microscopy enables visualisation and localisation of specific molecules[1]→\ce{ -> }​live-imaging techniques allow dynamic processes to be observed[1]→\ce{ -> }​electron microscopy provides significantly higher resolution than light microscopy[1]→\ce{ -> }​transmission electron microscopy reveals details of the internal structure of organelles[1]→\ce{ -> }​scanning electron microscopy provides 3-D images of cell surfacesORcell shape[1][4 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Light microscopy first allowed us to seecellsand theirbasicparts (✓\checkmark✓). Later,stainingmade it easier to see these parts moreclearly(✓\checkmark✓).Fluorescencemicroscopy has allowed scientists to visualise and pinpoint thelocationsof specific molecules within cells (✓\checkmark✓).Electronmicroscopy providesfar greater resolutionthan light microscopy (✓\checkmark✓), making it possible to seeinternal structureslike mitochondria and membranes infine detail(✓\checkmark✓).anyeightof the following:In favour→\ce{ -> }​prokaryotic cells lack membrane-bound organellesORhave less compartmentalisation[1]→\ce{ -> }​prokaryotic cells have a single, circular chromosome; eukaryotic cells have multiple linear chromosomes[1]→\ce{ -> }​prokaryotic cells are generally smaller[1]→\ce{ -> }​prokaryotic cells reproduce by binary fission, which is less complex than mitosis/meiosis[1]Against→\ce{ -> }​prokaryotic cells efficiently carry out all life processes within a single cell, demonstrating functional sophistication[1]→\ce{ -> }​prokaryotic cells exhibit diverse and complex metabolic pathways[1]→\ce{ -> }​prokaryotic cells exhibit unique metabolic pathways, ie chemosynthesis[1]→\ce{ -> }​prokaryotic cells can engage in cell signaling[1]→\ce{ -> }​prokaryotic cells have highly specialised adaptations (ie flagellae)[1]→\ce{ -> }​prokaryotic cells have a high surface area to volume ratio, increasing the exchange rate with the surroundings[1]→\ce{ -> }​prokaryotic cells are structurally simpler but functionally complex[1]→\ce{ -> }​evaluation of the application of the word “simple”[1][8 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Prokaryotes are generallysmaller(✓\checkmark✓) than most eukaryotic cells, and they reproduce bybinary fission(✓\checkmark✓) instead of mitosis or meiosis. Prokaryotic cells are often called more simple than eukaryotic cells, but it is important todistinguish between structure and function(✓\checkmark✓). Prokaryotic cells may appear simple, but they still carry out all of thefunctions of life(✓\checkmark✓) and have some that are unique to prokaryotes. Although prokaryotesdo not have membrane-bound organelles(✓\checkmark✓), they still havecomplex metabolicpathways like cellular respiration and even pathways eukaryotes do not have, likechemosynthesis(✓\checkmark✓). Prokaryotes can communicate with each other viacell signallingpathways like quorum sensing (✓\checkmark✓) and also have highlyspecialised structuressuch as flagellae for motility (✓\checkmark✓). The term “simple” is an oversimplification of a superficial observation.A quality mark is awarded if each part of the question (a, b, c) is answered to earn at least half of the points available, answers do not require re-reading to be understood, and there are almost no errors and little irrelevant information.[1]

list.title: Question 293
list.content: Which characteristic isnottrue for both mitochondria and chloroplasts?A.\hspace{1em}They are present in both eukaryotes and prokaryotes.B.\hspace{1em}They are both able to self replicate.C.\hspace{1em}They are both able to synthesise proteins.D.\hspace{1em}They both contain circular DNA.
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Chloroplasts and mitochondria are present only in eukaryotes. ThereforeChoice Ais the correct answer.Mitochondria and chloroplasts are both able to self replicate (Choice B), synthesise proteins (Choice C) and contain circular DNA (Choice D).

list.title: Question 294
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:First, compare the sequences of the different organisms to the human sequence:OrganismAmino acid sequence for HBA1Number of differences from humanHumanAQVKGHGKKVADAL0 (reference)SharkPSIKAHGAKVVTAL6DuckAQIKAHGKKVAAAL3BatAQVKGHGKKVGDAL1CobraKDIIHQGEKVGKAL9Then rank the organisms by similarity in amino acid sequences for HBA1 to humans:Most similar is the bat, then the duck, then the shark, and then the one with the least similar sequence is the cobraThe correct cladogram isChoice Das it reflects this hierarchy.In real life, cobra (a reptile) and human (a mammal) are both amniotes, sharing a more recent common ancestor than either does with shark, which is a cartilaginous fish. The observed pattern in the table, where the shark appears more similar to humans than the cobra based on HBA1 sequences, is an artefact of analysing a single gene and is not reflective of the broader evolutionary relationship.Choices A, B, andCare incorrect because they do not follow the relationship order suggested by the amino acid differences in the table.

list.title: Question 295
list.content: DNA and RNA are nucleic acids that are essential to all living organisms. ATP is a type of nucleotide.Distinguish between ATP and the monomers of DNA in humans.[3]Outline the roles of the different types of RNA involved in translation.[4]Describe the structure of the DNA double helix.[8]
list.markScheme: Anythreeof the following:→\ce{ -> }​ATP contains three phosphate groupsWHEREASeach DNA nucleotide contains only one phosphate group[1]→\ce{ -> }​ATP has adenine for a nitrogenous baseWHEREASa DNA nucleotide can contain adenine, cytosine, guanine or thymine[1]→\ce{ -> }​a component of ATP is riboseWHEREASDNA nucleotides have deoxyribose instead[1]→\ce{ -> }​ATP stores energyORprovides energy,WHEREASDNA carriesORtransmits genetic information[1]→\ce{ -> }​ATP can perform its function as a single monomerWHEREASDNA can only perform its function,ORcarry genetic material as a polymer[1]→\ce{ -> }​ATP is found throughout the cellORprimarily in the cytoplasmORmitochondriaWHEREASDNA is found primarily in the nucleusORonly found in the nucleus AND mitochondria[1][3 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Both ATP and DNA molecules are nucleic acids which contain a phosphate group, a sugar and a base. The structural difference between a molecule of ATP and a molecule of DNA is that one ATP molecule containsthree phosphate groupswhereas one DNA nucleotide containsone phosphate group(✓\checkmark✓). In addition, the nitrogenous base in ATP isadeninewhereas there are four possible nitrogenous bases in one nucleotide of DNA which areadenine, cytosine, guanine and thymine(✓\checkmark✓). The functional difference is that ATPstores energy, whereas DNAcarries genetic material(✓\checkmark✓).Anyfourof the following (there must be at least one statement for each of mRNA, tRNA and rRNA to achieve maximum marks):→\ce{ -> }​mRNA carries the genetic information from DNA to the ribosome[1]→\ce{ -> }​mRNA serves as a template for protein synthesis[1]→\ce{ -> }​codons of mRNA  specify positioning of  amino acids along polypeptideORcodons guide the assembly of amino acids into a polypeptide[1]→\ce{ -> }​tRNA molecules carry amino acids to mRNAORribosome[1]→\ce{ -> }​anticodons on tRNA complementary to codons on mRNA allow amino acids to be positioned correctly along the polypeptideORanticodons bind to codons to bring corresponding amino acid to the ribosome[1]→\ce{ -> }​rRNA provides the ribosome's structural frameworkORforms ribosomes[1]→\ce{ -> }​rRNA catalyses the formation of peptide bonds between adjacent amino acids[1]→\ce{ -> }​rRNA facilitates binding of mRNA and tRNA[1]→\ce{ -> }​mRNA, tRNA, and rRNA orchestrate protein synthesis during translation[1][4 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Together, mRNA, tRNA, and rRNAorchestrate the process ofprotein synthesis(✓\checkmark✓) during translation.mRNA carriesthe geneticinformationfromDNAto theribosome(✓\checkmark✓).Codonson the mRNAspecify the positioningofamino acidsalong thepolypeptidechain  (✓\checkmark✓). EachtRNAmolecule has a specificanticodonsequence that iscomplementaryto acodonon the mRNA  (✓\checkmark✓). This base-pairing specificity allows tRNA to bring thecorresponding amino acidto thecorrect positionto form the polypeptide  (✓\checkmark✓). The rRNAcatalysesthe formation ofpeptide bondsbetween adjacent amino acids  (✓\checkmark✓).Anyeightof the following:(appropriately labelled and correctly drawn DNA segment can be used in the answer)→\ce{ -> }​each strand of DNA is a polymer of nucleotides[1]→\ce{ -> }​each strand has a sugar-phosphate backbone[1]→\ce{ -> }​four nitrogenous bases AORadenineANDTORthymineANDCORcytosineANDGORguanine[1]→\ce{ -> }​two strands are anti-parallelORparallel but in opposite directionsORone strand is in the 5’ to 3’ direction and the other strand is in the 3’ to 5’ direction[1]→\ce{ -> }​strands are twistedORright-handed and turn into a double helix with around 10 base pairs per turn[1]→\ce{ -> }​nucleotides consist of one phosphate group, one deoxyribose sugar and one nitrogenous base[1]→\ce{ -> }​phosphate group is bound to the 5’ carbon of the sugarORdeoxyriboseORpentose[1]→\ce{ -> }​phosphate group is bound to the 3’ carbon OH group of deoxyribose (of the next nucleotide)[1]→\ce{ -> }​covalentORphosphodiester bond between phosphate and the sugar[1]→\ce{ -> }​nitrogenous baseORbase is bound to the 1’ carbon of the sugarORdeoxyriboseORpentose sugar[1]→\ce{ -> }​covalent bond between nitrogenous base and deoxyriboseORsugarORpentose sugar[1]→\ce{ -> }​two strands are held together by hydrogen bonds between nitrogen bases of two nucleotidesOR3 hydrogen bonds between guanine and cytosineOR2 hydrogen bonds between adenine and thymine[1]→\ce{ -> }​complementary base pairing between nitrogenous bases[1]→\ce{ -> }​A pairs up with T AND C pairs up with G[1][8 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:DNA is a nucleic acid, also known as apolymer of nucleotides(✓\checkmark✓) . Many nucleotides are joined together to form it.One nucleotideconsists of three parts; aphosphate group, deoxyribose sugar and a nitrogenous base(✓\checkmark✓).One end of thephosphate groupis bonded to the5’ carbonof thedeoxyribose sugar(✓\checkmark✓). On the other side of the nucleotide,the phosphate group is bonded to the 3’ carbon sugar(✓\checkmark✓) of another nucleotide. Both bonds are covalentphosphodiester bonds(✓\checkmark✓). Repeated alternating sugar-phosphate bonds form thesugar-phosphate backbone(✓\checkmark✓).  The1’ carbon of the sugar is covalently bonded to the nitrogenous base(✓\checkmark✓) also through a condensation reaction to make up one complete nucleotide.DNA is a double helix(✓\checkmark✓) in which nitrogenous bases form the centre of the structure, andboth strands are held together by hydrogen bonds(✓\checkmark✓) between the complementary bases from each strand.Apairs upwith T, andCalways pairs upwith G(✓\checkmark✓).A quality mark is awarded if each part of the question (a, b, c) is answered to earn at least half of the points available, answers do not require re-reading to be understood, and there are almost no errors and little irrelevant information.[1]

list.title: Question 296
list.content: DNA and RNA are nucleic acids that are essential to all living organisms.Draw and label a diagram of a nucleotide.[4]Explain how the variation in base sequences leads to the ability of DNA to have an enormous capacity for storing genetic information.[4]DNA is a polymer of nucleotides. Describe the structure of DNA.[7]
list.markScheme:
the following:→\ce{ -> }​phosphate group drawn as a circle in correct place.[1]→\ce{ -> }​ribose sugar drawn as a pentagon in correct place[1]→\ce{ -> }​nitrogenous base drawn as a rectangle in correct place[1]→\ce{ -> }​all three parts labelled correctly[1]Bonds and names of nitrogenous bases do not need to be labelled[4 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9150aae9-afb7-4f8c-ad8a-a689af882f11/images/e2a45c02-e188-4e34-a535-699a939168c7/BI1047.png)

[© Revision village 2022]anyfourof the following (there must be at least one similarity and one difference given to gain full marks):→\ce{ -> }​genetic code is stored in the sequence of nitrogenous bases[1]→\ce{ -> }​three basesORa codon, codes for one amino acid[1]→\ce{ -> }​64 codons but only 20 amino acidsORdegenerate code[1]→\ce{ -> }​complementary base pairing[1]→\ce{ -> }​for each extra nucleotide along a DNA strand, the number of possible combinations of bases increases exponentially[1]→\ce{ -> }​mutations introduce new genetic information[1]→\ce{ -> }​certain sequences are conserved across species because they encode vital information[1]→\ce{ -> }​DNA molecules can be hundreds of millions of base pairs longORDNA molecules are very long[1]→\ce{ -> }​non-coding regions have regulatory functions, contributing to the complexity of gene expression and overall genetic information[1][4 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:The genetic code resides within thesequencesof nitrogenousbases(✓\checkmark✓) along a DNA molecule. Amino acids are coded for bycodons(✓\checkmark✓), and the code isdegenerate(✓\checkmark✓), in other words, some amino acids are coded for by more than one codon. The longer the DNA molecule, the greater the number of possible combinations of bases along the DNA strand, in fact there is anexponential increasein possibilities (✓\checkmark✓) for each single nucleotide added to the polymer.Mutationsalso add to the variety (✓\checkmark✓) of the genetic code.anysevenof the following:(appropriately labelled and correctly drawn DNA segment can be used in the answer)→\ce{ -> }​DNA is a double helix[1]→\ce{ -> }​two strands are anti-parallelORparallel but in opposite directionsORone strand is in the 5’ to 3’ direction and the other strand is in the 3’ to 5’ direction[1]→\ce{ -> }​strands are twistedORright-handed and turn into a double helix with around 10 base pairs per turn[1]→\ce{ -> }​nucleotides consist of one phosphate group, one deoxyribose sugar and one nitrogenous base[1]→\ce{ -> }​phosphate group is bound to the 5’ carbon of the sugar OR deoxyriboseORpentose[1]→\ce{ -> }​phosphate group is bound to the 3’ carbon OH group of deoxyribose (of the next nucleotide)[1]→\ce{ -> }​covalentORphosphodiester bond between phosphate and the sugar[1]→\ce{ -> }​nitrogenous baseORbase is bound to the 1’ carbon of the sugarORdeoxyriboseORpentose sugar[1]→\ce{ -> }​covalent bond between nitrogenous base and deoxyriboseORsugarORpentose sugar[1]→\ce{ -> }​two strands are held together by hydrogen bonds between nitrogen bases of two nucleotidesOR3 hydrogen bonds between guanine and cytosineOR2 hydrogen bonds between adenine and thymine[1]→\ce{ -> }​A pairs up with TANDC pairs up with G[1][7 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:DNA is a nucleic acid, also known as a polymer of nucleotides. Many nucleotides are joined together to form it.One nucleotideconsists of three parts; aphosphate group, deoxyribose sugar and a nitrogenous base(✓\checkmark✓).One end of the phosphate group is bonded to the 5’ carbon of the sugar(✓\checkmark✓) through a condensation reaction. On the other side of the nucleotide,the phosphate group is bonded to the 3’ carbon sugar(✓\checkmark✓) of another nucleotide through a condensation reaction. Both bonds arecovalent bonds(✓\checkmark✓). Repeated alternating sugar-phosphate bonds form the sugar-phosphate backbone.  The1’ carbon of the sugar is covalently bonded to the nitrogenous base(✓\checkmark✓)also through a condensation reaction to make up one complete nucleotide.DNA is a double helix(✓\checkmark✓) in which nitrogenous bases form the centre of the structure, andboth strands are held together by hydrogen bonds(✓\checkmark✓) between the complementary bases from each strand.A pairs up with T, and C always pairs up with G(✓\checkmark✓).A quality mark is awarded if each part of the question (a, b, c) is answered to earn at least half of the points available, answers do not require re-reading to be understood, and there are almost no errors and little irrelevant information.[1]

list.title: Question 297
list.content: Outline how reproductive isolation can result in changes in allele frequencies between populations.[3]Compare and contrast spermatogenesis and oogenesis.[5]Outline how muscle contraction is brought about according to the sliding filament model.[7]
list.markScheme: anythreeof the following:→\ce{ -> }​allopatric speciation is caused by geographical isolation and, therefore reproductive isolation[1]→\ce{ -> }​sympatric speciation takes place in the same habitat due to different nichesORdifferences in feeding behaviourORbehavioural differencesORcourtship differences[1]→\ce{ -> }​both processes lead to isolation of populations[1]→\ce{ -> }​genetic variation occurs due to genetic driftORmutation[1]→\ce{ -> }​reproductive isolation prevents or limits gene flow between populations[1]→\ce{ -> }​leads to changes in allele frequencies within those populations[1]→\ce{ -> }​over time this leads to formation of a new species due to inability to breed with the original population of the species[1][3 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Geographic isolation, such as that caused by tectonic plate movement, can lead toisolationof apopulation(✓\checkmark✓).Reproductive isolation preventsor limitsgene flow(✓\checkmark✓) between populations of the same species.Thisleadstochangesinallele frequencieswithin those populations, andover timecould lead to theformationof anew species(✓\checkmark✓) due to its inability to breed with the original population that it separated from.anyfiveof the following: (at least one from each):Similarities→\ce{ -> }​BOTHproduce haploid cellsORnuclei[1]→\ce{ -> }​BOTHinvolve meiosis[1]→\ce{ -> }​BOTHoccur in reproductive organs[1]→\ce{ -> }​BOTHinvolve maturation of immature germ cells[1]Differences→\ce{ -> }​spermatogenesis occurs in testesWHEREASoogenesis occurs in the ovaries[1]→\ce{ -> }​spermatogenesis produces many gametesWHEREASoogenesis produces one gamete per month or cycle[1]→\ce{ -> }​spermatogenesis producesORresults in four mature sperms from one precursor cell ( and no polar bodies)WHEREASoogenesis produces one mature egg from the precursor cell, (the other cells forming polar bodies)ORspermatogenesis involves mitotic and meiotic divisionsWHEREASoogenesis involves meiotic divisions with uneven cytokinesis[1]→\ce{ -> }​spermatogenesis starts at pubertyWHEREASoogenesis begins during fetal development[1]→\ce{ -> }​spermatogenesis continues through adult lifeWHEREASoogenesis stops at menopause[1][5 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Bothspermatogenesisandoogenesistake place inreproductive organs(✓\checkmark✓), howeverspermatogenesisoccurs in thetestesof biologically male animals  whereasoogenesisoccurs in theovariesof biologically female animals (✓\checkmark✓).Bothprocessesproduce haploid cells(✓\checkmark✓) via the process ofmeiosis(✓\checkmark✓). Whilespermatogenesisproducesfour mature spermsfrom oneprecursor cell,oogenesisproducesone mature egg(✓\checkmark✓) from the precursor cell, the other cells becoming polar bodies.Spermatogenesis continuesthroughoutadult lifein the biological male, whereasoogenesis stopsatmenopause(✓\checkmark✓) in biological females.Spermatogenesisproducesmany gametes, whereasoogenesisproducesone gamete per month(✓\checkmark✓).anysevenof the following:→\ce{ -> }​muscle fibres consist of myofibrils made up of myosinANDactinANDtroponinANDtropomyosin protein[1]→\ce{ -> }​tropomyosin winds around actin filaments covering binding sites for myosin heads[1]→\ce{ -> }​action potential passes along cell membrane of muscle fibreORsarcolemmaORdown T-tubules[1]→\ce{ -> }​causes release of calcium ionsORCa2+from sarcoplasmic reticulum[1]→\ce{ -> }​Ca2+bind troponin protein on the actin filaments causing a conformational change[1]→\ce{ -> }​change lifts tropomyosin away for myosin binding sites on actinORleads to a change in the tropomyosin protein on the actin filament exposing sites to which myosin can bind[1]→\ce{ -> }​myosin head binds to actin forming cross bridges[1]→\ce{ -> }​inorganic phosphateORPi released from myosin head and  myosin head changes angle, pulling actin filament alongORleading to power stroke[1]→\ce{ -> }​‘power stroke’ORmovement of myosin head shortens the sarcomere leading to a muscle contraction[1]→\ce{ -> }​ADP is released from myosin head, allowing ATP to bind[1]→\ce{ -> }​causes cross-bridge to breakORcause myosin head to release actin[1]→\ce{ -> }​hydrolysis of ATP releases energy to return myosin head to original positionORto ‘re-cock’ head[1]→\ce{ -> }​titin stabilises the sarcomere by anchoring myosin to the Z-lineORprovides elasticityORhelps the sarcomere return to its resting length after contraction[1][7 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Muscle fibres consist ofmyofibrilsmade up of thick filaments containingmyosin, and thin filaments made up ofactin, tropomyosinandtroponin(✓\checkmark✓).An action potentialtravelling along the sarcolemma causes therelease of calcium ionsfrom thesarcoplasmic reticulum. The calcium ions bind to troponin, which causes aconformational change(✓\checkmark✓), lifting thetropomyosinand, exposingsitesto whichmyosincanbind(✓\checkmark✓). Thebindingof the myosin head to the actin causes therelease of inorganic phosphate, and thechangein theangleof themyosin head, pulling the actin filament along (✓\checkmark✓).ADP is releasedfrom the myosin head, which allowsATPtobindto the myosin in its place (✓\checkmark✓), causing thecross-bridgebetween the actin and myosin tobreak(✓\checkmark✓). TheATPmolecule is thenhydrolysedto ADP and Pi,releasingtheenergyneeded for themyosinhead to return to itsoriginal position(✓\checkmark✓).  It is now ready for the whole process to occur again.For additional detail‾\underline{\textrm{For additional detail}}For additional detail​: , see 6:00 in Muscle and Motility II Key Concept Video:https://www.revisionvillage.com/ib-biology/hl/key-concepts/?keyConceptId=6ed962e4-ed05-44fc-b4e4-c0ff93db627fA quality mark is awarded if each part of the question (a, b, c) is answered to earn at least half of the points available, answers do not require re-reading to be understood, and there are almost no errors and little irrelevant information.[1]

list.title: Question 298
list.content: Describe how the primordial soup hypothesis (an aqueous mix of simple organic molecules) explains the origin of carbon compounds on Earth.[3]Mitochondria are organelles that are thought to have evolved from early prokaryotes. Discuss whether mitochondria can be considered living or nonliving.[4]Discuss the evidence and limitations for the existence of a last universal common ancestor.[8]
list.markScheme: Anythreeof the following:→\ce{ -> }​early atmosphereORoceans contained a mixture of gasesORcarbon dioxide AND methaneORwater vapourORammoniaORhydrogen gas[1]→\ce{ -> }​high levels of UVORultraviolet lightORelectrical dischargesORlightning catalysed reactions in these gases[1]→\ce{ -> }​the gases broke down into smaller, highly reactive components[1]→\ce{ -> }​the smaller components reacted to form larger carbon compoundsORmore complex organic molecules[1]→\ce{ -> }​abiogenesisORchemical evolution[1]→\ce{ -> }​in waterORpoolsORoceans[1][3 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:The primordial soup hypothesis states that billions of years ago, there were muchhigher levels of UV lighton Earth whichcatalysedreactions in thegasesof the early atmosphere (✓\checkmark✓). The UV radiationbroke downinorganic molecules intosmaller, highly reactivecomponents (✓\checkmark✓). The smaller, highly reactive components reacted toform larger carbon compounds(✓\checkmark✓).Anyfourof the following:Answers must include at least one argument for living and one argument for non-living to gain full marksLiving because…→\ce{ -> }​they can replicate independently of the host cellORcarry our binary fission[1]→\ce{ -> }​they contain their own ribosomes to make their own proteins[1]→\ce{ -> }​they contain their own DNAORgenetic material[1]→\ce{ -> }​they can make their own ATPORrelease energy from organic moleculesORcarry out a series of metabolic reactions independent of the host cell[1]→\ce{ -> }​they have their own membranes[1]→\ce{ -> }​they can grow larger[1]→\ce{ -> }​they can excrete wasteORcarbon dioxide[1]Non-living because…→\ce{ -> }​they cannot survive independently outside of a host cell[1]→\ce{ -> }​the majority of proteins needed for mitochondrial function are synthesised in the host cell[1]→\ce{ -> }​they do not regulate homeostasis independently of the host cell[1]→\ce{ -> }​they cannot respond to stimuliORadapt to changing environments[1][4 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Mitochondria can be thought of as non-living because theycannot survive independentlyoutside the host cell (✓\checkmark✓) and the majority ofproteinsneeded for mitochondrial function aremade in the host cell(✓\checkmark✓). However, it could be argued that they are living as they carry out several life processes, such asreproduction, independentlyof the host cell (✓\checkmark✓), and contain their ownribosomeswhich they use tomaketheir ownproteins(✓\checkmark✓).Anyeightof the following:Answers must include at least one argument in support of a last universal common ancestor (LUCA) and at least one gap in the evidence to gain full marksEvidence that exists for the existence of a last universal common ancestor→\ce{ -> }​universal genetic codeORall organisms have the same nucleotide basesORgenetic code[1]→\ce{ -> }​conserved molecular structuresORall organisms have the same degenerate amino acid codeORthe same codons code for the same amino acids in all organismsORthere are highly conserved DNA sequences that are common across many domains of life[1]→\ce{ -> }​genomic analysis of fossils shows that there are many similarities in the DNA sequences between modern and extinct organisms[1]→\ce{ -> }​specific proteins produced by different organisms can be used interchangeably between species without any major side effects[1]→\ce{ -> }​all organisms have a similar process for gene transcription and protein synthesisORtranscription and translation[1]→\ce{ -> }​mutations in DNAORamino acid sequences can be tracked over time and used as a ‘molecular clock’ to estimate the age of the last universal common ancestor[1]Gaps in the evidence for the existence of a last universal common ancestor→\ce{ -> }​incomplete fossil record makes it difficult to link all species together anatomically[1]→\ce{ -> }​very early organisms were unicellularORmade of soft tissues that do not readily fossilise[1]→\ce{ -> }​lack of direct fossil evidence for the last universal common ancestor[1]→\ce{ -> }​the last universal common ancestor does not exist today[1][8 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:The last universal common ancestor (LUCA) is proposed to be the evolutionary link between the abiotic phase of Earth’s history and the biotic phase. It is the last ancestor that links all biological life on Earth. Evidence for the LUCA’s existence comes from the fact that organisms are all biochemically similar; they share thesame DNA bases(✓\checkmark✓). Furthermore, thesame codonscode for thesame amino acidsin all organisms (✓\checkmark✓), and all organisms have a similar process forgene transcription and protein synthesis(✓\checkmark✓). Also, there are somehighly conserved sequencesacross the majority of organisms such asribosomal RNAwhich is common across all domains of life (✓\checkmark✓).Genomic analysisof fossils also shows that there are many similar DNA sequences betweenextinct and modern organisms(✓\checkmark✓). However, thereisn’tacomplete fossil recordwhich makes it difficult to link all species anatomically (✓\checkmark✓), there isno direct fossil evidencefor the existence of the LUCA (✓\checkmark✓) and the LUCA doesnot existon Earthtoday(✓\checkmark✓).

list.title: Question 299
list.content: A researcher labelled two different proteins with molecules that emit light of distinct colours when illuminated with a specific wavelength of light. To determine if these proteins are present in the same location in the cell, which type of microscopy would be most appropriate?A.\hspace{1em}Bright field microscopyB.\hspace{1em}Scanning electron microscopyC.\hspace{1em}Fluorescence microscopyD.\hspace{1em}Transmission electron microscopy
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Fluorescence microscopy uses specific wavelengths of light to excite fluorescent molecules, the labels, causing them to emit light at different wavelengths. Using appropriate filters, the light emitted from each can be detected to determine their locations. Therefore,Choice Cis correct.Bright field microscopy is the term used to describe a common light microscopy technique where specimens appear dark against a bright background due to the direct transmission of light through the sample. Bright field microscopy would not be able to excite specific fluorescent molecules or distinguish between particular wavelengths of light, soChoice Ais incorrect.Scanning electron microscopy uses a stream of electrons to produce an image of the surface of an organism and does not use or detect any wavelength of light, soChoice Bis incorrect.Transmission electron microscopy passes a stream of electrons through a thin specimen to visualise internal structures and does not use or detect any wavelength of light, soChoice Dis incorrect.

list.content:

list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The diameter of the cell is the total length, along the widest part of the cell; 3.5 cm. When the scale bar, which represents 10 µm, is measured, it is shown to be 1 cm long in the image. 3.5 multiplied by 10 is 35 µm.Choice Dis correct.Choices A, BandCare incorrect.

list.title: Question 302
list.content:
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/baf04dcc-f4a0-48d2-9a7d-1963add3cf0c/images/19006f6d-bdf7-40b0-a6de-aa5d19c784ed/BI1850.png)

[© Revision Village 2024. Created with BioRender.com]Describe the role of DNA in storing genetic information.[2]Outline the importance of the antiparallel arrangement of DNA strands in the structure of DNA.[3]Outline the importance of the diversity of DNA base sequences in the process of evolution.[3]Discuss the importance of the conservation of the genetic code in understanding universal common ancestry.[2]
list.markScheme: Anytwoof the following:→\ce{ -> }​genetic code is stored in the sequence of nucleotide basesORadenine, thymine, cytosine, guanine	 within the DNA molecule[1]→\ce{ -> }​groups of three nucleotidesORbases form codons, which correspond to specific amino acids[1]→\ce{ -> }​sequence of codons determines the primary structure of proteins, which controls the organism’s traits and functions[1]→\ce{ -> }​double-helix structure ensures stability of genetic information and allows for accurate replication during cell division[1]→\ce{ -> }​genetic code is degenerateORmultiple codons can code for same amino acid providing some protection against mutations[1]→\ce{ -> }​genes can be turned on or offORare used when neededORcan be expressed and repressed[1][2 mark maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:DNA stores genetic information in the form ofcodons, which aresequencesofthree nucleotide bases(✓\checkmark✓) thatcodefor specificamino acids(✓\checkmark✓). These codonsdeterminethestructure of proteins, which are essential for theorganism’s traitsandfunctions(✓\checkmark✓).Anythreeof the following:→\ce{ -> }​two DNA strands run in opposite directionsORone strand runs 5' to 3', while the other runs 3' to 5'[1]→\ce{ -> }​allows the complementary base pairsORadenine-thymine AND guanine-cytosine to align properly and form hydrogen bonds[1]→\ce{ -> }​hydrogen bonding stabilises the double helix[1]→\ce{ -> }​antiparallel strands allow for the twisting of the DNA molecule[1]→\ce{ -> }​ensures that the DNA molecule is stable and can store genetic information effectively[1][3 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:The antiparallel arrangement means thatone DNA strandruns5' to 3', while theother runs 3' to 5'(✓\checkmark✓). This allows thecomplementary base pairstoaligncorrectly and formhydrogen bondsbetween adenine-thymine and guanine-cytosine (✓\checkmark✓). Thesehydrogen bondshelpstabilisethedouble helixand allow theDNA to twistinto its characteristic structure (✓\checkmark✓).Anythreeof the following:→\ce{ -> }​leads to genetic variation between individuals within a population[1]→\ce{ -> }​provides the basis for natural selection, as certain traits may offer a selective advantage in specific environments[1]→\ce{ -> }​Individuals with advantageous traits are more likely to survive and reproduce, passing their favourable allelesORgenes to the next generation[1]→\ce{ -> }​over time, advantageous traits become more common, driving evolution and the development of new species[1]→\ce{ -> }​allows populations to adapt to changing environments, contributing to species' survival[1][3 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:The diversity of DNA base sequences leads togenetic variationbetweenindividualsin apopulation(✓\checkmark✓). This variation provides the basis fornatural selection, wherecertain traitsoffer a selectiveadvantageinspecific environments(✓\checkmark✓). Over time,individualswithadvantageous traitsaremore likelytosurvive, reproduce, andpass ontheirfavourable genes(✓\checkmark✓), driving the process of evolution and the development of new species.Anytwoof the following:→\ce{ -> }​genetic code is nearly universal across all living organismsORthere are only a few minor variations in the genetic code observed in certain species[1]→\ce{ -> }​in nearly all organisms the same triplet codons specify the same amino acids[1]→\ce{ -> }​universality of the genetic code implies a shared ancestral origin for all organisms[1]→\ce{ -> }​used in phylogenetic analysis to reconstruct evolutionary relationships, providing strong evidence for universal common ancestry[1]→\ce{ -> }​conservation of the genetic code helps maintain the integrity of proteinsORreduces  risk of mutations that could disrupt essential cellular functions[1]→\ce{ -> }​despite evolutionary changes in species, the genetic code remains largely unchanged over time[1][2 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:The conservation of the genetic code across all organisms suggests that all life shares a common ancestor, as thesame triplet codonsspecify thesame amino acidsinall species(✓\checkmark✓). This universality indicates that thegenetic codehas beenpassed downthroughgenerationswithlittle change(✓\checkmark✓), providing evidence for universal common ancestry.

Only the mitochondria and chloroplasts' origin are explained by endosymbiotic theory.

The electron micrograph shows a sarcomere, the smallest functional unit of striated muscle tissue. What is the actual length between the two Z lines?

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/c4757206-7907-4040-94a2-08079ed88b94/images/b762a3a8-46a3-4d64-a154-328e5b7831c2/BI0562i.png)

[Source: Adapted from Loison, O., Weitkunat , M., Kaya-Çopur , A., Nascimento Alves, C., Matzat , T., & Spletter , M. L. (2018).Category: sarcomeres. Wikimedia Commons. Retrieved March 5, 2023, from https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/CategoryCopyright under CC BY 3.0][Ruler tool, cm]A.\hspace{1em}10 µmB.\hspace{1em}1 mmC.\hspace{1em}1 cmD.\hspace{1em}1 µm
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The length between the two Z lines is 4.5 cm, which is equivalent to 45000 µm. Actual length is calculated using the equation; image size divided by magnification. 45000 µm ÷ 45000 x = 1 µm.Choice Dis correct.Choices A, BandCare incorrect.

list.title: Question 305
list.content: What is adaptive radiation?A.\hspace{1em}When a new species is produced through natural selectionB.\hspace{1em}When new ecological niches are exploited, resulting in speciationC.\hspace{1em}When a species moves to a new location and adapts to new conditionsD.\hspace{1em}When speciation occurs, and analogous traits remain
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Bis correct because adaptive radiation refers to the rapid diversification and speciation of a single ancestral species into multiple descendent species, taking advantage of different niches within a community.Choice Ais incorrect as natural selection refers to organisms with advantageous traits having a greater chance of survival and so a greater chance to reproduce and pass on those traits to future generations within that population, leading to the evolution of species over time.Choice Cis incorrect as it refers to the phenomenon where an organism changes in response to new environmental conditions through natural selection and random mutations, while adaptive radiation involves the rapid evolution of more than one species from a single ancestral species.Choice Dis incorrect, as analogous traits do not result from common ancestry.

list.title: Question 306
list.content: The black-throated loon (Gavia arctica) is a bird that lives near large bodies of water in cold climates.  Which of the following is a correct description of how the properties of water may make winter temperatures more moderate for the black-throated loon?A.\hspace{1em}Water has a relatively high specific heat capacity which buffers the environmental temperature.B.\hspace{1em}Ice floats on water so insulates the liquid water beneath the ice.C.\hspace{1em}Water has a low specific heat capacity which warms the surrounding air.D.\hspace{1em}Water is dense which enables the black-throated loon to float.
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Ais correct because water’s ability to absorb and store a significant amount of heat without undergoing large temperature changes provides thermal cushioning.  In summer water absorbs heat energy and then in winter this heat energy is lost to the surrounding air helping to create milder microclimates. This enables the black-throated loon to inhabit areas where temperature might otherwise be too extreme.Choice Bis incorrect because it does not explain how winter air temperatures are made more moderate, only that ice insulates water that is below it which is not where the black-throated loon lives.Choice Cis incorrect because water does not have a low specific heat capacity.Choice Dis incorrect because, although it is a true statement, it does not explain how winter temperatures are made more moderate.

list.title: Question 307
list.content: Which property describes water’s ability to associate with a wide range of other compounds, and how did this property help retain water on early Earth before the emergence of life?Property of waterHow did this property help retain water on Earth?A.\hspace{1em}High heat capacityMinimised temperature fluctuations that would evaporate waterB.\hspace{1em}Universal solventAllowed a wide range of condensation reactions to occur, so water is trapped in biological polymersC.\hspace{1em}PolarityAllowed water to interact with minerals so that it is stored in hydrated rocksD.\hspace{1em}Low densityPrevented water from sinking through the surface of the Earth into the mantle
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Water is a polar molecule, meaning it has partial positive and negative charges. This polarity allows water to form chemical bonds with rock-forming minerals, leading to hydrated compounds such as gypsum (CaSOX4⋅HX2O\ce{CaSO_4.H_2O}CaSOX4​⋅HX2​O) and hydrated feldspars. These minerals incorporate water into their crystal structures (known as water of crystallisation), helping retain water in the Earth's crust before the appearance of life;Choice Cis correct.High heat capacity refers to water’s ability to store heat without large temperature changes, which helps to regulate Earth’s climate, but doesn’t explain why water is retained on Earth;Choice Ais incorrect.Water is described as a universal solvent as it can dissolve a wide range of substances; however, while water is required for condensation reactions, the process of condensation does not trap water in a manner that would keep it on Earth. Also, biological polymers did not exist until after life emerged.Choice Bis incorrect.If water had entered the mantle, the heat there would cause it to evaporate instantly, and therefore, water would not be retained on Earth. Water's ability to sink into the mantle would be due to rock porosity and cracks, not its density;Choice Dis incorrect.

list.title: Question 308
list.content: Environmental DNA can be used to form which of the following?A.\hspace{1em}BarcodesB.\hspace{1em}KaryotypesC.\hspace{1em}Dichotomous keysD.\hspace{1em}Binomial naming system
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Ais correct because environmental DNA is genetic material shed by organisms into their environment and can be used to produce barcodes for each species.Choice Cis incorrect because environmental DNA does not directly lend itself to the construction of dichotomous keys, as these keys are usually based on observable physical characteristics rather than genetic material.Choice Dis incorrect as while eDNA analysis can help identify species, it doesn't play a direct role in assigning scientific names, so is not used as the basis for the binomial naming system.Choice Bis incorrect, as environmental DNA does not provide enough detailed information about individual chromosomes to construct karyotypes.

[Source: Adapted from User: Madprime. (2010, March).File: DNA chemical structure jp.svg.Wikimedia Commons. Retrieved May 15, 2022, from https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File: DNA_chemical_structure_jp.svg. Copyright under CC-SA 3.0]Suggestonepossible problem that could arise if DNA consisted of two parallel strands instead of two antiparallel strands.[1]State one place where DNA is found in cells.[1]Compare and contrast the structure of DNA and RNA.[5]
list.markScheme: Anyoneof the following:→\ce{ -> }​no hydrogen bonding between base pairs[1]→\ce{ -> }​two strands are not held togetherORno double-stranded DNA[1]→\ce{ -> }​two strands would be geometrically the same, thus unable to combine[1][1 mark maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:If DNA were made of two parallel strands, both strands would be oriented in the same 3’ to 5’ direction. Since the DNA strand is tilted and not straight, that would mean that two DNA strandswould not be able to combine(✓\checkmark✓) to form a double helix.\hspace{1em}→\ce{ -> }​nucleusORnucleoidORmitochondriaORchloroplastsORplasmids[1][1 mark maximum]\hspace{1em}Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:\hspace{1em}One place where DNA is found in the cell is in thenucleus(✓\checkmark✓).Anyfiveof the following (there must be at leastonesimilarity andonedifference given to gain full marks):Similarities:→\ce{ -> }​BOTHDNA and RNA are composed of nucleotidesORsugar, phosphateANDbase[1]→\ce{ -> }​BOTHDNA and RNA contain four types of nitrogenous bases[1]→\ce{ -> }​BOTHDNA and RNA have covalent bonds holding nucleotides together[1]→\ce{ -> }​BOTHDNA and RNA exhibit base pairingORcomplementary bases are connected through hydrogen bondsORhave hydrogen bonds between the complementary nitrogenous bases[1]→\ce{ -> }​BOTHDNA and RNA have a backbone made up of alternating sugar and phosphate groups[1]→\ce{ -> }​BOTHDNA and RNA are polymers, composed of repeating monomer unitsORnucleotides, linked together in a chain[1]Differences:→\ce{ -> }​DNA contains deoxyribose sugarWHEREASRNA contains ribose[1]→\ce{ -> }​DNA contains the nitrogenous bases adenine, thymine, cytosine and  guanineORATCGWHEREASRNA contains adenine, uracil, cytosine and guanineORAUCG,ORin DNA adenine pairs with thymine and cytosine pairs with guanineWHEREASin RNA adenine pairs with uracil and cytosine pairs with guanine[1]→\ce{ -> }​DNA typically consists of two (antiparallel) strandsWHEREASRNA is usually single-stranded[1]→\ce{ -> }​in DNA adenine pairs with thymine and cytosine pairs with guanineWHEREASin RNA adenine pairs with uracil and cytosine pairs with guanine[1]→\ce{ -> }​DNA typically forms a double-stranded helical structure with base pairing between the two strandsWHEREASRNA can fold into complex secondary structures due to intra-strand base pairing, creating loops, stems, and hairpin structures[1][5 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Both DNA and RNA are made up ofnucleotides(✓\checkmark✓), however, the sugar in DNA isdeoxyribose, whilst that in RNA isribose(✓\checkmark✓). Both DNA and RNA containfourdifferentnitrogenous bases(✓\checkmark✓), however, DNA contains adenine, guanine, cytosine and thymine, whilst RNA containsuracil instead of thymine(✓\checkmark✓). Both DNA and RNA arepolymersof nucleotides (✓\checkmark✓) held together bycovalent bonds(✓\checkmark✓) between the sugar of one nucleotide and a phosphate group of the next, however, DNA is typicallydouble-stranded, and RNA is typicallysingle-stranded(✓\checkmark✓).

list.title: Question 310
list.content: Which of the following highlight(s) difficulties in applying the biological species concept?I.Budding in yeastII.Runners in spider plantsIII.Bacterial conjugationA.\hspace{1em}III onlyB.\hspace{1em}I and II onlyC.\hspace{1em}I and III onlyD.\hspace{1em}I, II and III
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Dis correct because all statements are examples of either asexual reproduction (Statements I and II) or horizontal gene transfer (Statement III), which makes applying the biological species concept difficult. The biological species concept defines a species as a group of organisms that can interbreed and produce fertile offspring under natural conditions. This concept is formulated for sexual reproduction, not asexual or horizontal genetic transfer.

list.title: Question 311
list.content:
Below is a diagram of swan necked flasks, containing boiled broth, which are similar to those used by Pasteur in his experiments on spontaneous generation. The air access and neck shape differ between them.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/fa7cb3ca-ef45-4a81-8a5f-53a77f8d6f8a/images/ce69f2c0-818b-4b45-9d4a-985c0ab6ed48/BI1444%20fig1.png)

[©Revision Village 2024. Created with BioRender.com]How did Pasteur's experiments with swan-necked flasks provide convincing evidence to falsify the concept of spontaneous generation?I.\hspace{1em}Broth in flask X grew cloudy due to dust and microbes being trapped in the neck, suggesting that even filtered air can induce microbial growth.II.\hspace{.7em}Broth in flask Y remained clear, indicating no spontaneous microbial growth, as the sealed environment prevented any external contamination.III.\hspace{.4em}Broth in flask Z remained clear, proving that exposure to air alone does not lead to microbial growth.A.\hspace{1em}I onlyB.\hspace{1em}II onlyC.\hspace{1em}I and II onlyD.\hspace{1em}I, II and III
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Statement I is not true. In Pasteur's experiment, the broth in flask X, which had a swan neck, remained clear because the swan neck prevented dust and airborne microbes from reaching the broth while still allowing air to pass through. The dust and microbes were trapped in the bends of the swan neck and did not contaminate the broth.Statement II is true. Flask Y was sterilised and then sealed. The absence of microbial growth in this sealed environment supports the idea that microorganisms are not spontaneously generated from the broth but must be introduced from an external source.Statement III is not true. Pasteur's experiment showed that microbial growth occurred when the swan neck of flask Z was broken off, exposing the previously sterilised broth to the air without any barrier. This demonstrated that microorganisms in the air were responsible for the growth in the broth, not spontaneous generation.As only Statement II is true, answer choice B is the correct answer to this question.

list.title: Question 312
list.content:
The diagram shows an unidentified species of crab.

Created with BioRender.com]Use the dichotomous key provided to identify this species.1.\hspace{1em}Smooth shell … .Go to 2.Bumps or spikes on shell … .Go to 3.2.\hspace{1em}Eyestalks … .Go to 4.No eyestalks … .Menippe mercenaria.3.\hspace{1em}Pear-shaped shell … .Go to 5.Non-pear-shaped shell … .Go to 6.4.\hspace{1em}Antennae visible … .Birgus latro.No antennae visible … .Ocypode quadrata.5.\hspace{1em}Six walking legs … .Paralithodes camtschaticus.Eight walking legs … .Macrocheira kaempferi.6.\hspace{1em}Tail present … .Limulus polyphemus.Tail absent … .Callinectes sapidus.A.\hspace{1em}Menippe mercenariaB.\hspace{1em}Ocypode quadrataC.\hspace{1em}Paralithodes camtschaticusD.\hspace{1em}Callinectes sapidus
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Dis correct because this species has a rough, non-pear-shaped shell and no tail, making it a blue crab (Callinectes sapidus).Choices Ais incorrect because the species in the diagram has eyestalks and a rough shell.Choice Bis incorrect because the species in the diagram has a rough shell.Choice Cis incorrect because the species in the diagram has a non-pear-shaped shell.

list.title: Question 313
list.content: Enzymes are needed to replicate and transcribe DNA. Ribosomes are needed to translate the DNA into enzymes. According to the “RNA world” hypothesis, what problem does this present for the first lifeforms to evolve on Earth?A.\hspace{1em}Early life forms could not catalyse reactions.B.\hspace{1em}Early life forms could not self-replicate.C.\hspace{1em}Early life forms were unable to produce proteins.D.\hspace{1em}Early lifeforms did not have cell membranes.
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Cis correct because early life forms likely had neither ribosomes nor enzymes and therefore could not produce proteins. The “RNA world” hypothesis suggests that early life forms were believed to have used ribozymes (RNA molecules with catalytic activity) to catalyse essential reactions.Choice Ais incorrect because the ability to catalyse metabolic reactions is thought to be a requirement for early life forms.Choice Bis incorrect because self-replication is also a basic requirement for all living things.Choice Dis incorrect because early life forms would have been unicellular, and all cells need a membrane of some kind to maintain structure and chemical gradients.

list.title: Question 314
list.content: Which of the following isNOTa true statement of allopolyploidy in plants?A.\hspace{1em}It results in an increased chance of hybrid vigour.B.\hspace{1em}Plant breeders can select varieties that are best suited to local conditions.C.\hspace{1em}It results in the duplication of chromosomes within a single species.D.\hspace{1em}It results in an Increased ability of plants to colonise new habitats.
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Allopolyploidy arises from hybridisation between two different species, followed by chromosome doubling. The key point is that it introduces a new set of chromosomes from a different species rather than simply doubling an existing diploid genome.In contrast, autopolyploidy occurs within a single species and results in an exact doubling (or higher multiple) of its own chromosome set.Choice Cis, therefore, the correct answer.Choice Ais incorrect because hybrid vigour is often a direct result of allopolyploidy. New alleles are introduced into a species, giving an immediate selective advantage to that plant species.Choice Bis incorrect because allopolyploidy allows new varieties that are well adapted to different local abiotic and biotic conditions. This characteristic can explain the widespread global cultivation of wheat (Triticum aestivum) as a staple crop.Choice Dis incorrect because the new alleles brought in from new species allow a species to compete in a territory or habitat that it had not otherwise been successful in, allowing an invasive species to outcompete the native species in many cases.

list.title: Question 315
list.content:
The pale and dark forms of the peppered moth (Biston betularia) are a classic example of natural selection. The graph shows the changes in the population of pale (mostly white) and dark (mostly black) peppered moths (Biston betularia) during and post the industrial revolution.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/06c9ef98-77c2-415f-98d2-5ce3c2d35738/images/d3574329-664b-4912-804c-f9a20dfa2636/BI1291.png)

[© Revision Village 2023]The image shows the phenotype of pale and dark moths on white tree bark.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/06c9ef98-77c2-415f-98d2-5ce3c2d35738/images/2cab37cd-63f2-45dd-b597-e0d9ac454ded/BI1291b.png)

[Source: Adapted from Bedin, T. (2020, May 26).Tilpasning og evolusjon - natural science (PB) - NDLA. ndla.no.  Retrieved October 02, 2023, from https://ndla.no/en/subject:1/topic:6/topic:3/resource:09fc6c1a-eaa1-4901-b2ae-ee5e7ce1900c. Copyright free]Distinguish between the changes in the numbers of pale and dark moths shown in the graph.[2]Outline how the trends in the graph can be explained by natural selection.[3]Suggest a technique a group of students could use to compare the population sizes of peppered moths between a deciduous (broadleaved) and a coniferous (evergreen) wood.[1]Calculate the percentage increase in dark-coloured moths between 1850 and 1900.[1]Draw a line on the graph, predicting how the number of pale moths would have changed, if the industrial revolution did not happen.[1]In addition to collecting data such as that shown in the graph, scientists rely on various forms of evidence to explore the concept of evolution. State two other forms of evidence that supports the theory of evolution.[2]
list.markScheme:
Anytwoof the following→\ce{ -> }​between 1800 and 1850ORaround the middle of the Industrial Revolution, the number of pale moths remained highORbetween 95 and 100%WHEREASthe number of dark moths remained lowORbetween 0 and 5%[1]→\ce{ -> }​from 1850, the number of pale moths began to rapidly decreaseWHEREASthe number of dark moths rapidly increased[1]→\ce{ -> }​around 1870ORjust before 1875, the number of dark moths surpasses the number of pale moths[1]→\ce{ -> }​from 1900, the number of pale moths was lowORless than 5%WHEREASthe number of dark moths was highORaround 95%[1][2 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Between1800 and 1850, the number ofpalemoths was between95 and 100%, whereas the number ofdarkmoths was between0 and 5%(✓\checkmark✓). However,from 1850the number ofpalemothsdecreasedrapidly, whereas the number ofdarkmothsincreasedrapidly (✓\checkmark✓).Anythreeof the following→\ce{ -> }​natural selection explains how individuals with advantageous traits are more likely to survive to reproduce[1]→\ce{ -> }​before the Industrial Revolution, lichensORmossesORbark on treesORbrickwork were white, so the pale moths were able to camouflage from predators[1]→\ce{ -> }​increased rates of pollutionORsoot during the Industrial Revolution caused white lichen and mosses on lichenORmossORbark on treesORbrickwork to turn black[1]→\ce{ -> }​pale moths were more visible to predators, so their numbers decreased[1]→\ce{ -> }​dark moths were able to camouflage from predators, so were better able to survive and breed[1]→\ce{ -> }​the dark moths gained a selective advantage over the pale mothsORwere selected forORare under directional selectionORpale moths faced intense selection pressure due to predation[1][3 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Before the Industrial Revolution,lichen and mosseson trees werewhite, so the pale moths were able tocamouflage from predators(✓\checkmark✓). However,post-Industrial Revolution, there were increased rates ofpollutionwhich caused trees to turnblack(✓\checkmark✓). This meant that the dark moths were able tocamouflagefrom predators, so were better able tosurvive and breed(✓\checkmark✓).→\ce{ -> }​capture-mark-release-recapture[1][1 mark maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:One technique that students could use is themark-release-recaptureofpepperedmoths (✓\checkmark✓) in coniferous and deciduous woods.Anyoneof the following:→\ce{ -> }​1800 %[1][1 mark maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/06c9ef98-77c2-415f-98d2-5ce3c2d35738/images/335ad891-c368-45e8-8155-0eaae77e5ba2/BI1291c.png)

[© Revision Village 2023]Percentage increase = ((final  value - initial value) ÷ initial value)×\times×100%Percentage increase = ((95 - 5) ÷ 5 )×\times×100%Percentage increase =1800%(✓\checkmark✓)Anyoneof the following:→\ce{ -> }​line should continue the same trend from before 1850 to 1900[1][1 mark maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/06c9ef98-77c2-415f-98d2-5ce3c2d35738/images/6b0f3bad-5b55-4b8b-a3eb-6976229dd3c3/BI1291d.png)

[© Revision Village 2023]Anytwoof the following:→\ce{ -> }​DNA sequenceORRNA  sequencing[1]→\ce{ -> }​amino acid sequence of proteins[1]→\ce{ -> }​selective breedingORartificial selection[1]→\ce{ -> }​homologous structuresORcomparative anatomyORvestigial structures[1]→\ce{ -> }​embryonic development[1]→\ce{ -> }​the fossil record[1]→\ce{ -> }​geographic distribution of species[1][2 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Thefossil record(✓\checkmark✓) andDNA sequencing(✓\checkmark✓) provide evidence for the theory of evolution.

list.title: Question 316
list.content:
The Eurasian beaver (Castor fiber) has been described as a species that promotes biodiversity. Beavers are herbivores that feed on freshwater plants and tree bark. They use their sharp front teeth to fell trees and use the logs and branches to build dams that create pools in which they can build their lodge. A beaver lodge is a construction in which they nest and raise their young, providing protection from predators.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/137391ca-319d-43a2-9119-cf4e9aa52801/images/0716c3a5-4515-4c2c-9098-2dc170bfb110/BI1684%20fig1.png)

[Source: Jerzy Strzelecki, retrieved July 2024 from https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File: Castor_fiber_07(js),_Narew_River,
_Poland.jpg, copyright under CC BY-SA 3.0]Suggest ways in which the reintroduction of beavers can increase biodiversity.[4]The effect of introducing beavers on the species diversity of birds and bats was studied in four areas: on river banks, one without any beaver activity and one where beavers are present, and then ponds, again, one without beaver activity and one where beavers were present. The graph below shows the calculated Simpson’s reciprocal index of Diversity for each area.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/137391ca-319d-43a2-9119-cf4e9aa52801/images/536e088c-9e87-4ae5-902d-c81de6be0cb0/BI1684%20fig2.png)

[©Revision Village 2024]State two necessary measurements to calculate Simpson’s reciprocal index of diversity.[1]Calculate the percentage increase in the species diversity of bats in the pond after the introduction of the beaver.[2]Beavers became extinct in the UK over 400 years ago. Reintroduction programmes are now being carried out in various regions of the UK.Suggestthreeanthropogenic activities that could have led to the extinction of the beavers in the UK.[3]
list.markScheme: anyfourof the following:→\ce{ -> }​many different habitatsORniches are created by beaver activity[1]→\ce{ -> }​dams create pools that slow the run-off of rivers, benefiting plant rooting[1]→\ce{ -> }​dams generate wetlands that harbour insectORinvertebrate species[1]→\ce{ -> }​this promotes a food chain with consumers such as birds[1]→\ce{ -> }​pools are habitats for aquatic plantsORfish[1]→\ce{ -> }​felling trees allows sunlight onto the forest floor, benefiting ground-level plants and shrubs[1]→\ce{ -> }​fallen trees are a source of food for microorganismsORdetritivores[1][4 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:The activity of beaverscreates many habitatsfor other organisms (✓\checkmark✓), with an overall increase in biodiversity. For example, the felling of trees opens up patches of ground to sunlight,promoting ground-level vegetation(✓\checkmark✓). The pools created by beaver damsattract insects(✓\checkmark✓) and the consumers (such as birds) thatfeed on those insects(✓\checkmark✓). Dams slow the run-off of rainwater which has abeneficial effect on plant rootswhich are not washed away by fast-flowing water (✓\checkmark✓). The pools also attractfish species and aquatic plantsthat can oxygenate the pond water (✓\checkmark✓); beavers do not eat fish, so there is no harm to the fish from them.the following:→\ce{ -> }​total number of different species in the areaORspecies richnessANDtotal number of organisms of each speciesORspecies evenness[1][1 mark maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Two measurements needed to calculate Simpson’s Diversity Index are thetotal number of species in the areaand thetotal number of organisms of each species(✓\checkmark✓).the following:→\ce{ -> }​percentage increase = {(final volume - initial volume)/initial volume}×\times×100%[1]OR{(0.81-0.51) / 0.51}×\times×100%→\ce{ -> }​58.8%   (allow numbers between 52 and 64%)[1][2 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Percentage increase ={(p.81−-−0.51) / 0.51} x 100%(✓\checkmark✓)=−-−58.8%(✓\checkmark✓)anythreeof the following:→\ce{ -> }​hunting for furORcastoreum[1]→\ce{ -> }​habitat destructionORthe draining of wetlandsORother hydrological changes[1]→\ce{ -> }​deforestationORloggingORincrease in agricultural land[1]→\ce{ -> }​water pollution[1]→\ce{ -> }​fragmentation of landscape[1]→\ce{ -> }​urbanisationORindustrial developmentORroad construction[1]→\ce{ -> }​introduction of alien species[1]→\ce{ -> }​tradeORtravel leading to introduction of disease[1]→\ce{ -> }​use of pesticidesORherbicidesORagricultural chemicals[1][3 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:The extinction of beavers in the UK may have been caused byoverhuntingfor their valuablefurandcastoreum(✓\checkmark✓), combined withextensive habitat destructiondue to thedraining of wetlands(✓\checkmark✓) anddeforestationforagricultural expansion(✓\checkmark✓). Additionally, theintroduction of non-native species(✓\checkmark✓) anddiseases, through internationaltravel, (✓\checkmark✓) further contributed to their decline.

list.title: Question 317
list.content: A student, learning to use a microscope, observed a pollen grain under a microscope with a magnification of ×100. Using an eyepiece graticule, they measured the diameter of the pollen grain to be 25 divisions. At this magnification, 1 division on the eyepiece graticule equals 3μ\muμm. To allow the student to measure more pollen grains and to calculate a mean diameter, which of the following conclusions on the experimental work so far is/are correct?I.\hspace{1em}Increasing the magnification of the objective lens would widen the field of view.II.\hspace{.7em}The actual diameter of the pollen grain is 75μ\muμm.III.\hspace{.5em}If the magnification were increased to ×200, each eyepiece graticule division would represent a smaller actual size.A.\hspace{1em}I and II onlyB.\hspace{1em}I and III onlyC.\hspace{1em}II and III onlyD.\hspace{1em}I, II, and III
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Statement Iis not true. Increasing the magnification will narrow the field of view. This is a common student mistake. As magnification increases, the observer is focusing on a smaller area, like zooming in with a camera.Statement IIis true. The actual diameter of the pollen grain is calculated as 25 divisions × 3 µm/division = 75 µm.Statement IIIis true. If the magnification were increased by switching to a higher power objective, the same number of eyepiece graticule divisions would span a smaller actual distance on the specimen.Choice Cis correct because it contains the proper combination ofStatement IIandStatement III.Choice A, Choice BandChoice Ddo not contain the proper combination of statements.

list.title: Question 318
list.content:
A  biology class was given the following information:I.W, X, YandZare all closely related animal species.II.g, WandYall evolved from animal speciesX.III.Speciesgis an extinct recent common ancestor ofWandY.IV.Animal speciesZis the least related to the others, with extinct specieshserving as its most recent phylogenetic connection to the others.Below are cladograms drawn by four different students to represent the evolutionary relationships described.Which student drew the cladogram correctly?

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/26760cb4-c948-4999-8142-62356a5904b4/images/61ddfb74-bb4b-4911-b1e2-92fbf65411c6/4%20cladograms%20together.png)

[©Revision Village 2024]
list.markScheme:
BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Animal speciesZneeds to be in a different clade toWandYas it is the least closely related. However,Zis still linked toWandYvia animal speciesh.WandYare linked via a recent common ancestor,g, andW, Yandgare all linked via animal speciesX. This makes studentChoice Bcorrect.
