The cladogram drawn by student A is incorrect in many ways, including placing extinct specieshas the most distantly related species ofWandY, and placingZas the common ancestor connecting all the other species.Choice Ais, therefore, not the correct answer to this question.The cladogram drawn by student C is incorrect in several places, including puttinghas the most recent extinct ancestor ofWandXand puttinggas the common ancestor connecting all the other species.Choice Cis, therefore, not the correct answer to this question.The cladogram drawn by student D  incorrectly groupsWandXtogether after their divergence from the extinct species h. The cladogram incorrectly placesgas the common ancestor of all the other species.Choice Dis, therefore, not the correct answer to this question.

list.title: Question 319
list.content: The following table shows the approximate number of protein-encoding genes found in various species. What can be concluded from these findings?SpeciesApproximate number of protein-encoding genesDrosophila melanogaster(fruit fly)14,000Oryza sativa(rice)51,000Gallus gallus(chicken)20,000-23,000Homo sapiens(human)20,000-25,000I.The number of genes is not a good indicator of organism complexity.II.Chickens may have more genes than humans.III.The number of base pairs in the rice genome is greater than in the other species.A.\hspace{1em}I and II onlyB.\hspace{1em}II and III onlyC.\hspace{1em}I and III onlyD.\hspace{1em}I, II and III
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The number of genes found in a species does not serve as a good indicator of complexity (Statement I). If it did, the data here would suggest that chickens and humans are equally complex, and that rice is far more complex than either of them. Due to the overlapping ranges in the number of genes, it is entirely possible for chickens to have a greater number of genes than humans (Statement II). It is impossible to determine the size of the genome (measured in base pairs) of a species based on the number of genes it has. In reality, rice has far fewer base pairs than chickens or humans despite having approximately twice as many genes (Statement III).Choice Ais, therefore, correct.Choices B, C, andDare incorrect as they all containStatement III.

list.title: Question 320
list.content: In the early 19th century, vitalism was a widely accepted theory. This theory suggested that organic compounds, those found in living organisms, could only be produced through a "vital force" present in living matter.What was the role of urea in falsifying the theory of vitalism?A.\hspace{1em}Urea is produced by kidneys, indicating that living things can make organic compounds.B.\hspace{1em}Urea can be produced in laboratories, indicating that living things cannot synthesize organic compounds.C.\hspace{1em}Urea can be produced in laboratories, indicating that not only living things can synthesize organic compounds.D.\hspace{1em}Urea is produced by the kidneys, indicating that not only laboratories can make organic compounds.
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The theory of vitalism states that only living things can synthesise organic molecules. In 1953 Miller and Urey set up apparatus to simulate the conditions believed to be present on early Earth. Using these apparatus, they managed to produce urea, an organic compound, in the laboratory, which falsified this theory of vitalism. ThereforeChoice Cis correct.The fact that urea is produced by the kidneys (Choices AandD) does not falsify the theory of vitalism but rather supports it. The production of urea in laboratories does not mean it cannot be synthesised by living things (Choice B).

list.title: Question 321
list.content:
The diagram shows the phylogenetic tree of life. Which methodCANNOTbe used to estimate the ages of the first living cells?

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/487b410a-c72e-46bc-ac23-cf9fffe3bbfc/images/10fab881-d56f-4a45-a814-a9e928554585/BI1524%20fig1.png)

[Source: Adapted from Croft, J. D. (2014, November 4). File: phylogenic tree-en.svg. Wikimedia Commons. Retrieved February 26, 2024 from URL https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File: Phylogenic_Tree-en.svg. Copyright under CC BY 3.0]A.\hspace{1em}Dating fossils using radioactive techniquesB.\hspace{1em}Genomic analysis of mutation rateC.\hspace{1em}Analysis of stromatolitesD.\hspace{1em}Analysing fossils of LUCA from ancient volcanic rocks
list.markScheme: DSample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:While some of the oldest known microfossils have been found in volcanic sediments and have been used to estimate the age of early life, there are no direct fossils of LUCA. LUCA is inferred from molecular and phylogenetic analyses rather than from physical fossil evidence. Therefore,Choice Dprovides a method thatcannotbe used, and so is the correct answer to this question.is used to determine the age of ancient rocks and fossils by measuring the decay of radioactive isotopes. It provides an estimate of when organisms were alive on Earth, making it a valid method for dating early life;Choice Aprovides a method that can be used, and so is an incorrect answer to this question.Genomic analysis of mutation rate, known as the molecular clock, tracks changes in DNA sequences over time to estimate divergence points in evolutionary history. It can be used to infer when the first living cells emerged;Choice Bprovides a method that can be used, and so is an incorrect answer to this question.Stromatolites are layered rock formations created by the accumulation of sediment trapped by photosynthetic bacteria. By analysing the layering and geochemical signatures of these formations, scientists can estimate the age of the rock, thereby providing indirect dating by identifying potential habitats for early life.Choice Cprovides a method that can be used, so it is an incorrect answer to this question.

list.title: Question 322
list.content:
Louis Pasteur disproved the theory of spontaneous generation by showing that life did not spontaneously arise from non-living matter but came from existing microorganisms. In his experiment, he set up the following flasks:Open straight-neck flask containing boiled broth.
Swan-neck flask containing boiled broth (neck allowed air to flow but trapped dust and microbes).
Control flask containing boiled broth and sealed from the air.The experiment was replicated as shown below:

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/4f264e0a-eabd-4da0-bfbf-912611178311/images/9f2606f0-633f-460c-b9ba-a9599ddfb669/Pasteur%20flask%20RV.png)

[ © Revision Village. Created using BioRender.com ]Which two flasks would show the presence of microorganisms in the results?A.\hspace{1em}R and SB.\hspace{1em}S and QC.\hspace{1em}Q and RD.\hspace{1em}P and Q
list.markScheme:
AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Flasks R and S (Choice A) would show the presence of microorganisms as Flask R is exposed to the air, so bacteria can enter and Flask S wasn't boiled, so microorganisms originally in the flask were not killed before the flask was sealed.Flask P (Choice D)  is incorrect as it was boiled first, killing any microorganisms and sealed so no more microorganisms can enter.
Flask Q (Choices B,C,D) is incorrect because it was boiled, killing any microorganisms present. Swan-necked flasks prevent dust particles from carrying bacteria into the flask.

list.title: Question 323
list.content: Nutritional versatility is a key part of archaea's ability to colonise extreme environments. Describe the different sources of energy that archaea use for ATP production.[4]Discuss the effectiveness of Rubisco’s active site in facilitating carbon fixation.[4]Explain how fatty acids can spontaneously form vesicles, and why this was important for the development of primitive cells (protocells).[7]
list.markScheme: anyfourof the following:→\ce{ -> }​photoautotrophs use light to generate energy in the form of ATP[1]→\ce{ -> }​archaea don’t use chlorophyllORarchaea use a pigment called bacteriorhodopsin[1]→\ce{ -> }​light is captured and drives a protonORion pump to generate ATP[1]→\ce{ -> }​chemoautotrophs use oxidation of inorganic chemicals for ATP production[1]→\ce{ -> }​some archaea use hydrogen as an energy source[1]→\ce{ -> }​some archaea use hydrogen sulfide (HX2S\ce{H_2S}HX2​S)ORelemental sulfur, as an energy source[1]→\ce{ -> }​archaea may use metal ionsORironORmanganeseORother suitable example as part of their energy metabolism in extreme environments[1]→\ce{ -> }​some archaea can use fermentation pathways for ATP production in anaerobic conditions[1]→\ce{ -> }​some archaea oxidise methaneORammoniaORare methanogensORare methane-producing archaea[1]→\ce{ -> }​carbon dioxide acts as a terminal electron acceptor, reducing it to methane[1]→\ce{ -> }​heterotrophs use oxidation of carbon compounds as an energy source[1]→\ce{ -> }​archaea can metabolise complex organic molecules like sugarsORalcoholsORproteins[1][4 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Photoautotrophsuselightto produceATP(✓\checkmark✓).A pigmentin them captureslightanddrives a proton pump(✓\checkmark✓).Chemoautotrophsuseoxidationofinorganic chemicalsto produce ATP (✓\checkmark✓). Some archaea areheterotrophicand use theoxidationofcarbon compoundsas anenergy source(✓\checkmark✓).anyfourof the following(at leastoneadvantage andonedisadvantage is needed to gain full marks):Advantages→\ce{ -> }​rubisco’s active site binds specifically to RuBPORribulose-1,5-bisphosphate, enabling the efficient initiation of the carbon fixation process[1]→\ce{ -> }​binds to carbon dioxide, incorporating it into an organic molecule and playing a central role in the Calvin cycle[1]→\ce{ -> }​active site positions RuBP and carbon dioxide optimally for the reaction to occurORlowering activation energy[1]→\ce{ -> }​active site facilitates the formation of the unstable 6-carbon intermediate which then produces glycerate 3-phosphate[1]→\ce{ -> }​activity is regulated by environmental factorsORpHORmagnesium ion concentrationORother suitable named factor in the stroma, optimising activity under light-dependent conditions[1]Disadvantages→\ce{ -> }​rubisco can also bind to oxygen instead of carbon dioxideORcan also carry out photorespiration, which wastes energyORreduces the efficiency of photosynthesis[1]→\ce{ -> }​carbon dioxide needs to be at relatively high concentration to out compete oxygen for rubisco’s active site, which is not always achievable in certain environmental conditionsORis hot dry climatesORdeserts[1]→\ce{ -> }​relatively slow catalytic rate, requiring large amounts of Rubisco in plant cells to meet metabolic demands[1][4 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Rubisco’sactive siteis highly effective in facilitating the fixing of carbon dioxide because isbinds specificallytoribulose-1,5-bisphosphate(RuBP) (✓\checkmark✓) and also tocarbon dioxide, enabling itsincorporationinto anorganic molecule, and playing akey rolein theCalvin cycle(✓\checkmark✓). Bycorrectly positioning RuBPandcarbon dioxide, the active sitelowerstheactivation energyrequired for the reaction (✓\checkmark✓). This facilitates theformationof anunstable 6-carbon intermediate, which rapidly splits into two molecules ofglycerate-3-phosphate(✓\checkmark✓).However, rubisco canbind to oxygeninstead of carbon dioxide, resulting inphotorespiration, whichwastes energyandreduces photosynthetic efficiency(✓\checkmark✓). The enzyme’srelatively slow catalytic ratealso requires plants to producelarge amounts of Rubiscotomeettheirmetabolic needs(✓\checkmark✓).anysevenof the following(must contain at leasttwostatements for how vesicles form andtwofor the role of vesicles in protocell development):Fatty acids can spontaneously form vesicles→\ce{ -> }​fatty acids are amphipathic moleculesORhave a hydrophilicORpolar headANDa hydrophobicORnonpolar tail[1]→\ce{ -> }​the hydrophobicORnonpolar tails orient themselves away from water[1]→\ce{ -> }​the hydrophilicORpolar heads orient themselves towards the water[1]→\ce{ -> }​in aqueous environments, fatty acids spontaneously form micelles or bilayers[1]→\ce{ -> }​bilayers can close into spherical vesicles, creating an enclosed compartment that reduces the energy cost of hydrophobic interactions.[1]Role of vesicle formation in protocell development→\ce{ -> }​vesicles provide compartmentalisation of biochemical reactions, enabling the development of early metabolic pathways[1]→\ce{ -> }​the selective permeability of vesicle membranes allows controlled exchange of molecules, crucial for nutrient uptakeORwaste removal.[1]→\ce{ -> }​vesicles can grow and divide, a process resembling primitive cell divisionWHICHis a critical process for the emergence of cellular life[1]→\ce{ -> }​fatty acid-based vesicles are considered precursors to modern cellular membranes, providing a foundation for lipid bilayer evolution[1]→\ce{ -> }​primitive vesicles were less stable than modern membranes and required specific environmental conditions for stability and maintenance[1]→\ce{ -> }​vesicle formation alone does not explain the origin of complex metabolic networksORself-replicating systems[1]→\ce{ -> }​experimental evidence supports the RNA world hypothesis, where vesicles could encapsulate RNA and protect it from degradation, supporting early life processes[1]→\ce{ -> }​vesicles enable localised concentrations of reactants, increasing reaction efficiency compared to dispersed molecules in open water[1]→\ce{ -> }​vesicles that encapsulated RNAORother molecules had an evolutionary advantage by protecting their contents from degradation[1]→\ce{ -> }​primitive vesicle stability depended on environmental factors like temperatureORpHORionic concentration, which influenced protocell evolution[1][7 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Fatty acids spontaneously self-assemble into vesicles in aqueous environments due to theiramphipathic nature, meaning they have ahydrophilic (polar) headand ahydrophobic (nonpolar) tail(✓\checkmark✓). Thehydrophobic tailsorientaway from water, while thehydrophilic heads interact with water, leading to the formation ofstable structures(✓\checkmark✓).  Inaqueousconditions, fatty acids canspontaneously form bilayers(✓\checkmark✓), which can then close intospherical vesicles, creating acompartmentthatminimises hydrophobic interactions(✓\checkmark✓).Thesevesiclesplayed a crucial role in protocell development by providingcompartmentalisation, allowing for theconcentration of reactantsand the formation ofearly metabolic pathways(✓\checkmark✓). Theselective permeabilityof vesicle membranes enabled thecontrolled exchangeofnutrientsandwaste, an essential step forcellular evolution(✓\checkmark✓). Additionally, vesicles had the ability togrow and divide, a processresembling primitive cell division, which was crucial for theemergence of life(✓\checkmark✓). Theencapsulation of RNAwithin vesicles would have given protocells anevolutionary advantagebyprotecting genetic materialfromdegradation, supporting theRNA world hypothesis(✓\checkmark✓).A quality mark is awarded if each part of the question (a, b, c) is answered to earn at least half of the points available, answers do not require re-reading to be understood, and there are almost no errors and little irrelevant information.[1]

list.title: Question 324
list.content: Outline the binomial naming system and its importance.[4]Explain how a sample of cells taken from a foetus can be used to determine whether the foetus will be biologically male or biologically female at birth.[4]Outline the outcomes of the human genome project and their impacts on different fields of science.[7]
list.markScheme: Anyfourof the following:→\ce{ -> }​binomial naming system as the system used to name species[1]→\ce{ -> }​genus name and species name[1]→\ce{ -> }​species with the same genus share many characteristicsORare closely related[1]→\ce{ -> }​internationally agreed[1]→\ce{ -> }​facilitates understanding and communication between scientists[1][4 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:The binomial naming system is the system which scientists use toname species(✓\checkmark✓) and this isinternationally agreed(✓\checkmark✓), which means it’s used all over the world, which aids in thecommunicationbetween scientists (✓\checkmark✓) in different countries. The name of each species has two parts, the first highlights thegenusto which it belongs and the second part refers to thespecies(✓\checkmark✓).Anyfourof the following:→\ce{ -> }​cells grown in a culture medium[1]→\ce{ -> }​cells stained[1]→\ce{ -> }​observed under a light microscope[1]→\ce{ -> }​photomicrograph taken during mitosisORmitotic metaphase[1]→\ce{ -> }​chromosomes arranged according to sizeORposition of centromeres[1]→\ce{ -> }​look at chromosome pair 23[1]→\ce{ -> }​two large chromosomes mean foetus is XX[1]→\ce{ -> }​one large chromosome and one small chromosome means foetus is XY[1]→\ce{ -> }​XX is biologically femaleANDXY is biologically male[1][4 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Once the sample of cells has been taken from the foetus they are grown in aculture medium(✓\checkmark✓). They are thenstained(✓\checkmark✓) and observed under alight microscope(✓\checkmark✓). Aphotomicrographis taken (✓\checkmark✓), and the image is cut up so that thechromosomescan bearranged by sizeand position of thecentromere(✓\checkmark✓). A foetus withtwo large Xchromosomes will bebiologically female(✓\checkmark✓), and a foetus withone large Xandone small Ychromosome will bebiologically male(✓\checkmark✓).Anysevenof the following:→\ce{ -> }​the Human Genome Project (HGP) sequenced the entire human genome[1]→\ce{ -> }​it determined the total number of base pairs in the human genome[1]→\ce{ -> }​it estimated the number of genes in the human genome[1]→\ce{ -> }​identified the loci of genes[1]→\ce{ -> }​identified repeat sequences[1]→\ce{ -> }​identified locations of single nucleotide polymorphisms[1]→\ce{ -> }​identified gene sequences associated with certain diseasesORbiological processesORtraits[1]→\ce{ -> }​HGP stimulated further developmentORreduced the price of sequencing technology[1]→\ce{ -> }​technology developed for the HGP is now used to diagnose diseasesORidentify micro-organisms OR DNA matching in forensics and medicineORgenetic modification[1]→\ce{ -> }​contributed to the field by identifying genetic markers that affect how individuals metabolise and respond to medicationsORcontribute information for personalised medicine[1]→\ce{ -> }​insights into evolutionary relationshipsORgenetic similaritiesORgenetic differences[1]→\ce{ -> }​identification of regulatory elementsORnon-coding RNAsORcomponents that play essential roles in gene expressionORcellular function[1]→\ce{ -> }​emphasised importance of consideration of ethicalORlegalORsocial implications of genomic research[1][7 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:The Human Genome Project (HGP)sequencedthe entire human genome (✓\checkmark✓),identified the lociof genes (✓\checkmark✓) and identified gene sequences that are connected to somediseases(✓\checkmark✓) such as breast cancer. Locations ofsingle nucleotide polymorphisms(✓\checkmark✓) were discovered which are variations in individuals DNA base pairs. The results have contributed to the development ofpersonalised medicine(✓\checkmark✓) as genetic markers have been identified that affect how individuals respond to medications. The technology developed for the HGP has led to further advancements in technology,reducing the costof genetic sequencing (✓\checkmark✓).  The HGP also emphasised how important it is to consider theethical implications(✓\checkmark✓) of genomic research and the importance of informed consent.A quality mark is awarded if each part of the question (a, b, c) is answered to earn at least half of the points available, answers do not require re-reading to be understood, and there are almost no errors and little irrelevant information.[1]

list.title: Question 325
list.content: Outline the varied forms of genetic material found in viruses.[4]Discuss the evidence supporting that the diversity of viruses exists as a result of convergent evolution.[4]Compare the structure of the coronavirus with the human immunodeficiency virus, HIV.[7]
list.markScheme: Anyfourof the following:→\ce{ -> }​single-stranded RNA[1]→\ce{ -> }​single-stranded DNA[1]→\ce{ -> }​double-stranded RNA[1]→\ce{ -> }​double-stranded DNA[1]→\ce{ -> }​nucleic acidORDNAORRNA[1][4 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:There are many different types of viruses. The types of genetic information found in different types of viruses includesingle-stranded RNA(✓\checkmark✓),double-stranded RNA(✓\checkmark✓),single-stranded DNA(✓\checkmark✓), anddouble-stranded DNA(✓\checkmark✓).Anyfourof the following:→\ce{ -> }​convergent evolution refers to the appearance of similar traits in unrelated organisms as a response to similar selection pressures[1]→\ce{ -> }​viruses exhibit a wide range of formsORstructuresORmechanisms to adapt to different hostsORenvironments[1]→\ce{ -> }​presence of a capsid surrounding genetic materialORnucleocapsid is a shared feature that evolved independently in different viral lineages[1]→\ce{ -> }​presence of specific protein receptors or spikes have evolved independently to facilitate host cell attachmentORsuitable example such as similar spike proteins in coronaviruses and influenza viruses[1]→\ce{ -> }​independent evolution of similar replication enzymesORreverse transcriptase[1]→\ce{ -> }​viruses utilise either DNAORRNA as their genetic material, demonstrating molecular convergence in adapting to different replication strategies[1]→\ce{ -> }​convergent traits enhance viral fitness by aiding in host cell attachmentORimmune evasionORefficient replication[1][4 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Convergent evolution occurs whenunrelated organismsevolvesimilar traitsdue tosimilar selection pressures(✓\checkmark✓). In viruses, an example is theindependent evolutionofprotein spikesincoronavirusesandinfluenza virusesto aid inhost cell attachment(✓\checkmark✓). Similarly, unrelated viruses have independently evolvedreverse transcriptaseforefficient replication(✓\checkmark✓). Additionally, viruses use eitherDNA or RNAas genetic material, showingmolecular convergencein adapting to variousreplication needs(✓\checkmark✓).Sevenof the following (there must be at least one similarity and one difference):Similarities→\ce{ -> }​BOTHare spherical in shape[1]→\ce{ -> }​BOTHcontain (viral) envelope,ORboth are enveloped with a lipid bilayer[1]→\ce{ -> }​BOTHcontain RNA as the genetic material[1]→\ce{ -> }​BOTHcontain a capsid[1]→\ce{ -> }​BOTHcontain spikes[1]→\ce{ -> }​BOTHspikes are made of glycoprotein[1]Differences→\ce{ -> }​HIV contains reverse transcriptase,WHILEcoronaviruses do not[1]→\ce{ -> }​HIV contains two (single) strands of RNA,WHILEthe coronavirus contains one single strand of RNAORHIV genome is shorter or about 10,000 nucleotides,WHILEcoronavirus is longer (about 30,000 nucleotides)[1]→\ce{ -> }​HIV has an enveloped capsid,WHILEcoronavirus contains a helical (nucleo)capsid[1]→\ce{ -> }​HIV genome is within enveloped capsid,WHILEcoronavirus genome is a nucleocapsid/not in envelope[1][7 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:In comparing the coronavirus and the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), there are several similarities and differences.  Both the coronavirus and HIV arespherical in shape(✓\checkmark✓), the genetic information is enclosed by acapsid(✓\checkmark✓), and both types of viruses containRNA as the genetic material(✓\checkmark✓). However,HIVis a retrovirus andcontains the enzyme reverse transcriptase, while thecoronavirus does not contain reverse transcriptase(✓\checkmark✓). Both virusescontain spikes(✓\checkmark✓) for attachment to cells,and both HIV spikes and coronavirus spikes are made of glycoprotein(✓\checkmark✓).HIV contains twosinglestrands of RNA; however, the coronavirus contains one single strand of RNA(✓\checkmark✓).A quality mark is awarded if each part of the question (a, b, c) is answered to earn at least half of the points available, answers do not require re-reading to be understood, and there are almost no errors and little irrelevant information.[1]

list.title: Question 326
list.content: The DNA sequence from the same section of DNA but from two different organisms is shown in the table below.Which organisms are most likely to have diverged from each other most recently?Sequence 1Sequence 2\hspace{1em}A.\hspace{1em}ATCGGGTCGCTTTCTCGATCCGGTCGCTTTGTCG\hspace{1em}B.\hspace{1em}TCGCGCGTAAATCGATGTCCCGCGTCAATCGTTA\hspace{1em}C.\hspace{1em}ATCGGGTGTGTCATATGATCGCGTGTCTCATCTG\hspace{1em}D.\hspace{1em}TGTCATCATCCCGTACTGTGTCATCATCGGCATGAC
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Ais correct because the two sequences have the smallest number of differences between them, only two, therefore they are the most closely related.Choices B,CandDare incorrect, as there are more than 2 differences between the two sequences, 4, 3 and 8, respectively.

list.title: Question 327
list.content: Which organelle is formed by a vesicle derived from the cell membrane?A.\hspace{1em}Food vacuoleB.\hspace{1em}RibosomeC.\hspace{1em}Golgi apparatusD.\hspace{1em}Smooth endoplasmic reticulum
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:When a cell takes in material through endocytosis, it produces a vesicle derived from the cell membrane, which is how a food vacuole is formed.Ribosomes are involved in translation (Choice B), the golgi apparatus sorts, packages and modifies proteins (Choice C) and the smooth endoplasmic reticulum, among other functions, synthesizes lipids (Choice D).

list.title: Question 328
list.content: Genetic variation is the root of phenotypic diversity between and within species.Phenotypic expression relies on the genome and proteome. Outline the differences between the genome and the proteome[3]While genetic variations can be beneficial, others can lead to detrimental health conditions, such as diabetes. Compare and contrast Type I and Type II diabetes.[4]Describe the approaches used to classify different species.[8]
list.markScheme: Anythreeof the following:→\ce{ -> }​genome is the complete set of genetic material present in an organismORincludes all the genes, regulatory elements and non-coding regions of the genetic material of an organismWHEREASproteome is the entire set of proteins producedORexpressed by a cell, tissue, or organism at a specific time under defined conditions[1]→\ce{ -> }​genome composed of DNA nucleotidesWHEREASproteome composed of amino acids[1]→\ce{ -> }​genome stores genetic informationORis a template for the synthesis of proteomeWHEREASproteome carries out the functions of the organismORis involved in cellular processes[1]→\ce{ -> }​genome relatively stable over timeWHEREASproteome is highly dynamicORproteome constantly changing in response to cellular needsORenvironmentORinternal signals[1]→\ce{ -> }​size of genome is relatively constant within a speciesWHEREASproteome can be much largerORmore diverse than the genome due to alternative splicing, post-translational modifications, and protein-protein interactions[1][3 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Thegenomeis thecomplete set of genetic materialpresent in an organism, includingallthegenes, regulatory elementsandnon-coding regions, whereas theproteomeis theentire setofproteinsproduced by acell, tissue,ororganismat a specific time under defined conditions (✓\checkmark✓). Thegenomeis made up ofnucleotides, whereas theproteomeis composed ofamino acids(✓\checkmark✓). Functionally, thegenomeacts as a source of geneticinstructions, providing the information necessary for development and regulation, while theproteomeactivelyparticipatesincellular processes(✓\checkmark✓) based on these instructions. Thegenomeis relativelystablewith occasional genetic variations, whereas theproteomeis highlydynamic, responding to environmental factors (✓\checkmark✓).Anyfourof the following (AT LEAST ONEsimilarity andAT LEAST ONEdifference must be given):→\ce{ -> }​BOTHTypes of diabetes affect blood glucose concentrationORaffect the body’s ability to control blood glucose concentration[1]→\ce{ -> }​BOTHtypes of diabetes cause health complications if blood glucose concentration is not controlled[1]→\ce{ -> }​Type I is an autoimmune diseaseWHEREASType II is linked to geneticsORlifestyleORageing[1]→\ce{ -> }​Type I diabetes is caused when the beta cells are destroyed by the immune system and do not secrete enough insulinWHEREASType II diabetes is caused when body cells become insensitiveORresistant to insulin[1]→\ce{ -> }​Type I diabetes usually begins in childhoodWHEREASType II diabetes usually begins in adulthood[1]→\ce{ -> }​Type I diabetes cannot be controlled by lifestyle changesWHEREASType II diabetes can often be controlled by lifestyle changes[1]→\ce{ -> }​Type I diabetes requires frequent measurement of blood glucose concentrationWHEREASType II diabetes does not require frequent measurement of blood glucose concentration[1]→\ce{ -> }​Type I diabetes requires insulin injections from startWHEREASType II diabetes is only treated with insulin if the disease progresses[1]→\ce{ -> }​Type I tends to be diagnosed at early ageWHEREASType II tends to be diagnosed in older people[1][4 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:BothType I and Type II diabetesdisrupttheregulationofnormal blood glucose concentration(✓\checkmark✓).Type I diabetesis anautoimmune diseasewhere theimmune system destroys beta cells in the pancreas, resulting in alack of insulinproduction. The causes ofType II diabetesaremultifactorial, includinggenetics, lifestyleandageing(✓\checkmark✓), and it manifests when bodycellsbecomeresistant to insulin(✓\checkmark✓).Type I diabetesrequiresfrequent measurement of blood glucoseconcentration, whereasType II diabetesdoesnot usually requirefrequent measurements of blood glucose concentration (✓\checkmark✓).Type Idiabetes requires lifelonginsulin injections, whereasType IIdiabetes only requiresinsulininjections if thecondition progresses(✓\checkmark✓).Anyeightof the following:→\ce{ -> }​classification is used to organise organisms into groups[1]→\ce{ -> }​binomial nomenclatureORbinomial system used to name organismsORname is genus and species[1]→\ce{ -> }​allows communication and understanding between scientists all around the world[1]→\ce{ -> }​there are three domains of life[1]→\ce{ -> }​a species is the smallest unit of classification[1]→\ce{ -> }​hierarchy is used to group speciesORthe taxa are arranged in order of decreasing group size: domain, kingdom, phylum, class, order, family, genus, species[1]→\ce{ -> }​morphologicalORartificial classification is based on physical characteristics[1]→\ce{ -> }​morphology can lead to errorsORanalogous structures can mislead classification[1]→\ce{ -> }​biochemical classification analyses molecular componentsORproteinsORDNAORRNA[1]→\ce{ -> }​base sequences in nucleic acidsORamino acid sequences of proteins are analysed[1]→\ce{ -> }​cladistics is based on shared characteristics traced to most recent common ancestorORcladogram is a visual representation of how species are evolutionarily related, with a node representing a common ancestor[1]→\ce{ -> }​modern approach combines evidenceORuses all types of classificationORuses morphology, biochemistry and genetics[1]→\ce{ -> }​natural classification groups organisms based on evolutionary history[1]→\ce{ -> }​classification includes fossils[1]→\ce{ -> }​organisms with a recent common ancestor are classified more closely together[1]→\ce{ -> }​species in the same genus share many characteristics[1]→\ce{ -> }​organisms can be reclassified when new evidence is found[1]→\ce{ -> }​natural classification allows scientists to predict characteristics of species within a group[1][8 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Classification is the process oforganising organismsinto appropriate categories orgroupsbased on theirshared characteristics(✓\checkmark✓). Scientists usebinomial nomenclatureto assigneach organisma unique two-part name made up of thegenusandspecies(✓\checkmark✓), facilitatingglobal scientific communication(✓\checkmark✓). Organisms are traditionally classifiedhierarchically, starting with the broadest category, thedomain, then working downwards -kingdom, phylum, class, order, family genus, species(✓\checkmark✓) (which can then be split into sub-species).Traditional, artificial, classification has been based onphysical traits. However, thismorphologicalapproach (✓\checkmark✓) can bemisleadingdue toanalogous structures(✓\checkmark✓).Modernclassification integratesmorphological, biochemical, andgeneticinformation, (✓\checkmark✓).Biochemicalclassification examines themolecular componentsof organisms, including thesequencesofbasesofDNAandamino acidsofproteins(✓\checkmark✓).Cladisticsis based onshared characteristicstraced to themost recent common ancestor, and these relationships can be represented visually oncladograms(✓\checkmark✓). Asnew data emerges, reclassificationmay occur (✓\checkmark✓).A quality mark is awarded if each part of the question (a, b, c) is answered to earn at least half of the points available, answers do not require re-reading to be understood, and there are almost no errors and little irrelevant information.[1]

list.title: Question 329
list.content: Distinguish between RNA and DNA.[3]Explain the importance of orientation and directionality of DNA and RNA.[4]Describe how the Hershey and Chase experiment demonstrated that DNA carries the genetic information .[8]
list.markScheme: Anythreeof the following:→\ce{ -> }​RNA is single-strandedWHEREASDNA is double-stranded[1]→\ce{ -> }​RNA has a variety of shapesWHEREASDNA is a double helix[1]→\ce{ -> }​RNA contains ribose sugarWHEREASDNA contains deoxyribose[1]→\ce{ -> }​RNA contains the nitrogenous base uracilORUWHEREASDNA contains thymineORT[1]→\ce{ -> }​RNA only contains permanent genetic code in RNA virusesWHEREASDNA contains permanent genetic code in all cells (except red blood cells)[1][3 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:RNA is asingle strandedmolecule containing ribose sugar and uracil as one of its four nitrogenous bases. DNA on the other hand isdouble-stranded(✓\checkmark✓), containsdeoxyriboseinstead ofribosesugar (✓\checkmark✓), and hasthymineinstead ofuracil(✓\checkmark✓) as one of its four nitrogenous bases. DNA forms a regulardouble helix, whereas RNA can formdifferent shapes(✓\checkmark✓) depending on its role, such as the clover-shaped tRNA and long-stranded mRNA.Anyfourof the following:→\ce{ -> }​5’OR5 prime end  refers to the end with a phosphate group bound to the 5th carbon of the deoxyriboseORpentose sugar, but not bound to another nucleotide, the 3’OR3 prime end refers to the end where the 3rd carbon of the deoxyriboseORpentose sugar is not bound to another nucleotide[1]→\ce{ -> }​DNA has antiparallel strandsORone strand is in the 5’ to 3’ direction, and another strand is in the 3’ to 5’ strand[1]→\ce{ -> }​single DNA strand is tilted; therefore, two DNA strands can only bind together if they are in antiparallel orientation[1]→\ce{ -> }​in DNA replication, one lagging strand and one leading strand are produced[1]→\ce{ -> }​in DNA replication DNA polymerase only adds free nucleotides to the 3’ end of the growing DNA strandORadds free nucleotides in the 5’ to 3’ direction[1]→\ce{ -> }​in transcription RNA polymerase can only add nucleotides in the 5’ to 3’ direction to form mRNA[1]→\ce{ -> }​translation must start nearest to the 5’ end of the mRNA[1][4 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Both RNA and DNA have directionality they have a5’and3’end. The5’ endrefers to the end with aphosphate groupattached to carbon 5 of the deoxyribose, butnot attachedto anothernucleotide, the3’end refers to the end wherecarbon 3of the deoxyribose isnot attachedto anothernucleotide(✓\checkmark✓). DNA forms a double helix withantiparallelstrands (✓\checkmark✓). Duringreplication DNA polymerasecan onlyadd free nucleotidesin the5’ to 3’direction (✓\checkmark✓). Duringtranscription RNA polymerasecan onlyadd nucleotidesin the5’ to 3’direction (✓\checkmark✓) to form a strand of mRNA.Translationof the mRNA muststart at the 5’end (✓\checkmark✓).Anyeightof the following:→\ce{ -> }​bacteriophagesORphage virus was used[1]→\ce{ -> }​bacteriophage contains an inner core that has DNA and a protein coat[1]→\ce{ -> }​experiments tested the hypothesis that DNA and not protein carries the genetic information[1]→\ce{ -> }​bacteriophageORvirus can attach to the surface of bacterial cellORhost and inject substance into the cell[1]→\ce{ -> }​substance contains information for bacteria cellORhost to duplicateORproduce more bacteriophagesORviruses[1]→\ce{ -> }​bacteriophagesORvirus were labeled with radioactive phosphorus (32P) and radioactive sulfur (35S)OR32P was incorporated into DNA core and35S was incorporated into protein coat[1]→\ce{ -> }​phosphorus is found only in DNA and not protein[1]→\ce{ -> }​sulfur is found only in protein and not DNA[1]→\ce{ -> }​Escherichia coliORbacterial cells were infected with bacteriophageORvirus[1]→\ce{ -> }​used centrifuge to separate bacteriophageORvirus from bacteria[1]→\ce{ -> }​virus in liquidORsupernatant did not contain radioactive32P but bacterial sedimentORpellet contained radioactive32P[1]→\ce{ -> }​32P DNA entered the bacteriaORhost cell for replication[1]→\ce{ -> }​virus in liquidORsupernatant contained radioactive35S but bacterial sedimentORpellet did not contain radioactive35S[1]→\ce{ -> }​35S protein structure did not enter the bacteriaORhost cell for replication[1]→\ce{ -> }​genetic material needs to enter the bacterial cell in order to produce new viruses[1][8 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Hershey and Chase's experiment was conducted to investigate whether DNA or protein carries the genetic material. In their experiment, they usedbacteriophages(✓\checkmark✓) to infect bacteria cells.Bacteriophagecontains anouter coat made of proteinand aninner core containing DNA(✓\checkmark✓) which makes it suitable for comparing DNA and protein. The bacteriophage can thenattach itself to the surface of the bacteria cellandinject the substance(✓\checkmark✓) which carries important genetic information into the bacteria cell.The bacteriophages were then cultured under two different conditions —one was incorporated with a radioactive phosphorus isotope,32Pand another with a radioactivesulfur isotope,35S(✓\checkmark✓). Radioactive elements 32P and 35S were used becausephosphorus is found in the DNA structurebutabsent in protein(✓\checkmark✓), whereassulfur, isfound intheproteinstructure butabsentin theDNA(✓\checkmark✓) structure.The bacteria cells were then cultured together with the bacteriophages and wereinfected with the bacteriophages(✓\checkmark✓). After centrifugation, it was found that the pellets containingbacteria culturedwith theradioactive32P bacteriophages contained radioactivity, whereas thebacteriophage protein coatsin the supernatantdidn’t(✓\checkmark✓).  The pellets containing thebacteria culturedwith theradioactive35S bacteriophages did not contain any radioactivity, whereas thebacteriophage protein coatsin the supernatantdid(✓\checkmark✓). These provided evidence that DNA labelled with the32P entered the bacteria cells, whereas theproteinwhich was labelled with the35S did not(✓\checkmark✓) enter the bacteria cells.A quality mark is awarded if each part of the question (a, b, c) is answered to earn at least half of the points available, answers do not require re-reading to be understood, and there are almost no errors and little irrelevant information.[1]

list.title: Question 330
list.content:
Louis Pasteur disproved the theory of spontaneous generation by showing that life did not spontaneously arise from non-living matter but came from existing microorganisms. In his experiment, he set up the following flasks:I. Open straight-neck flask containing boiled broth.II. Swan-neck flask containing boiled broth (neck allowed air to flow but trapped dust and microbes).III.
Control flask containing boiled broth and sealed from the air.Researchers carried out a similar experiment to Louis Pasteur’s famous experiment, using the set-up below, and incubating the flasks at 30°C.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/a499eca1-3fdc-499b-a934-107e6a0815bc/images/e58dbdf5-c36e-4567-ad68-a5f3248068bd/spontaneous%20origin%20of%20cells%20flasks.png)

[© Revision Village 2023. Created with Chemix (https://chemix.org)]State the purpose of boiling the broth before placing it in some of the flasks.[1]State two variables that must be controlled in this experiment.[2]Explain why it is important to have controlled variables in this study.[1]State the letters of three flasks which would show signs of decomposition of broth.[1]Explain your answer to part (i).[3]Suggest, with reasons, how the results of the study would differ if the flasks were incubated at 4°C.[2]
list.markScheme: the following:→\ce{ -> }​to kill any pre-existing microorganismsORbacteria in the brothORbeofre the experiment[1][1 mark maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:The purpose of boiling the broth was tokillany pre-existingmicroorganisms in the broth. (✓\checkmark✓).Anytwoof the following:→\ce{ -> }​initial volume of broth[1]→\ce{ -> }​temperature broth is incubated at[1]→\ce{ -> }​oxygen concentration[1]→\ce{ -> }​concentration of nutrients in the broth[1]→\ce{ -> }​typeORvolume of flask[1]→\ce{ -> }​time flask is incubated for[1]→\ce{ -> }​time that broth is boiled for[1]→\ce{ -> }​sterilisation of flasksORapparatus before setting up the experiment[1]→\ce{ -> }​consistent composition of the broth[1][2 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Two variables that must be controlled in this experiment are the initialvolume of broth(✓\checkmark✓) and thetemperatureat which the broth is incubated (✓\checkmark✓).Anyoneof the following:→\ce{ -> }​to ensure that any differences in the decomposition of the broth are only due to the independent variable[1]→\ce{ -> }​to limit the influence of confounding variables[1]→\ce{ -> }​to allow for a fair comparison between the flasks[1]→\ce{ -> }​to increase replicabilityORrepeatability[1][1 mark maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:It is important to have controlled variables in this study to ensure that anydifferences in the decomposition of the brothare only due to theindependent variable(✓\checkmark✓).Anythreeof the following gives one mark:Do NOT award mark if any incorrect flasks are included.→\ce{ -> }​Q, R, S, T[1][1 mark maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:The flasks that would show decomposition of broth areQ, RandS(✓\checkmark✓).Anythreeof the following:→\ce{ -> }​flask Q was not boiled so microorganisms would be aliveORwould reproduceANDmicroorganisms could enter from the air[1]→\ce{ -> }​flask R was tilted after being boiled, so microorganisms could still enter the flask at an angle[1]→\ce{ -> }​flask S was not boiled, so any microorganisms in the flask were not killed before the flask was sealed[1]→\ce{ -> }​flask T was sealed with a metal mesh, so microorganisms from the air could enter the broth[1][3 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:FlaskQwould show decomposition of broth, as it was not boiled somicroorganisms would be alivein the broth and could alsoenter from the air(✓\checkmark✓). FlaskRwould show decomposition of broth, as even though it was tilted, it was not sealed somicroorganisms can still enter the flaskat an angle (✓\checkmark✓). FlaskSwould also show decomposition of the broth, as it wasnot boiled before being sealed, so microorganisms would be alive in the broth (✓\checkmark✓).Anytwoof the following→\ce{ -> }​there would be less decomposition of the brothORless bacterial growthORless rapid growth of microorganisms in flasks Q, R, S and T[1]→\ce{ -> }​at lower temperatures, microorganisms have a lower metabolic rateORthere is stiffening of phospholipid bilayer which decreases efficiency of membrane transportORhave a slower growth rate[1]→\ce{ -> }​cooler temperatures can reduce the likelihood of contamination[1]→\ce{ -> }​there would be no difference in flask P because no bacteria could enter and the broth was boiled killing any bacteria in the broth[1][2 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:If the flasks were incubated at 4°C, there would beless decomposition(✓\checkmark✓) of the broth in flasks Q, R, S and T, as at lower temperatures, microorganisms have aslower growth rate(✓\checkmark✓).

list.title: Question 331
list.content: Enzymes are central to the control of the majority of biochemical processes in an organism, including the cell cycle.Explain how the rate of an enzyme-controlled reaction is affected by changes in the enzyme concentration.[4]Outline how polyploidy results in reproductive isolation.[4]Explain the reasons for changes in allele frequency in different populations.[7]
list.markScheme: Anyfourof the following (an annotated graph correctly drawn is acceptable to achieve full marks)→\ce{ -> }​at lower enzyme concentrations, the rate of reaction is relatively slower[1]→\ce{ -> }​as enzyme concentration increases, the reaction rate increases[1]→\ce{ -> }​the greater the concentration of an enzyme is, the higher the probability of substrate molecules binding withORcolliding with the active siteORforming enzyme-substrate complexes[1]→\ce{ -> }​at very low concentrations of substrate, increasing enzyme concentration has little effect on reaction rate[1]→\ce{ -> }​enzyme saturationORif all active sites have substrate attached, substrate is the limiting factor[1]→\ce{ -> }​eventually, if substrate limited, rate of reaction plateaus[1][4 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Asenzyme concentration increases, the rate of reaction also increases (✓\checkmark✓).   Themore enzyme moleculespresent, thegreater the chancesare of asubstratemoleculebindingto theactive site(✓\checkmark✓).  If there is a verylow concentration of substrate, adding more enzymes haslittle effecton therateof reaction (✓\checkmark✓) since there is no more substrate to bind. Onceallthesubstratemolecules areattached to active sitestherateof reactionwill plateau(✓\checkmark✓) as thesubstrateis thelimiting factor(✓\checkmark✓).Anyfourof the following:→\ce{ -> }​polyploids possess more than two sets of chromosomes[1]→\ce{ -> }​can be caused by hybridisation events between two closely related species[1]→\ce{ -> }​can result from failed spindle formationORnon-disjunctionORfailed separation of chromosomesORchromosomes replicate and cell does not divideORwhen a diploid gamete fuses with a haploid gameteORtwo sperm may fertilise an egg[1]→\ce{ -> }​organisms with a different number of chromosomesORnew tetraploid and original diploid cannot breed together to produce fertile offspring[1]→\ce{ -> }​results in being reproductively isolated from the original population[1]→\ce{ -> }​once isolated polyploid population diverges genetically from original population[1]→\ce{ -> }​the polyploid organism is a new species[1][4 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Polyploidy is when an organism hasmore than two sets of chromosomes(✓\checkmark✓), this is often the result of chromosomesfailing to separate properlyduring anaphase I or II of meiosis (✓\checkmark✓). The polyploid organism becomesreproductively isolatedfrom the original population  (✓\checkmark✓) and thus becomes anew species(✓\checkmark✓).Anysevenof the following:→\ce{ -> }​allele frequency is the proportion of an allele in a population[1]→\ce{ -> }​affected by natural selection, where the frequency of more favourable alleles will increaseORthe frequency of less favourable alleles will decrease[1]→\ce{ -> }​three types of natural selection: disruptive, stabilising and directional[1]→\ce{ -> }​disruptive selection is when selection pressures act to remove intermediate varieties in a population, causing the alleles for extreme traits to increase in frequencyORthe alleles for intermediate traits to decrease in frequency[1]→\ce{ -> }​increasing the variation in a population[1]→\ce{ -> }​stabilising selection is when selection pressures act to remove extreme varieties, causing the alleles for extreme traits to decrease[1]→\ce{ -> }​decreasing the variation within a population[1]→\ce{ -> }​directional selection is when selection pressures act to remove one extreme, which results in the increase of the favoured allele[1]→\ce{ -> }​mutations are random changes to the DNA base sequence[1]→\ce{ -> }​if they result in favourable phenotypes, then the frequency of those alleles can increase in the population[1]→\ce{ -> }​genetic drift is random changes in the number of alleles in a population[1]→\ce{ -> }​can lead to rapid changes in allele frequency in a short period of time[1]→\ce{ -> }​gene migrationORgene flow is the transfer of genetic information from one population to another, often via migration[1]→\ce{ -> }​introduces new alleles to populations, thereby changing the allele frequency[1]→\ce{ -> }​crossing over can result in new allele combinations that may be favourable to 	offspring[1]→\ce{ -> }​can result in the allele frequency of the favourable allele becoming more prominent in a population[1][7 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Allele frequency is theproportion of an allele in a population(✓\checkmark✓) and it can be affected by many factors, includingnatural selection, which is when organisms that aremore adaptedto an environment aremore likelytosurviveand breed (✓\checkmark✓). There arethree typesof natural selection;disruptive, stabilising and directional(✓\checkmark✓).Disruptive selectionis when selection pressures act toremove intermediate varieties,  causing the alleles for extreme traits toincrease in frequency(✓\checkmark✓), whichincreases the variation in a population(✓\checkmark✓). Stabilising selection is when selection pressures act toremove extreme varieties, causing thealleles for extreme traits to decrease(✓\checkmark✓), whichdecreases the variation in a population(✓\checkmark✓). Directional selection is whenselection pressuresact toremove one extreme, which results in theincrease of the favoured allele(✓\checkmark✓). Mutations arerandom changes to the DNA base sequence(✓\checkmark✓), if theyresult in favourable phenotypes, then the frequency of those alleles can increase in the population(✓\checkmark✓).A quality mark is awarded if each part of the question (a, b, c) is answered to earn at least half of the points available, answers do not require re-reading to be understood, and there are almost no errors and little irrelevant information.[1]

list.title: Question 332
list.content: Which organism contains DNA in just two different types of organelle?A.\hspace{1em}A treeB.\hspace{1em}A mushroomC.\hspace{1em}An ArchaeonD.\hspace{1em}A seaweed
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:All eukaryotic organisms contain organismal DNA in the cell nucleus and mitochondrial DNA in the mitochondria. Photosynthetic organisms additionally contain DNA in the chloroplasts. So, an organism that is a eukaryote but not photosynthetic contains DNA in exactly two organelles. A mushroom is a non-photosynthetic eukaryote, so a mushroom contains DNA in exactly two organelles.A tree (Choice A) and a seaweed (Choice D) each contain DNA in three organelles (nucleus, mitochondria, and chloroplasts). An Archaeon (Choice C) lacks membrane-bound organelles; its DNA is contained within the cytoplasm.

list.title: Question 333
list.content:
The diagram shows a solar system very similar to ours, where five planets orbit a central star.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d1815dc7-50c2-4579-afea-9498544e0f6d/images/b5e55501-0c1e-425e-8da0-e61f7243b9e5/BI1018.png)

[© Revision Village 2023]Define the term “Goldilocks zone”.[1]Label with the letter R the planet that is least likely to have extraterrestrial life present.[1]Explain reasons for your answer to part (i).[3]Some of the planets in this solar system have water present on them. Suggest where this water might have come from.[1]Explain why the planets referred to in part (i) have retained water, whereas others in this solar system have not.[2]Suggest one other biological molecule, other than water, that may be a sign of life on a planet.[1]
list.markScheme:
\hspace{1em}→\ce{ -> }​the zone around a star where temperatures allow for water to exist in a liquid state on the surface of planets[1][1 mark maximum]\hspace{1em}Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:\hspace{1em}The Goldilocks zone is the zonearound a starwheretemperaturesallowwaterto exist in aliquidstate on the surface of planets (✓\checkmark✓).→\ce{ -> }​line labelled with letter R, pointing to the furthest planet from the starORline labelled with letter R, pointing to the closest planet to the star[1][1 mark maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d1815dc7-50c2-4579-afea-9498544e0f6d/images/4c3b4745-b738-49da-8aa2-8d4d7c19e444/BI1018ansa.png)

[© Revision Village 2023]Anythreeof the following:If R is the planet furthest from the star:→\ce{ -> }​temperature is too cold[1]→\ce{ -> }​chemical reactions may be slowerORnot happen at all due to the lack of water as a solventORenzymes are unable to catalyse chemical reactions[1]If R is the planet closest to the star:→\ce{ -> }​temperature is too hot[1]→\ce{ -> }​chemical reactions may not happen at all due to the lack of water as a solvent,ORenzymes are denaturedORunable to catalyse chemical reactions[1]Applies to either answer:→\ce{ -> }​unlikely to have 	liquid water on the surface of the planetORis outside the Goldilocks zoneANDwater is a necessary resource for the survival of all known organisms[1][3 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:The planet furthest from the star is the least likely to have extraterrestrial life, as it is furthest from the heat and light source, so it may betoo coldfor organisms to survive (✓\checkmark✓). It is outside the Goldilocks zone, which means that it isunlikely to have liquid waterand water is anecessary resourcefor the survival of all known organisms (✓\checkmark✓). The lack of liquid water also means that anychemical reactionsnecessary for life may be slower or not happen at all due to thelack of a solvent(✓\checkmark✓).→\ce{ -> }​asteroidsORcomets[1][1 mark maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Water on some of the planets may have come fromasteroids(✓\checkmark✓) which contained ice and collided with the planet.BOTHof the following:→\ce{ -> }​gravity stops water from escaping[1]→\ce{ -> }​temperatures low enough to condense water[1][2 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Some planets in the solar system retain water because the force ofgravityon those planets prevents water from escaping those planets (✓\checkmark✓), and the distance from the star keeps thetemperatureson those planetslowenough to allow water tocondense(✓\checkmark✓).Anyoneof the following:→\ce{ -> }​nucleic acids[1]→\ce{ -> }​proteinsORamino acids[1]→\ce{ -> }​carbohydrates[1]→\ce{ -> }​lipidsORfats[1]→\ce{ -> }​methane - indicates methanogens[1]→\ce{ -> }​oxygen- indicates photosynthetic organisms[1]→\ce{ -> }​ammonia - indicates biological process, including the nitrogen cycle[1][1 mark maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:One other biological molecule that may suggest the presence of life on a planet iscarbohydrates(✓\checkmark✓).

list.title: Question 334
list.content:
The diagrams below show two cladograms for primates. One cladogram was made using data from DNA sequences and the other using amino acid sequences.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d834264a-48ae-474c-af53-c7ed003a94e8/images/d839b234-e401-4a51-ae04-32fd9b023985/BI0272.png)

[Source: Adapted from Bockman, P. (2011, October 3).File: Primate cladogram.jpg. Wikimedia commons. Retrieved June 14, 2022, from https: //commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File: Primate_cladogram.jpg CC-BY-SA-3.0]Identify the organism(s) most closely related to humans in the cladogram based on…DNAsequences[1]amino acidsequences[1]Describe the advantage of using DNA sequences to construct cladograms compared to amino acid sequences.[2]Suggest why cladograms made using physical features are not reliable predictors of phylogenetic relationships.[2]
list.markScheme: →\ce{ -> }​apes[1][1 mark maximum]→\ce{ -> }​old world monkeysANDnew world monkeys[1][1 mark maximum]Anytwoof the following:→\ce{ -> }​the nucleotide sequence of a gene contains more information than the amino acid sequence of the corresponding polypeptides[1]→\ce{ -> }​silent mutations alter the DNA sequence but do not affect the amino acid sequence[1]→\ce{ -> }​degeneracy in the genetic code means a mutation does not necessarily change the amino acid sequence[1]→\ce{ -> }​greater information can be obtained by DNA sequence analysis because variability in both the coding and non-coding regions of the genome can be examined[1]→\ce{ -> }​DNA samples can be easily sequencedORDNA is cheaper to sequenceORDNA sequencing yields more data whereas the approach to sequencing of proteins varies with type of protein[1]→\ce{ -> }​DNA sequence can be used to establish amino acid sequence, but not the other way around[1][2 mark maximum]Sample Answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample Answer}}Sample Answer​:Using DNA sequences to construct cladograms is advantageous because due to the existence ofcoding and non-coding regions(✓\checkmark✓) of DNA,more information(✓\checkmark✓) is held in the nucleotide sequence than the amino acid sequence . Also mutations may occur in the DNA which do not show up in the amino acid sequence due to thedegenerative code(✓\checkmark✓) leading tosilent mutations(✓\checkmark✓).Any two  of the following:→\ce{ -> }​adaptive radiation can result in closely related species showing very different structural features[1]→\ce{ -> }​convergent evolution means that distantly related organisms may show very similar structural features[1]→\ce{ -> }​analogous structures are derived through separate evolutionary pathways and are not indicators of evolutionary relationships[1]→\ce{ -> }​DNA and amino acid analysis have shown that some classification of organisms based on shared structural features was incorrect[1][2 mark maximum]Sample Answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample Answer}}Sample Answer​:Cladograms are no longer based on structural features due to the presence ofanalogous structures, which are the result ofconvergent evolution(✓\checkmark✓) and so arenot indicators of evolutionary relationships(✓\checkmark✓). DNA and amino acid analysis have shown that many cladograms based solely onshared structural featuresare incorrect (✓\checkmark✓).

list.title: Question 335
list.content: Which of the following statements explains how water has facilitated the evolution of life on Earth?A.\hspace{1em}Water acts as a catalyst for chemical reactionsB.\hspace{1em}Water acts as a solvent allowing chemical reactions to occur faster within itC.\hspace{1em}Water acts in hydrolysis reactions allowing for the synthesis of large biological moleculesD.\hspace{1em}Water has a high latent heat of vaporisation so is able to convert between states easily
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Water's unique ability to act as a solvent is crucial for life's evolution. Many biochemical reactions that are fundamental to life occur within aqueous environments. Water's solvent properties facilitate the dissolution and interaction of molecules, enabling chemical reactions to occur more rapidly and efficiently.Choice Bis, therefore, correct.Water acts as a reaction medium for many chemical reactions, but does not catalyse the chemical reactions that facilitate evolution,Choice Ais incorrect.Choice Cis incorrect as hydrolysis reactions break down larger molecules into smaller ones.Choice Dis incorrect as water’s high latent heat of vaporisation means that it requires a lot of energy to convert liquid water into a gas.

list.title: Question 336
list.content: Which feature of Archaea helped biologists to classify them in a separate domain from other prokaryotes?A.\hspace{1em}The presence of a cell wallB.\hspace{1em}The frequency of introns in the genomeC.\hspace{1em}The presence of linear chromosomesD.\hspace{1em}The difference in structure of membrane phospholipids
list.markScheme:
DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The rRNA sequencing by Carl Woese (1977) revealed that Eubacteria and Archaea are fundamentally different at a molecular level, including differences in membrane lipid structure.
Archaea have membrane phospholipids consisting of the L-glycerol in the phosphate group. Eubacteria, and Eukarya, have D-glycerol in the phosphate groups of their phospholipids.Choice Dis, therefore, correct.Choice Ais incorrect because cell walls are present in both domains (Archaea and Eubacteria), although made of different polymers.Choice Bis incorrect because introns (non-coding regions of DNA) are found in Eukaryota only, not in either of the prokaryote domains.Choice Cis incorrect because linear chromosomes are found in Eukaryota only, not in either of the prokaryote domains. The genomes of Archaea and Eubacteria are made of circular DNA.

list.title: Question 337
list.content: Which row in the table is correct for either the biological or morphological species concept?ConceptSpecies DefinitionProposed by…A.\hspace{1em}BiologicalA group of organisms that can interbreed to produce fertile offspringLinnaeusB.\hspace{1em}BiologicalA group of organisms with shared traitsMayrC.\hspace{1em}MorphologicalA group of organisms that can interbreed to produce fertile offspringMayrD.\hspace{1em}MorphologicalA group of organisms with shared traitsLinnaeus
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The morphological concept refers to a species as a group of organisms with shared traits. It assumes that individuals that look alike are part of the same species. This was proposed by Linnaeus.Choice Dis correct.Choice Ais incorrect because although the definition of the biological species concept is correct, it was not proposed by Linnaeus, it was proposed by Mayr.Choices BandCare incorrect because neither the definitions nor the proposers are correct.

list.title: Question 338
list.content:
The graph shows the global human population since 1700 CE, with a projection made to 2086.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/fc62bbd6-bbe9-4221-9a0b-b191f799f8dd/images/5e38479b-021b-42bf-9f22-5749b575d27f/QuesEdit2.png)

[© Revision Village 2025]According to the projection, what will be the percentage population increase between 2000 and 2050 CE?A.\hspace{1em}27%B.\hspace{1em}38%C.\hspace{1em}62%D.\hspace{1em}88%
list.markScheme:
CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Cis correct because the global human population in 2000 was 6.0 billion, projected to increase to 9.7 billion by 2050.The increase is:
9.7 billion − 6.0 billion = 3.7 billionTo calculate the percentage increase:Percentage increase = (increasepopulationin2000)×100\dfrac{\ce{increase}}{\ce{population in 2000}}) \times 100populationin2000increase​)×100%= (3.7billion6.0billion)×100\dfrac{\ce{3.7 billion}}{\ce{6.0 billion}}) \times 1006.0billion3.7billion​)×100% = 61.67%All the choices are stated to 2 significant figures, so rounding this answer to two significant figures gives62%.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/fc62bbd6-bbe9-4221-9a0b-b191f799f8dd/images/254de718-6f94-46dc-b122-0decdf87d016/AnsEdit2.png)

Choices A, BandDare incorrect because they all contain calculation errors.

list.title: Question 339
list.content:
Which letter in the Venn diagram correctly matches a description of a speciation event?

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/20820265-d2c3-4e59-814e-19b8b0ef6f14/images/eab43cca-4ca7-478f-ba36-41e908d682e6/BI0868%20A4.1.11%20png.png)

[©Revision Village 2023.]A.\hspace{1em}Bonobos (Pan paniscus) and chimpanzees (Pan troglodytes) evolved from a common ancestor.B.\hspace{1em}A hybrid species (3n) was produced by two smartweed species (genusPersicaria) living in the same geographical region.C.\hspace{1em}Sub-species of tortoise (C. nigra beckiandC. nigra guntheri) in the Galapagos have evolved due to lava flow forming lava fields and impassable terrain.D.\hspace{1em}The tetraploid grey treefrog emerged as a new species distinct from its diploid relative leading to reproductive isolation despite occupying the same geographical area.
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Bis correct because speciation through polyploidy is common in smartweed; if the resulting chromosome number is odd (here 3n), then the plants will become reproductively isolated from the 2n population, even though they are in the same geographic location. This is, therefore, an example of polyploidy and sympatric speciation.Choice Ais incorrect because, although bonobos and chimpanzees were geographically isolated from each other (allopatric speciation), there was no increase in the chromosome number during the speciation event.Choice Cis incorrect because the lava fields geographically isolated the tortoises, leading to sub-species forming. This is, therefore, an ongoing allopatric speciation event, not sympatric, and it does not involve polyploidy. The tetraploid frog resulted from a polyploidy speciation event that resulted in reproductive isolation. This did not involve spatial separation, so cannot be regarded as allopatric speciation; therefore,Choice Dis also incorrect.

list.title: Question 340
list.content: This table shows the estimated number of genes inE. colibacteria, fruit flies, mice, humans, and rice.SpeciesEstimated number of genesE.coli(bacteria species)4,000Drosophila melanogaster(fruit fly)13,000Canis lupis familiaris(dog)20,000Homo sapiens(humans)30,000Oryza sativa(rice)40,000What can you conclude from the above information?A.\hspace{1em}Species in the same kingdom of life have a similar number of genesB.\hspace{1em}Different species have different numbers of genesC.\hspace{1em}More complex species have more genesD.\hspace{1em}The number of genes is not a characteristic of a species
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Bis the correct answer.  This is a small sample of species, but the process of elimination meansChoice Bis the only possible correct answer. Fruit flies, humans and dogs are all in the animal kingdom but have different numbers of genes (Choice A).  This information shows that the number of genes does not determine the complexity, as rice has more genes than humans (Choice C). It is not possible to conclude that the number of genes is not a characteristic of a species from this small sample of data (Choice D).

list.title: Question 341
list.content: Which of the following statement(s) about the role of water as a solvent is correct?I.Salt can dissolve in water because it is hydrophilicII.Lipids cannot dissolve in water because they are non-polarIII.Cellulose can dissolve in water, as it is able to form hydrogen bondsA.\hspace{1em}I onlyB.\hspace{1em}I and III onlyC.\hspace{1em}I and II onlyD.\hspace{1em}I, II and III
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Salt, an ionic compound, dissolves readily in water because water is a polar solvent and can interact with the charged ions in salt through electrostatic attractions. Substances that have an affinity for water and can form interactions with water molecules are referred to as hydrophilic (Statement I). Lipids are non-polar molecules, and water is a polar solvent. Polar and non-polar substances do not readily mix because water molecules are attracted to each other through hydrogen bonding and other dipole-dipole interactions. Lipids are hydrophobic, meaning they repel water and do not dissolve well in it (Statement II).Choice Cis, therefore, correct.Although cellulose can form hydrogen bonds, it is insoluble (Statement III) as it is too large to dissolve in water;Choices BandDare therefore incorrect as they include this statement.Choice Ais incorrect as it does not includestatement II.

list.title: Question 342
list.content: Which isnotcharacteristic of HIV?A.\hspace{1em}The viral RNA encodes for reverse transcriptaseB.\hspace{1em}Spike glycoproteins allow for entry into CD4 cellsC.\hspace{1em}Two single strands of RNA are encased in a capsidD.\hspace{1em}Integrase proteins are required for entry into a host cell
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Dis correct because integrase proteins are not required to enter the host cell; integrase proteins are needed to integrate viral genetic information into host DNA. All other answer options (Choice A, Choice B, andChoice C) are characteristics of HIV.

list.title: Question 343
list.content:
Organisms may be reclassified using evidence from cladistics. Cladogram 1, based on DNA comparisons of several species, represents the historical view of relationships among arachnids. Cladogram 2, based on DNA comparisons of many more species than Cladogram 1, challenges the historical view.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9f58f8ff-0c6d-45ec-b83b-b630124d062a/images/facf56c0-5f41-4a9d-9e82-077c9b0d142f/BI0510.png)

[Source: Adapted from Ballesteros, J.A., Santibáñez-López, C.E., Baker, C.M.,  Benavides, L.R., Cunha T.J., Gainett, G., Ontano A.Z., Setton, E.V.W, Arango, C.P., Gavish-Regev, E., Harvey, M.S., Wheeler, W.C., Hormiga, G., Giribet, G., & Sharma, P.P. (2022).Comprehensive Species Sampling and Sophisticated Algorithmic Approaches Refute the Monophyly of Arachnida. Molecular Biology and Evolution, Volume 39, Issue 2, Retrieved March 15, 2022, from https://doi.org/10.1093/molbev/msac021. Copyright under CC BY 4.0]What is suggested by Cladogram 2 that is not suggested by Cladogram 1?A.\hspace{1em}Horseshoe crabs are a sister group of arachnids.B.\hspace{1em}Horseshoe crabs are a group within arachnids.C.\hspace{1em}Sea spiders are an ancestor of arachnids.D.\hspace{1em}Sea spiders are not an ancestor of horseshoe crabs.
list.markScheme:
BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Both cladograms show the relationships among arachnids and organisms related to arachnids. Cladogram 1 shows sea spiders and horseshoe crabs as related to, but not members, of the arachnids. Horseshoe crabs therefore form a sister group to the arachnids (A sister group is the closest relative to a given unit in a cladogram). Cladogram 2 shows horseshoe crabs as a group within the arachnids.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9f58f8ff-0c6d-45ec-b83b-b630124d062a/images/fc803d09-abaa-4f4e-bdb8-31f8b7aab5c1/BI0510A.png)

So, Cladogram 2 indicates that horseshoe crabs are a group within the arachnids, a relationship not indicated by Cladogram 1.Cladogram 1, not Cladogram 2, indicates that horseshoe crabs are a sister group of arachnids (Choice A). Both cladograms show that sea spiders were an ancestor of arachnids (Choices CandD).

list.title: Question 344
list.content: Which statement is true for both Lamarckism and epigenetic inheritance?A.\hspace{1em}Both involve changes in the DNA sequence that are inherited and lead to evolution.B.\hspace{1em}Both involve inherited changes caused by the environment, but the effect of epigenetics may only last a few generations, so it is not a type of evolution.C.\hspace{1em}Both operate by the use and disuse of traits, leading to evolutionary change.D.\hspace{1em}Only epigenetics leads to changes in the DNA sequence and, therefore, evolution.
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Bis correct because both Lamarckism and epigenetic inheritance propose that environmental factors can cause inherited changes, while Lamarckism suggested these changes were permanent and led to evolution through traits acquired during an organism's lifetime. Epigenetic changes involve reversible chemical modifications to DNA or histone proteins that affect gene expression without altering the DNA sequence. These epigenetic changes can be passed to offspring, but often only persist for a few generations and typically do not lead to long-term evolutionary change.Choice Ais incorrect because neither Lamarckism nor epigenetic inheritance involves changes to the DNA sequence itself. Epigenetics modifies gene expression through chemical tags, while Lamarckism assumed physical or behavioural changes were inherited.Choice Cis incorrect because only Lamarckism proposed that the use or disuse of traits directly causes evolutionary change. Epigenetic inheritance does not involve the use or disuse of structures but rather chemical changes to gene regulation influenced by environmental factors. Furthermore, epigenetics does not lead to evolution.Choice Dis incorrect because epigenetic inheritance does not involve changes to the DNA sequence itself and therefore does not cause long-term evolutionary change.

list.title: Question 345
list.content: Organisms that are better adapted to their environment are more likely to survive and thrive.Describe how the skin and mucous membranes provide both physical and chemical defence against pathogens.[4]Explain the importance of concentration gradients and the mechanisms that regulate them in the human ventilation system.[4]Discuss to what extent the fossil record provides evidence for evolution.[7]
list.markScheme: anyfourof the following:Answer must include one point from physical defence and one point from chemical defence to gain full marksPhysical defence→\ce{ -> }​skin provides a physical barrierORis composed of multiple tissue layers preventing pathogens from entering the body[1]→\ce{ -> }​skin continuously sheds dead cells which removes any pathogens on the surface[1]→\ce{ -> }​cells in skin are held together by tight junctions reinforcing the barrier functionORpreventing pathogens from passing between cells[1]→\ce{ -> }​mucus produced by mucous membranes can trap pathogens[1]→\ce{ -> }​mucus containing trapped pathogens is either expelled by the body or swallowed[1]→\ce{ -> }​cilia on mucous membrane surfaces move pathogensORforeign particles out of the body[1]Chemical defence→\ce{ -> }​sebaceous glands in the skin secrete sebum, which lowers the pH of the skin and inhibits the growth of bacteria and fungi[1]→\ce{ -> }​mucus contains lysozymeORantimicrobial enzymes which break down bacterial cell walls[1]→\ce{ -> }​sweat contains antimicrobialsORacids which inhibit growth of pathogens[1][4 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Theskinprovidesphysical defenceby forming abarrierthatprevents pathogensfromenteringthebody(✓\checkmark✓). It also provideschemical defenceagainst pathogens by havingsebaceous glandsthatsecrete sebum, whichlowersthepHof the skin and soinhibitsthegrowthofbacteriaandfungion the skin (✓\checkmark✓). Mucous membranes line the internal surfaces of some organs and body cavities and secrete mucus, which cantrap pathogens(✓\checkmark✓). The mucus is thenexpelledby the body orswallowed(✓\checkmark✓).anyfourof the following:→\ce{ -> }​steeper the concentration gradient, the greater the rate of diffusion, allowing for faster movement of molecules from areas of high concentration to areas of low concentration[1]→\ce{ -> }​inhaled air in alveoli has a higher concentration of oxygen than oxygen-depleted blood in the capillaries surrounding the alveoliORblood has a higher concentration of carbon dioxide than the air in the alveoli.[1]→\ce{ -> }​concentration gradients facilitate diffusion of oxygen from alveoli into bloodORcarbon dioxide from blood into alveoli, which provides cells with oxygen for respiration and removes waste carbon dioxide[1]→\ce{ -> }​large network of capillaries surrounding alveoli rapidly transport oxygen away from the lungsORrapidly transport carbon dioxide from the body to the lungs[1]→\ce{ -> }​the processes of inhalation and exhalation ensure that there is a constant flow of air in and out of lungs[1]→\ce{ -> }​chemoreceptors in carotid arteryORaortaORmedulla monitor blood pH levelsORblood carbon dioxide concentrations[1]→\ce{ -> }​chemoreceptors send signals to respiratory centre in medulla oblongata OR brain stem[1]respiratory centreORmedulla oblongata controls breathing rateORdepth of breathing to maintain concentration gradient of oxygen[1][4 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Efficient gas exchange in the lungs relies on maintaining concentration gradients, whereinhaled airin thealveolihas ahigher concentrationofoxygenthanoxygen-depleted bloodand alower concentrationofcarbon dioxide than that inthe surroundingcapillaries(✓\checkmark✓). This gradient allowsoxygentodiffuse fromthealveoliinto thebloodandcarbon dioxide fromtheblood intothealveoli(✓\checkmark✓). An extensivenetwork of capillariessurrounding the alveoli rapidlytransports oxygen awayfrom thelungsandcarbon dioxide tothe lungs (✓\checkmark✓). The processes ofinhalationandexhalationensure aconstant flowofairin and out of the lungs,maintainingthesegradients(✓\checkmark✓).Chemoreceptorsin thecarotid arteryandaortamonitorblood pH(✓\checkmark✓), sendingsignals totherespiratory centretoadjust breathing rateanddepth(✓\checkmark✓).Aaysevenof the following:Answer must include one answer from ‘provides evidence’ and one answer from ‘doesn’t provide’ evidence to gain full marksProvides evidence→\ce{ -> }​some organisms have very good fossil records, which allow their evolution to be tracked easily, e.g. horses[1]→\ce{ -> }​the sequence of fossils that appear in layers of rock matches the sequence in which they would be expected to evolve[1]→\ce{ -> }​older organisms appear in deeper rock layersORstrata, and more recently evolved organisms appear in the upper layers[1]→\ce{ -> }​there are fossils of extinct organisms with transitional formsORfossils of extinct organisms that have features that link different stages of evolution, e.g. Archaeopteryx, bird-like dinosaurs that support the hypothesis that birds evolved from reptiles[1]→\ce{ -> }​the fossil record shows evidence of mass extinction eventsORthere
