are many more extinct species than living ones[1]→\ce{ -> }​fossils show evidence of adaptive radiationORdivergence of different organisms from a common ancestorORspeciation[1]→\ce{ -> }​the fossil record shows evidence of vestigial structures that are no longer present in current organisms[1]→\ce{ -> }​there is fossil evidence for the existence of the last universal common ancestor (LUCA) near hydrothermal vents[1]→\ce{ -> }​fossils provide chronological evidence that supports the theory of gradualism in evolution, where small changes accumulate over long periods[1]→\ce{ -> }​fossilised remains of early hominids show a clear progression in brain sizeORbipedalism, supporting human evolution[1]Doesn’t provide evidence→\ce{ -> }​fossil record is incomplete, with many gapsORsome fossil species appear abruptly in the fossil record without any precursors[1]→\ce{ -> }​some species in the fossil record appear not to have changed much over long periods of time[1]→\ce{ -> }​convergent evolutionORfossils of unrelated organisms with similar features makes it difficult to track evolution accurately[1]→\ce{ -> }​soft-bodied organisms are rarely fossilised, leading to an incomplete record that skews our understanding of evolutionary history[1]→\ce{ -> }​process of fossilisation is rare and biased towards certain environments, meaning that the fossil record may not accurately represent all ecosystems and organisms[1][7 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:The fossil record supports evolution because some organisms havewell-documented fossil recordsthat allow their evolutionary changes to betracked easily(✓\checkmark✓). Additionally, thesequencein whichfossils appear in rock layersmatches the sequence in which they would beexpected to evolve(✓\checkmark✓). For example,olderorganisms are found indeeper layersof rocks, while morerecently evolved organismsare found in theupper layers(✓\checkmark✓). There are also fossils of extinct organisms withtransitional features, such as Archaeopteryx, a bird-like dinosaur, which supports the hypothesis that birds evolved from reptiles and providesevolutionary linksbetween present and extinct species (✓\checkmark✓). However, there aregapsin the fossil record (✓\checkmark✓), some species appear not to havechanged over long periods of time(✓\checkmark✓), andconvergent evolutioncan make it difficult to track evolution accurately (✓\checkmark✓).A quality mark is awarded if each part of the question (a, b, c) is answered to earn at least half of the points available, answers do not require re-reading to be understood, and there are almost no errors and little irrelevant information.

list.title: Question 346
list.content:
Natural classification is used to group organisms with common ancestry together, based on similarities and shared characteristics. All organisms can be classified into one of the three domains.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/dec0eb78-75d9-46b9-8d5b-dd3556815829/images/5ca392ca-aa33-406f-ace3-eb2621e12545/BI0260.png)

[ © Revision Village 2022]List three characteristics of Eubacteria.[3]Distinguish between archaeans and eukaryotes.[1]Outline how a case study like the reclassification of the figwort family (Scrophulariaceae) demonstrates the limitations of morphology-based taxonomy.[4]
list.markScheme: anythreeof the following:→\ce{ -> }​unicellular[1]→\ce{ -> }​prokaryoticORno true nucleusORno membrane-bound organelles[1]→\ce{ -> }​single chromosome[1]→\ce{ -> }​DNA is a loop[1]→\ce{ -> }​proteins associated with DNA may or may not be present[1]→\ce{ -> }​70S ribosomes[1]→\ce{ -> }​cell wall made of peptidoglycan[1][3 marks maximum]Sample Answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample Answer}}Sample Answer​:Eubacteria are organisms that areunicellular(✓\checkmark✓) and have no true nucleus. They havea single chromosome(✓\checkmark✓) that is aloop(✓\checkmark✓) andhistone proteins may or may not be present(✓\checkmark✓). Theribosomes of Eubacteria are 70S(✓\checkmark✓) and theircell walls are made of peptidoglycan(✓\checkmark✓).anyoneof the following:→\ce{ -> }​Archaea do not have membrane-bound organellesWHEREASEukaryota do have membrane-bound organelles[1]→\ce{ -> }​Archaea do not have a nucleusWHEREASEukaryota do have a nucleus[1]→\ce{ -> }​Archaea have circular chromosomesWHEREASEukaryota have linear chromosomes[1][1 mark maximum]Sample Answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample Answer}}Sample Answer​:Archaeahave circular chromosomesbut Eukaryotahave linear chromosomes(✓\checkmark✓). Archaeado not have a nucleusbut Eukaryota do (✓\checkmark✓).anyfourof the following:→\ce{ -> }​morphology-based taxonomy relies on physical similarities in structuress[1]→\ce{ -> }​similarities used in morphology-based classification may result from convergent evolution, not common ancestry[1]→\ce{ -> }​convergent evolution produces analogous structures that look similar but evolved independently[1]→\ce{ -> }​the figwort familyORScrophulariaceaewas originally grouped based on morphological traits[1]→\ce{ -> }​molecular and cladistic analyses showed that some species classified in the figwort family were more closely related to species in other families[1]→\ce{ -> }​led to the reclassification of many species into different families based on genetic evidence[1]→\ce{ -> }​case study shows that relying only on morphology can mislead taxonomy because of homoplasy OR similar traits not due to common ancestry[1]→\ce{ -> }​cladistics, using DNAORmolecular data, provides a more objective and accurate method for determining evolutionary relationships[1]→\ce{ -> }​reclassification highlights how scientific classifications are hypotheses that can be falsified or revised with new evidence[1][4 marks maximum]Sample Answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample Answer}}Sample Answer​:The figwort family wasoriginally classifiedbased onmorphological traits, such asflower shape(✓\checkmark✓). However,DNA sequencingandcladistic analysisshowed thatsome specieswere more closely related to plants in other families,not sharingarecent common ancestorwith thefigworts(✓\checkmark✓). This finding demonstrated that thesimilarities in structureresulted fromconvergent evolution, whereunrelated speciesdevelopsimilar traitsindependently (✓\checkmark✓). Therefore,relying solelyonmorphologycan bemisleading in classification, highlighting the importance ofmolecular dataformore accurateevolutionary relationships (✓\checkmark✓).

list.title: Question 347
list.content: Which of the following are a reason why water's properties would have influenced early cellular evolution in aquatic environments?I.High surface tension allowing formation of proto-cell membranes.II.Polar solvent properties enabling interaction of biomolecules.III.High density causing rapid sedimentation of organic material.A.\hspace{1em}I onlyB.\hspace{1em}II onlyC.\hspace{1em}II and III onlyD.\hspace{1em}I and III only
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Water's ability to dissolve biomolecules and, therefore, enabling them to interact (Statement II) would have been crucial to early cellular evolution. This property allows for the formation of a "primordial soup," where simple organic molecules could interact, form more complex compounds, and eventually lead to the development of proto-cells.Choice Bis the correct answer to this question.While surface tension is a property of water, it does not directly contribute to the formation of proto-cell membranes (Statement I) in the context of early cellular evolution. Proto-cell membranes are primarily formed by the self-assembly of amphipathic molecules like phospholipids, which align themselves in a bilayer in water due to their hydrophilic and hydrophobic regions.Organic molecules needed to remain in suspension for interactions, rather than settling quickly (Statement III). Water's density is well-suited for suspending organic particles, allowing them to remain available for biochemical reactions, while enabling gradual sedimentation over time.Choices A, CandDare incorrect as they include one or more untrue statements.

Allium angulosumAllium oleraeceum2n = 164n = 32[Source: Adapted from Lefnaer, S. (2015, July 26).Category: allium angulosum. Wikimedia Commons. Retrieved January 8, 2023, from https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File: Allium_angulosum_sl3.jpg. Copyright under CC BY 4.0][Source: Adapted from Leidus, I. (2013, July 7).File: allium oleraceum - rohulauk.jpg- wikimedia commons. Wikimedia commons. Retrieved January 8, 2023, from https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:  Allium_oleraceum_-_rohulauk.jpg. Copyright under CC BY 3.0]Suggest how polyploidy may occur in plants.[1]Outline how polyploidy in a species can lead to speciation.[2]With reference to plant hormones, explain the directional growth observed in the image ofAllium oleraceum.[3]Plants within theAlliumgenus often have bulbs which grow underground. Outline how bulbs can be considered sinksandsources in the process of translocation.[2]
list.markScheme: Anyoneof the following:→\ce{ -> }​hybridisation events between closely related plant speciesORgametes of two closely related plant species fuse[1]→\ce{ -> }​extra set of chromosomes formed during DNA replication stage in interphaseORcell cycle[1]→\ce{ -> }​a diploid gamete fuses with a haploid gameteORtwo diploid gametes fuse together[1]→\ce{ -> }​failed spindle formationORnon-disjunctionORfailed separation of chromosomesINmeiosis leading to gametes with extra set of chromosomes[1]→\ce{ -> }​chromosomal duplications in cells involved in vegetativeORasexual reproduction[1][1 mark maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Polyploidy can occur in plants if there arehybridisationevents betweenclosely related plantspecies (✓\checkmark✓).Anytwoof the following:→\ce{ -> }​organisms with a different number of chromosomesORnew tetraploid and original diploid cannot breed together to produce fertile offspring[1]→\ce{ -> }​results in reproductive isolation[1]→\ce{ -> }​polyploid plants may be largerORmore fertileORbetter adapted than original populations allowing them to exploit different ecological niches leading to geographical isolation[1]→\ce{ -> }​once isolated polyploid population diverges genetically from original populations[1][2 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:The new polyploid organism has a different number of chromosomes than the original plant and so theycannot breedtogether to producefertile offspring(✓\checkmark✓). This can result inreproductive isolation(✓\checkmark✓), which could lead to the formation of a new species.Anythreeof the following:→\ce{ -> }​plant stemsORAllium oleraceumstems respond to light by growing towards itORplant stems are positively phototropic[1]→\ce{ -> }​auxin is produced by actively dividing cells in the tip of the stemORin the meristem[1]→\ce{ -> }​light causes auxin to accumulate on the shaded side of the stem[1]→\ce{ -> }​auxin efflux pumps bring about increased concentration on shaded side[1]→\ce{ -> }​this causes cells on the shaded side to elongate[1]→\ce{ -> }​auxin causes protons to be pumped from cytoplasm of cells into cell wall lowering pH[1]→\ce{ -> }​lowering of pH loosens linkages between cellulose fibres so when water enters cell wall stretches and cell elongates[1][3 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Allium oleraceumhas apositive phototropicresponse to light (✓\checkmark✓).Auxinis released from theactively dividing cellsof themeristem(✓\checkmark✓). Light stimulates auxin toaccumulateon theshadedside of thestem(✓\checkmark✓), so thatcellson theshaded side elongate(✓\checkmark✓).Anytwoof the following:Answer must include statements supporting bulbs being a sink and supporting bulbs being a source to gain full marksBulbs are a source because…→\ce{ -> }​when the plant is not actively photosynthesising, it uses sucroseORstarchORcarbohydrateORnutrientsORamino acids stored in bulb[1]Bulbs are a sink because…→\ce{ -> }​when the plant is actively photosynthesising it will provide carbohydratesORglucoseORsucroseORstarch, for storage inORgrowth of, bulb[1][2 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:At thebeginningof thegrowingseason, the bulb is asourcebecause the plant isnotactivelyphotosynthesising, so it needs to use thesucrose and amino acids stored in the bulbsforgrowth(✓\checkmark✓).   However, during themiddleof the growing season, when the plant isactively photosynthesising,sucroseistransportedfrom theleaves to the bulbtostoretheexcess carbohydrateand so the bulb becomes asink(✓\checkmark✓).

list.title: Question 350
list.content: The table shows the number of bases in a single DNA strand that codes for a strand of mRNA. The strand contains no introns.The letters X, Y and Z represent the percentage of each type of base in the mRNA.BasesNumber of kilobases (kb) in the DNA strandPercentage of same bases in the mRNAAdenine3123.3Cytosine22XGuanine26YThymine24ZWhich option shows the correct percentages of bases in the mRNA synthesised?A.\hspace{1em}X= 25.2%,Y= 21.4%,Z= 30.1%B.\hspace{1em}X= 21.4%,Y= 25.2%,Z= 23.3%C.\hspace{1em}X= 25.2%,Y= 21.4%,Z= 0%D.\hspace{1em}X= 21.4%,Y= 25.2%,Z= 0%
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The correct answer isChoice Cbecause there are 103 kb in total in the DNA strand. This means that in the DNA strand, 30.1% of bases are adenine (31103×100\dfrac{31}{103} \times 10010331​×100%), 21.4% of bases are cytosine (22/103 x 100), 25.2% of bases are guanine (26103×100\dfrac{26}{103} \times 10010326​×100%) and 23.3% of bases are thymine (24103×100\dfrac{24}{103} \times 10010324​×100%). In the mRNA, these bases will be matched with their complementary base pair, so that the percentage value in the cytosine row will be the same as the percentage of guanine, so X = 25.2%. Likewise, Y will be the cytosine percentage (21.4%). Z is 0%, as there are no thymine bases found in mRNA, only uracil.Choice Ais not correct because even though X and Y are showing the right percentages, Z is incorrect as it is showing the percentage of uracil, not thymine.Choice Bis not correct because the percentages shown are for the DNA not for the complementary base pair of that base (which would be found in the mRNA), Z is also incorrect as it is showing the percentage of uracil, not thymine.Choice Dis not correct because the percentages shown are for the DNA not for the complementary base pair of that base (which would be found in the mRNA).

list.title: Question 351
list.content: Which of the following shows the correct components of one nucleosome?Number of histone moleculesNumber of loops the DNA formed\hspace{1.5em}A.\hspace{1.5em}eightsingle\hspace{1.5em}B.\hspace{1.5em}eightdouble\hspace{1.5em}C.\hspace{1.5em}foursingle\hspace{1.5em}D.\hspace{1.5em}fourdouble

anyoneof the following→\ce{ -> }​biologically maleBECAUSEthey have a Y chromosomeORthey have 22 pairs of homologous chromosomesAND1 pair of non-homologous sex chromosomes[1][1 mark maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:The foetus is biologicallymalebecause they have aY chromosome(✓\checkmark✓).anythreeof the following→\ce{ -> }​parental genotypes identified in the Punnett square; biological father:XXhY\ce{X^hY}XXhYANDbiological mother:XXHXXh\ce{X^HX^h}XXHXXh[1]→\ce{ -> }​offspring genotypes identified asXXHY,XXhY\ce{X^HY, X^hY}XXHY,XXhY[1]→\ce{ -> }​0.50OR50%OR12\frac{1}{2}21​[1][3 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:

The probability of a biologically male foetus having haemophilia is50 %(✓\checkmark✓).anyoneof the following→\ce{ -> }​it is a sex-linked recessive disease,ORthe gene is carried on the X chromosomeANDbiological males only have one X chromosome, so if they have the recessive allele, they will have the disease, whereas biological females with one copy would be carriers[1]→\ce{ -> }​for a biological female to have haemophilia, they would need to have two copies of the recessive allele, whereas biological males only need one copy of the recessive allele to have haemophilia[1][1 mark chromosome, so inheriting therecessive allele resultsin thedisease, whilebiological femaleswithtwo X chromosomescan becarriers without symptoms(✓\checkmark✓).anythreeof the following (at leastoneadvantage andonedisadvantage must be given to gain full marks)advantages:→\ce{ -> }​adult stem cells can be obtained from the individual needing treatment, reducing the risk of immune rejectionWHILEembryonic stem cells may be rejected by the patient’s immune system[1]→\ce{ -> }​harvesting adult stem cells is generally less controversialORhas fewer ethical implications compared to embryonic stem cells[1]→\ce{ -> }​adult stem cells have a lower risk of producing tumours compared to embryonic stem cells[1]→\ce{ -> }​adult stem cell therapies generally face fewer regulatory hurdles and greater public acceptance compared to therapies involving embryonic stem cells[1]disadvantages:→\ce{ -> }​adult stem cells are multipotentORare often restricted in the number of cell types they can produceWHILEembryonic stem cells are pluripotentORcan differentiate into any bpdy cell type[1]→\ce{ -> }​adult stem cells are limited in number within adult tissuesORcan be challenging to obtainORcultureWHILEembryonic stem cells are more numerous OR easier to harvest[1]→\ce{ -> }​adult stem cells have less potential for long-term proliferationORdurability in cultureCOMPARED TOembryonic stem cells[1]→\ce{ -> }​adult stem cells are derived from fully developed tissues so typically more differentiated,WHEREASembryonic stem cells are derived from a very early developmental stage so less differentiated[1][3 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Oneadvantageof using adult stem cells in therapy is that they can be obtained from the patient,reducing the risk of immune rejection(✓\checkmark✓). Additionally, harvesting adult stem cells isless controversialand hasfewer ethical implications(✓\checkmark✓) compared to embryonic stem cells. However, adult stem cells aremultipotentandlimitedin thetypes of cells(✓\checkmark✓)  they can produce, unlike pluripotent embryonic stem cells. Moreover, adult stem cells areless numerousandharder to harvest(✓\checkmark✓) than embryonic stem cells.

list.title: Question 353
list.content: Adaptive radiation results in a single ancestral species evolving into multiple, closely related new species which may live in close proximity to each other.  Outline 3 mechanisms by which closely related species living in close proximity may be reproductively isolated.[3]Outline the process by which two species may be formed from an ancestral population through the process of allopatric speciation.[5]Explain what polyploidy is and how it can lead to speciation.[7]
list.markScheme: Anythreeof the following:→\ce{ -> }​behavioural isolationORfailure to recognise members of different species as possible mates[1]→\ce{ -> }​temporal isolationORreproduction occurs at different times[1]→\ce{ -> }​postzygotic barriers[1]→\ce{ -> }​habitat isolation, whereby a subsection of one population occupies a different ecological niche[1]→\ce{ -> }​hybrid offspring are sterile[1]→\ce{ -> }​mechanical isolationORdifferent morphological structures evolve, resulting in physical incompatibility[1]→\ce{ -> }​two closely related species may have different numbers of chromosomes[1]→\ce{ -> }​incompatibility of gametesORinability of sperm to fertilise egg[1][3 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Species living close to one another may bereproductively isolateddue tobehavioural isolation(✓\checkmark✓), which is afailuretorecognisepotentialmates.  Two species may also be isolated due topostzygotic barriers(✓\checkmark✓).  For example, theiroffspringcould besterile(✓\checkmark✓).Anyfiveof the following:→\ce{ -> }​geographic isolationORancestral population is separated into two areasORany named example, e.g.  mountain range, isthmus[1]→\ce{ -> }​different random mutations accrue in the two different populationsORdifferent alleles are produced in the two different populations[1]→\ce{ -> }​different phenotypes are produced in the two different populations[1]→\ce{ -> }​different selection pressures in two different areas[1]→\ce{ -> }​different traits selected for in two different areas[1]→\ce{ -> }​genetic drift[1]→\ce{ -> }​reproductive isolationORbehavioural isolationORtemporal isolationORpost-zygotic barriers[1]→\ce{ -> }​gene flow cannot occur[1]→\ce{ -> }​changes occur over many generations[1][5 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:The ancestral population could have been divided intotwo populationsby the formation of amountain range(✓\checkmark✓), which meansgene flowbetween the two populationsdoes not occur(✓\checkmark✓).Random mutationsthen build up (✓\checkmark✓) between the two populations leading tonew phenotypes(✓\checkmark✓).Selectionpressures maydiffer(✓\checkmark✓) between the two populations which meansdifferent phenotypeswould be selected for in thetwo different environments.  Eventually, the two different populations may becomereproductively isolated(✓\checkmark✓).Anysevenof the following:→\ce{ -> }​genetic condition in which an organism has more than two complete sets of chromosomes in its cells[1]→\ce{ -> }​more common in plants[1]→\ce{ -> }​formation of new species is through two main mechanisms: autopolyploidy and allopolyploidy[1]→\ce{ -> }​autopolyploidy occurs due to failure of chromosomes to separate during meiosis[1]→\ce{ -> }​autopolyploidy occurs within one species[1]→\ce{ -> }​reproductive isolation of polyploid individuals from diploid population[1]→\ce{ -> }​reducedORcessation of gene flow in population due to polyploids being incompatible with diploids[1]→\ce{ -> }​polyploid population begins to evolve independently from the diploid populationORgenetic divergence occurs[1]→\ce{ -> }​allopolyploidy occurs when two different species interbreed and produce hybrid offspring[1]→\ce{ -> }​can result in an entire extra set of chromosomes from each parent species[1]→\ce{ -> }​allopolyploid individuals often reproduce asexually due to the mismatched chromosomes from different species[1]→\ce{ -> }​asexual reproduction acts as a reproductive barrier between the allopolyploid and its parent species[1]→\ce{ -> }​reduced gene flow allows for independent evolutionORgenetic divergence[1]→\ce{ -> }​over time, the allopolyploid population may accumulate genetic differences and adapt to specific ecological niches, leading to the formation of a new species[1]→\ce{ -> }​polyploidy can result in odd ploidy numberOR3n, 5n, etc. in daughter species[1]→\ce{ -> }​individuals with odd ploidy number cannot undergo meiosis which acts as a reproductive barrier[1][7 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Polyploidy is the condition of havingmorethantwo setsofchromosomes(✓\checkmark✓).Autopolyploidyis due to the failure of chromosomes toseparateduringmeiosis(✓\checkmark✓).  Often, autopolyploid individuals arereproductively isolated(✓\checkmark✓) from the parent species due to theirgametesbeingincompatiblewith the diploid parent’s gametes.Allopolyploidspecies are produced when two differentspecies hybridise(✓\checkmark✓) resulting in a daughter species with anextra set of chromosomesfrom each parent species (✓\checkmark✓).In bothallopolyploids and autopolyploids(✓\checkmark✓), occasionally individuals are produced withodd ploidy numbers(ex: 3n, 5n) (✓\checkmark✓).  These individuals will generally beunableto undergomeiosis(✓\checkmark✓), willreproduce asexuallyand thus bereproductively isolatedfrom their parent species (✓\checkmark✓).Once two populations are reproductively isolated there isno gene flow(✓\checkmark✓) and a new species is produced.A quality mark is awarded if each part of the question (a, b, c) is answered to earn at least half of the points available, answers do not require re-reading to be understood, and there are almost no errors and little irrelevant information.[1]

list.title: Question 354
list.content:
The table shows genome sizes for several different species.OrganismGenome Size (base pairs)Escherichia coli(Bacterium)5 millionSaccharomyces cerevisiae(Yeast)12 millionDrosophila melanogaster(Fruit Fly)140 millionXenopus laevis(Frog)????Homo sapiens3 billionDescribe the challenges of predicting the size of the genome ofXenopus laevisbased on the information provided in the table.[2]Single-cell genome sequencing allows researchers to analyse the genetic material of individual cells. Cancer is characterised by significant genomic instability, leading to massive variations in genome size when compared to noncancerous cells.Explain how single-cell genome sequencing can be more useful than traditional genome sequencing for developing effective cancer treatments.[3]The diagram below depicts nanopore DNA sequencing technology.  This portable technology involves passing a single piece of DNA through a tiny pore in a membrane in an electrical field in a manner such that the current can reveal the DNA sequence.  This allows for the analysis of environmental DNA (eDNA), which consists of DNA fragments shed by organisms into their surroundings (e.g., skin cells, waste).  It can also give almost immediate results for shorter fragments, and sequence entire genomes in as little as 3 days.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/bc9dbc7a-73a6-41de-bef4-c83dfff6f8fc/images/3d062db1-de82-446a-8141-4670a3bbbe8f/BI2802.png)

[Source: Adapted from National Institutes of Standards and Technology (2024, November 18)DNA Sequencing Method[image]. Wikimedia Commons. Retrieved 04:53, May 5, 2025 from https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?title=File:DNA_Sequencing_Method_ (8051510835).jpg&oldid=958458868.Public Domain]Discussonepotential benefit and one potential risk associated with the widespread use of portable DNA sequencing technologies.[2]Suggest ways whole-genome sequencing can contribute to our understanding of evolutionary relationships between species, and also to personalised medicine.[4]
list.markScheme: the following (award zero marks for a numerical prediction):→\ce{ -> }​genome size does not increase with complexity in a predictable manner[1]→\ce{ -> }​WHICH MEANSit is not possible to predict a genome size based on the information in the table[1][2 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:The genome size of Xenopus laeviscannot be predicted(✓\checkmark✓) from the table because there isno correlationbetween organismcomplexity and genome size(✓\checkmark✓).anythreeof the following:→\ce{ -> }​traditional whole-genome sequencing provides an average genomic profile of the whole organismORnot just the tumour[1]→\ce{ -> }​single-cell sequencing can show differences between the typical genome of that organism and the tumor[1]→\ce{ -> }​single-cell sequencing can show differences within the tumour itself[1]→\ce{ -> }​heterogeneity within the tumour can provide cliniciansORresearchers with clues as to the best treatment options[1]→\ce{ -> }​comparison of single-cell genome sequencing of tumour with originating tissue can help clinicians predict which treatment option will best allow healthy tissue to survive[1]→\ce{ -> }​single-cell sequencing facilitates the development of more personalised and effective therapies[1][3 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Traditional whole-genomesequencing provides an overall genomic view of awhole organism(✓\checkmark✓), giving us an average of the genetic information across all cells.Single-cell sequencingoffers a moredetailedperspective by revealingdifferences(✓\checkmark✓) between the typical genome of that organism and the tumour cells.  Heterogeneity within the tumour can provide clinicians and researchers with crucial clues for determining themost effective treatment options(✓\checkmark✓).anytwoof the following(must includeonebenefit andonerisk):benefits→\ce{ -> }​enables rapid identification of pathogens in remote or resource-limited areas[1]→\ce{ -> }​faster response time for public health interventions[1]→\ce{ -> }​tracking of endangeredORinvasiveORelusive species by eDNA without the need for lab facilities[1]→\ce{ -> }​identification of species present in an ecosystem based on eDNA without the need for lab facilities[1]→\ce{ -> }​genetic analysis at the point of careORon-site for rapid treatment response[1]→\ce{ -> }​individual empowermentORaccountability over their own health[1]→\ce{ -> }​increased speed of identification of criminal suspectsORdisaster victims[1]risks→\ce{ -> }​privacy concerns due to easy access to genetic data[1]→\ce{ -> }​misuse of genetic informationORgenetic discrimination[1]→\ce{ -> }​misinterpretation of results by non-experts may lead to incorrect medical or legal decisions[1]→\ce{ -> }​potential for higher error rate[1]→\ce{ -> }​potential for bioterrorism[1]→\ce{ -> }​technological advancements moving faster than legal regulatory framework leads to misuse and abuse[1][2 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:One potential benefit of portable DNA sequencing is that it can providefaster results(✓\checkmark✓) because the sequencing can be done on-site rather than sent to a lab, which can take days.  One possible risk is that DNA samples can be collected from the environmentwithout the consent of the people, raising importantethical concerns(✓\checkmark✓).anyfourof the following, at least one must be presented for each applicationevolutionary relationships→\ce{ -> }​allows for comparison of whole genomes across species[1]→\ce{ -> }​identifies conserved regions and genes[1]→\ce{ -> }​facilitates the study of evolutionary genetic changes such as gene duplication, loss, chromosomal alterations and horizontal gene transfer[1]→\ce{ -> }​generates data for analysing genome patterns of evolution[1]→\ce{ -> }​extensive genetic data enables the creation of detailed and accurate phylogenetic trees[1]personalised medicine→\ce{ -> }​identifies genetic predispositions to disease[1]→\ce{ -> }​predict individual responses to drugs and medicines[1]→\ce{ -> }​characterise the genetic make-up of tumours to guide cancer treatment[1][4 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Whole-genome sequencing can contribute to the study of evolutionary relationships by identifying differences ingenetic patterns of evolution, such asgene duplication or lossandchromosomal duplication or loss(✓\checkmark✓).  It can alsoidentify conserved genesor regulatory sequences between species (✓\checkmark✓).  Whole-genome sequencing can contribute to personalised medicine through theidentification of genetic diseases(✓\checkmark✓) and predispositions to disease, as well as probable individual physiologicalresponses to treatmentoptions (✓\checkmark✓).

list.title: Question 355
list.content: Adaptive radiation results in a single ancestral species evolving into multiple, closely related new species which may live in close proximity to each other.  Outline 3 mechanisms by which closely related species living in close proximity may be reproductively isolated.[3]Outline the process by which two species may be formed from an ancestral population through the process of allopatric speciation.[5]Describe how sexual and asexual reproduction can lead to the formation of new species with different numbers of copies of each chromosome.[7]
list.markScheme: Anythreeof the following:→\ce{ -> }​behavioural isolationORfailure to recognise members of different species as possible mates[1]→\ce{ -> }​temporal isolationORreproduction occurs at different times[1]→\ce{ -> }​postzygotic barriers[1]→\ce{ -> }​habitat isolation, whereby a subsection of one population occupies a different ecological niche[1]→\ce{ -> }​hybrid offspring are sterile[1]→\ce{ -> }​mechanical isolation, whereby different morphological structures evolve, resulting in physical incompatibility[1]→\ce{ -> }​two closely related species may have different numbers of chromosomes[1]→\ce{ -> }​incompatibility of gametesORinability of sperm to fertilise egg[1][3 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Species living close to one another may be reproductively isolated due tobehavioural isolation(✓\checkmark✓), which is a failure to recognise potential mates.  Two species may also be isolated due topostzygotic barriers(✓\checkmark✓).  For example, theiroffspring could be sterile(✓\checkmark✓).Anyfiveof the following:→\ce{ -> }​geographic isolationORancestral population is separated into two areasORany named example, e.g.  mountain range, isthmus etc.[1]→\ce{ -> }​different random mutations accrue in the two different populations[1]→\ce{ -> }​different alleles are produced in the two different populations[1]→\ce{ -> }​different phenotypes are produced in the two different populations[1]→\ce{ -> }​different selection pressures in two different areas[1]→\ce{ -> }​different traits selected for in two different areas[1]→\ce{ -> }​genetic drift[1]→\ce{ -> }​reproductive isolationORbehavioural isolationORtemporal isolationORpost-zygotic barriers[1]→\ce{ -> }​gene flow cannot occur[1][5 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Theancestral population could have been divided into two populations by the formation of a mountain range(✓\checkmark✓), which meansgene flowbetween the two populationsdoes not occur(✓\checkmark✓).Random mutationsthen build up (✓\checkmark✓) between the two populations leading to theproduction of new alleles(✓\checkmark✓) andphenotypes(✓\checkmark✓).Selection pressures may differ(✓\checkmark✓) between the two populations as well, which means different phenotypes would be selected for in the two different environments.  Eventually, the two different populations may becomereproductively isolated(✓\checkmark✓).  For example, they may no longer recognise each other as potential mates.Anysevenof the following:Asexual reproduction:→\ce{ -> }​chromosome number of daughter species is an odd number[1]Sexual reproduction:→\ce{ -> }​the hybridisation of closely related species[1]→\ce{ -> }​new hybrid species has one set of chromosomes from each parent species[1]→\ce{ -> }​self-fertilisationORautogamy occurs, and chromosome number is doubledORhalved[1]→\ce{ -> }​fusion of two diploid gametesORanother valid example of fertilisation leading to a change in chromosome copy number[1]Both asexual and sexual reproduction:→\ce{ -> }​reproductive isolationORnew species are sometimes brought about by differences in chromosome copy number[1]→\ce{ -> }​abnormal meiotic division in parent species[1]→\ce{ -> }​daughter species is reproductively isolated from the parent species[1]→\ce{ -> }​daughter species reproduces asexually because meiosis is no longer possible[1][7 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Both sexually and asexually reproducing species can be produced whentwo closely related species hybridise(✓\checkmark✓) to produce a daughter species that can carry out mitosis and isreproductively isolated from the parent species(✓\checkmark✓).  Sometimes reproductive isolation in both sexually and asexually reproducing species is brought about by achange in chromosome copy number(✓\checkmark✓).  This is often due toabnormal meiotic divisions(✓\checkmark✓).  When anodd number of chromosomesis present (✓\checkmark✓) in the daughter species, for example, 3n,meiosis is impossible(✓\checkmark✓), and the daughter species can only reproduce asexually through mitosis.  If the daughter speciesreproduces through sexual reproduction, the chromosome copy number must be even(✓\checkmark✓) so thatmeiosis is possible(✓\checkmark✓).  Sometimes a single,self-fertilizing species may undergo abnormal meiotic divisions(✓\checkmark✓), which result in the production of anew species that has half(✓\checkmark✓) ordouble(✓\checkmark✓) the number of chromosomes and thus becomes reproductively isolated.A quality mark is awarded if each part of the question (a, b, c) is answered to earn at least half of the points available, answers do not require re-reading to be understood, and there are almost no errors and little irrelevant information.[1]

list.title: Question 356
list.content:
The diagram below shows the feeding areas of four species of warbler (genusSetophaga).  What is the best explanation for how these warblers came to coexist in such close proximity?

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/efab0b51-840a-4a0d-ba33-d1c317006c64/images/33161867-8ead-42eb-bf6d-c392376ff2be/BI0869.png)

[©Revision Village 2023.]A.\hspace{1em}Polyploidy resulted from multiple sympatric speciation events.B.\hspace{1em}Adaptive radiation reduced competition between the species.C.\hspace{1em}The presence of four species increases biodiversity and ecological stability.D.\hspace{1em}One species evolved over time to exploit new ecological niches.
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Bis correct because adaptive radiation involves exploiting new ecological niches and speciation, here resulting in 4 new species from the original ancestral species which compete less with one another.Choice Ais incorrect, as polyploidy is rare in vertebrates and animals generally. Although greater biodiversity generally increases ecological stability,Choice Cdoes not explain how the warblers came to coexist in such close proximity.Choice Dis incorrect because if only one species evolved to exploit new ecological niches, there would be only one warbler species, not four.

list.title: Question 357
list.content: Hershey and Chase conducted experiments using the radioactive isotopes35S and32P which demonstrated that DNA is the genetic material. What would they have observed about the distribution of isotopes in the centrifuged sample if protein, rather than DNA, were the genetic material?A.\hspace{1em}High proportion of35S in the bacterial pellet relative to the supernatant.B.\hspace{1em}High proportion of32P in the bacterial pellet relative to the supernatant.C.\hspace{1em}High proportion of both35S and32P in the bacterial pellet relative to the supernatant.D.\hspace{1em}Low proportion of both35S and32P in the bacterial pellet relative to the supernatant.
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Hershey and Chase grew bacteriophages in the presence of the radioactive isotope35S or32P, then allowed them to infect bacteria. If proteins, rather than DNA, had been the genetic material transferred to bacteria, the bacteria would have contained35S (the radiolabel in proteins) and not32P (the radiolabel in DNA). Therefore, Hershey and Chase would have observed a high proportion of35S in the bacterial pellet relative to the supernatant.A high proportion of32P in the bacterial pellet relative to the supernatant (Choice B) indicates that DNA, not protein, was the genetic material. Hershey and Chase did not grow bacteria in the presence of both isotopes at the same time and so could not have observed either a higher (Choice C) or lower (Choice D) proportion of both35S and32P in the bacterial pellet relative to the supernatant.

list.title: Question 358
list.content:
The graph below shows the results of an experiment conducted by a team of researchers investigating the relationship between the composition and melting point of different DNA samples. At the melting point, the DNA double helix separates into two individual strands.Two DNA samples were compared, one consisting of only PQ pairs and another one consisting of only RS pairs.  Letters P, Q, R and S represent different nitrogenous bases found in the DNA.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d59dd324-98c9-4e4e-91b6-758d5679701c/images/0881eea3-e69e-45cc-ad3b-7c9e377763b5/BI0321.png)

[ © Revision Village 2022]Based on the results presented in the graph, and your knowledge of nucleotide base pairing (between purines and pyrimidines), deduce which nitrogenous bases correspond to the letters P, Q, R and S.\hspace{2.5em}P\hspace{2.5em}\hspace{2.5em}Q\hspace{2.5em}\hspace{2.5em}R\hspace{2.5em}\hspace{2.5em}S\hspace{2.5em}\hspace{1.5em}A.\hspace{1.5em}CytosineGuanineThymineAdenine\hspace{1.5em}B.\hspace{1.5em}AdenineCytosineGuanineThymine\hspace{1.5em}C.\hspace{1.5em}GuanineAdenineThymineCytosine\hspace{1.5em}D.\hspace{1.5em}ThymineAdenineCytosineGuanine
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Adenine pairs up with thymine and cytosine pairs up with guanine. Hence, PQ or RS would either be adenine with thymine or cytosine with guanine (Choices AandD), but definitely notChoices BorC.Cytosine and guanine pairing has three hydrogen bonds, whereas the adenine and thymine pairing has only two hydrogen bonds. At95oC95^oC95oC, there is a smaller percentage of RS-rich DNA melted content compared to PQ-rich DNA.This shows that RS would be cytosine and guanine pairing (Choice D) and PQ is adenine and thymine. Because the extra hydrogen bond between C and G makes it more temperature resistant compared to A and T.
